questions.text: A 56-year-old man suffering from uncontrolled diabetes mellitus came for a routine checkup. His lipid profile revealed increased TG (triacylglycerol) and VLDL (very low-density lipoprotein). What is the cause of this abnormal lipid profile?

choices.text: Increased activity of lipoprotein lipase and decreased activity of hormone sensitive lipase
Increased activity of hormone sensitive lipase and decreased lipoprotein lipase activity
Increase in peripheral function of LDL receptors
Increased in activity of hepatic lipase

questions.solution:
In chronic diabetes, the values of TG and VLDL are increased due to an increase in hormone-sensitive lipase and a decrease in lipoprotein lipase.

Insulin has an inhibitory effect on hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL). In diabetes, low insulin corresponds to an increase in HSL activity. This promotes the breakdown of lipids and the release of TG and free fatty acids from the adipose tissue.

Insulin induces the activity of lipoprotein lipase (LPL) which is present on the capillary walls. LPL promotes hydrolysis of TG and the degradation of the transport proteins, VLDL, and chylomicrons. In diabetes, low insulin leads to decreased LPL activity which corresponds to an increase in VLDL and TG.

Related Pearl: Hormone sensitive lipase Vs lipoprotein lipase

   HSL  Lipoprotein lipase
Location  Adipocyte  Capillaries
Action  Hydrolyse TAG in adipose   tissue  Hydrolyse TAG in chylomicron , VLDL
Acts in the state of  Fasting (Glucagon)  Fed (Insulin)

questions.text: Rheobase is an indicator of which of the following?
questions.solution:
The rheobase is an indicator of the magnitude of the current. It is the minimum intensity (strength/magnitude) of stimulation required to generate an action potential when the stimulation is of infinite duration.

Utilization time is the minimum time (duration) for which the rheobase has to be applied for the excitation of tissue.

Chronaxie is the minimum time (duration) for which a stimulus double the strength of rheobase has to be applied for excitation of tissue.

Strength-duration curve gives the idea of the excitability of a tissue.

Strength-duration relationship arises because the same minimum electrical charge necessary to excite an action potential can come from a current that is either brief but large or prolonged but small. It is the product of strength and duration that determines excitability, and thus these two parameters are inversely related in their effectiveness.

Note: Chronaxie is a better index than rheobase and utilization time for comparing the excitability of a tissue.

questions.text: Which of the following treatments is appropriate for congenital hydrocele in a 2-year-old child?
questions.solution:
• Congenital hydroceles are treated by herniotomy if they do not resolve spontaneously.
  • In congenital hydrocele, the processus vaginalis is patent and connects with the peritoneal cavity. Hence all that is required for treatment is ligation of the processus (herniotomy).
  • Remember that herniotomy is the treatment of choice for congenital hydrocele and hernia.

questions.text: A patient having chronic liver disease is set to undergo a tooth extraction. During pre-op evaluation, his platelet count is found to be 60 x 10^9/ L. Which thrombopoietin receptor agonist can you prescribe to treat this?
questions.solution:
Avatrombopag is a thrombopoietin receptor agonist approved for the treatment of thrombocytopenia with chronic liver disease in patients who are scheduled to undergo a medical or dental procedure.

Thrombopoietin receptor agonist stimulates proliferation and differentiation of megakaryocytes from bone marrow progenitor cells resulting in increased production of platelets. Lusutrombopag is a drug with similar action and function.

Options A & B: Eltrombopag and romiplostim are thrombopoietin receptor agonists indicated in chronic immune thrombocytopenia.

Option C: Oprelvekin is a recombinant IL-11 that is used in the prophylaxis of thrombocytopenia during cancer chemotherapy.

questions.text: Chymotrypsinogen is a ________
questions.solution:
Chymotrypsinogen is a zymogen.

Some enzymes are secreted as an inactive form called as zymogens. The zymogens are converted to their active functional forms by partial, or selective proteolysis. Examples of zymogens include trypsinogen, chymotrypsinogen, proelastase, pepsinogen, prophospholipase A2 etc.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is present in the oropharynx?
questions.solution:
Lingual tonsils are lymphoid tissues seen in the base of the tongue, hence a part of the oropharynx. 

Oropharynx includes:

  • Base of tongue
  • Palatine tonsils
  • Vallecula
  • Anterior and posterior pillars
  • Posterior pharyngeal wall

The pharyngeal end of the pharyngotympanic tube and fossa of Rosenmuller is present in the lateral wall of the nasopharynx.

The pyriform fossa is a part of the hypopharynx.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is being evaluated for sudden onset of hypersecretory glaucoma, diarrhea, and cardiac failure. Further probing reveals that she had been purchasing groceries from a dealer who was recently arrested for food adulteration. What toxin is likely responsible for her presentation?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of epidemic dropsy. It is caused by the toxic compound sanguinarine, which is present in argemone oil. It is commonly used as an adulterant in mustard oil.

Epidemic dropsy results in sudden onset of swelling of lower limbs, diarrhea, and breathlessness. Some patients may develop hypersecretory glaucoma. It can lead to death due to cardiac failure.

Adulteration with argemone oil can be detected by the following tests:

  • Paper chromatography - most sensitive test
  • Nitric acid test

questions.text: Which of the following pathways act as a major energy source for cancer cells?
questions.solution:
Cancer cells derive energy mainly from glycolysis.

Cancer cells utilize large amounts of glucose and metabolize it to lactic acid, even in the presence of oxygen. This effect was termed the Warburg effect. 

The increased rate of glycolysis is due to certain defects in the mitochondrial electron transport chain. Besides, this enhanced glycolysis enables the cancer cells to proliferate in the reduced oxygen tension conditions, which is seen in tumors. This switch from aerobic to anaerobic glucose metabolism also acts as an impetus to tumorigenesis.

The increased glucose consumption is used as a carbon source for anabolic processes needed to support cell proliferation such as the de novo generation of nucleotides, lipids, and proteins. Also, the major isoenzyme of pyruvate kinase in cancer cells is PK-2 (in contrast to PK-1 in normal cells), which appears to play a role in the Warburg effect.

Note: This effect is the basis for detecting cancers by FDG-PET scanning.

questions.text: Insall-Salvati index is associated with which of the following bones?
questions.solution:
The Insall-Salvati index is used for the determination of patellar height.

It is the ratio of the patella tendon length (LT) to the length of the patella (LP). It can be measured from a lateral radiograph of the knee.

  • Ratio between 0.8 and 1.2 - normal
  • Ratio above 1.2 - high lying patella (patella alta)
  • Ratio below 0.8 - low lying patella (patella baja)

The high and low-lying patella are usually associated with anterior knee pain and recurrent dislocations of the patella.

The image below is the radiograph of the knee showing the calculation of Insall-Salvati index.

questions.text: What is the first marker to rise in a patient with acute hepatitis B?
questions.solution:
The first virologic marker to rise in acute hepatitis B is HBsAg i.e., Hepatitis B surface antigen. It is detectable in serum within 1–12 weeks of infection. Usually, HBsAg becomes undetectable 1–2 months after the onset of jaundice. If it persists beyond 6 months, it indicates chronic hepatitis B.

However, very rarely, patients may have an HBsAg negative status even during active infection due to infection with escape mutant HBV. These escape mutants have mutations within the S gene and they are known to be responsible for occult hepatitis B infections.

questions.text: A mother brings her 2-month-old infant with complaints of irritability and seizures. On examination, the infant has a bulging fontanelle and macrocephaly. CT was done, which shows the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The CT findings along with the clinical features are consistent with Dandy-Walker malformation. CT image shows a large cystic area that occupies the posterior aspect of the posterior fossa communicating directly with the fourth ventricle. No normal vermis can be identified with a small vermian remnant appearing displaced and rotated superiorly. An enlarged posterior fossa with an elevation of the lateral venous sinuses and the tentorium is also noted. 

Other options: 

Option B: Arnold Chiari malformation consists of herniation of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum. It is of two types:

  • Chiari I malformation is the most common type which is associated with peg-like cerebellar tonsils displaced into the upper cervical canal through the foramen magnum. It is also associated with syringomyelia.
  • Chiari II malformation is the displacement of the medulla, fourth ventricle, and cerebellar vermis through the foramen magnum. It is associated with lumbosacral spinal myelomeningocele. The image given below shows a Chiari malformation:

 

Option C:  The MR angiography in the vein of Galen malformation shows an enlarged midline venous structure, with multiple arteriovenous communications leading to aneurysmal dilatation. The image below shows the malformation:

 

Option D: Joubert syndrome is an autosomal recessive neurologic disorder. A pathognomonic finding on axial MRI of the brain is the presence of prominent superior cerebellar peduncles, referred to as 'molar tooth sign' of the midbrain-hindbrain junction. The image given below shows the molar tooth sign.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with itchy papules over the face, neck, and V area of the chest for the last 3 years which are exacerbated in summers and improved in winters. What test can be done to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given history points towards the diagnosis of photoallergic contact dermatitis. Photopatch test is used to diagnose this condition.

It is a delayed-type IV hypersensitivity reaction with a predilection for photo exposed sites with well‐demarcated margins where the skin is covered by clothing (at the collar and ‘V’ of the neck, on the backs of the hands, and on the ankles). It spares the skin behind the earlobe (Wilkinson’s triangle) since it is a photo-protected site.

Photopatch test: The standard patch test units are applied in two sets (on either side of the spine) and kept covered. One set of patches is removed and exposed to UVA. After irradiation, the other set of patches are also removed and both the sites are covered again for 48 hours. A positive reaction on the irradiated side only is an indication of photoallergy

The image below shows a photopatch test showing reaction after exposure to UVA only.

questions.text: What is the most common complication that is expected to occur in patients following splenectomy?

choices.text: Avascular necrosis of greater curvature of stomach

questions.solution:
Left lower lobe atelectasis is the most common complication after splenectomy.

Other complications of splenectomy include:

  • OPSI (Overwhelming post-splenectomy infection)is the most common fatal late complication of splenectomy.
  • Avascular necrosis of the greater curvature of the stomach is a rare complication that can occur after ligation of short gastric vessels.
  • Damage to the tail of the pancreas during surgery can lead to pancreatitis, a localized abscess, or pancreatic fistula.
  • Hemorrhage during the perioperative period etc.

questions.text: The contrast-enhanced CT abdomen of a 50-year-old woman shows the following finding. Which of the following classifications would you use to assess the severity of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given CT image shows a simple renal cyst. The Bosniak classification system is used for the classification of renal cystic masses based on characteristics seen on contrast-enhanced CT. It is helpful in predicting malignancy risk and formulating a management plan.

Bosniak class Appearance Malignancy Management
 1

Simple cyst : 

Rounded with imperceptible wall

 Not malignant No further workup required
2

Minimally complex: 

  • Size <1 mm with septa, thin calcifications

 

 Not malignant No further workup required
2F

Minimally complex:

  • Size >3 cm
  • Increased number of septa
  • Minimally thickened with nodular/thick calcifications
 5% chance  Ultrasound/CT follow-up every 6 months
3

Indeterminate:

  • Complicated cysts, thickened septa
  • Nodular calcification/solid non-enhancing areas (appears hyperdense on CT)
 55% chance

Partial nephrectomy

Radiofrequency ablation (elderly/poor surgical candidates)
4

Solid mass with a large cystic or necrotic component

Clearly malignant (100%)

 Partial/ total nephrectomy

 

Other options:

Option A: Jackson staging is used in carcinoma penis.

Option C: Durie-Salmon staging is used for multiple myeloma.

Option D: Todani classification is used in cases of choledochal cysts.

questions.text: A female patient comes with complaints of unintentional weight loss and right shoulder pain for the past 6 months. She reports that the pain radiates to her arm and is not relieved by NSAIDs. Chest X-ray is given below. Which nerve roots are likely to be compressed?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the X-ray findings is suggestive of Pancoast syndrome / superior sulcus tumor. This affects the C8, T1, and T2 nerve roots.

It presents with pain that radiates to the ulnar distribution of the arm, often with the destruction of the 1st and 2nd ribs. Patients with the central or endobronchial growth of the primary tumor may present with a cough, hemoptysis, wheeze, stridor, dyspnea, or post-obstructive pneumonitis.

Regional spread can cause

  • Tracheal obstruction
  • Esophageal compression with dysphagia
  • Recurrent laryngeal paralysis with hoarseness
  • Phrenic nerve palsy with the elevation of the hemidiaphragm and dyspnea
  • Sympathetic nerve paralysis with Horner’s syndrome (enophthalmos, ptosis, miosis, and anhydrosis)

questions.text: A 75-year-old man provisionally diagnosed with BPH underwent a TURP procedure. Histopathological exam of the resected tissue revealed a tumor involving less than 5% of the specimen. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
A tumor discovered incidentally on TURP present in <5% of resected tissue is staged as T1a. For older men, conservative treatment is done for stage T1a prostatic carcinoma.

Radical surgical treatment might be considered in younger (<70 years) men with the same stage of the disease.

Staging of prostate carcinoma:
Tx Primary tumor cannot be assessed
T0 No evidence of primary tumor
T1 Clinically inapparent tumor. Neither palpable nor visible on imaging
T1a Incidental histologic finding in 5% or less of tissue resected
T1b Incidental histologic findings in more than 5% of tissue resected
T1c Tumor identified by needle biopsy (for example, because of elevated PSA)
T2

Tumor confined within the prostate
T2a

Tumor involves one-half of one lobe or less
T2b

Tumor involves more than one-half of one lobe but not both lobes
T2c

Tumor involves both lobes
T3

Tumors extend through the prostate capsule
T3a Extracapsular extension (unilateral or bilateral)
T3b

Tumor invades seminal vesicle(s)
T4 Tumor is fixed or invades adjacent structures other than seminal vesicles, such as external sphincter, rectum, bladder, levator muscles, and/or pelvic wall
Management of Prostatic Carcinoma 
Stage of cancer Age > 70 or Gleason score=6 Age < 70 or Gleason score >6  
Early prostate cancer: T1B,T2A Active surveillance Radical prostatectomy    
Locally advanced prostate cancer: T2B, T2C, T3, T4, N1 Brachytherapy + Androgen deprivation therapy Brachytherapy + Radical prostatectomy   
Metastatic prostate cancer Androgen deprivation therapy Chemotherapy and radiotherapy (hormone-resistant  tumor)Radiopharmaceutical therapy (hormone resistant bony metastasis)

questions.text: In a patient, following venous cut down for access to the great saphenous vein, sensation over the medial side of the leg was lost. The affected nerve is a branch of which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
Loss of sensation of the medial side of the leg denotes injury to the saphenous nerve. It is a branch of the posterior division of the femoral nerve.

The saphenous nerve is the largest cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve.

It arises from the posterior division of the femoral nerve. In the femoral triangle, it lies lateral to the femoral artery. It then enters the adductor canal where it crosses anterior to the femoral artery to lie medial to it. It leaves the adductor canal by piercing the fascia lata between the gracilis and sartorius and supplies the skin over the patella.

It then descends along the medial border of the tibia along with the long saphenous vein and supplies the skin on the medial side of the knee leg and foot as far as up to the first metatarsophalangeal joint.

The images given below show the cutaneous innervation of the lower limb.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of subacute combined degeneration?
questions.solution:
Subacute combined degeneration (SACD) is due to the deficiency of vitamin B12. Pernicious anemia, partial gastrectomy, and Diphyllobothrium latum infestation can lead to this condition. High consumption of refined rice leads to thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency.

The most severely affected regions in SACD are the posterior columns at the cervical and upper thoracic levels.

Clinical features include: 

  • Signs of both peripheral nerve and spinal cord involvement
  • Paresthesias in the hands or feet > Weakness and unsteadiness of gait 
  • Loss of vibration or joint position sense in the legs
  • Mental slowing, depression, confusion, delusions, and hallucinations

SACD is treated by a replacement regimen of intramuscular daily injections of 1000 μg of vitamin B12 for the first week, followed by weekly 1000 μg injections for 1 month, and monthly injections thereafter.

Related Pearl: Neurological Manifestations in Deficiency Diseases

questions.text: A 53-year-old man who is a chronic smoker is diagnosed with lung carcinoma. Histopathology of the lung tissue is shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the histopathology showing the Azzopardi effect are suggestive of a small cell carcinoma of the lung.

Azzopardi effect is described as basophilic staining of vascular walls due to encrustation by DNA from necrotic tumor cells.

questions.text: If identified and intervened early, rapid clinical improvement can be expected in a patient with which of the following causes of dementia ?
questions.solution:
If diagnosed and intervened early, clinical improvement can be expected with normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH), as it is a reversible cause of dementia.

Normal pressure hydrocephalus can present with the following triad (Adam’s triad or Hakim's triad), remembered as:

  1. Urinary incontinence (wet)
  2. Dementia (wacky)
  3. Gait disturbance (wobbly)           

Causes of dementia:

Reversible Irreversible
  • Intracranial tumors
  • Subdural hematoma
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Autoimmune encephalopathy
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency
  • Meningitis 
  • Alzheimer's disease
  • Huntington's disease
  • Lewy body disease
  • Vascular dementia
  • Creutzfeld-Jacob disease
  • Pick's disease

Related Pearl: Differential diagnosis of dementia

Condition Features

  • Insidious onset
  • Short-term memory loss
  • Language deficits and spatial disorientation
  • Later, personality changes
Vascular Dementia
  • Stepwise decline
  • Early executive dysfunction
  • Cerebral infarction &/or deep white matter changes on neuroimaging

(Pick’s disease)

  • Apathy, disinhibition & compulsive behaviors
  • Frontotemporal atrophy on neuroimaging

questions.text: Phases of the ventricular muscle action potential are shown below. At which phase of the below image, the action potential is most dependant on sodium permeability?
questions.solution:
The action potential is most dependant on sodium permeability in phase 0. 

Action potential of myocardium:

  • Phase 0: Depolarisation: Influx of Na+ into myocyte.
  • Phase 1: Early repolarization: Efflux of K+ from myocyte.
  • Phase 2: Plateau: Ca2+ enters myocardial cells via voltage regulated L-type Ca2+ channels.
  • Phase 3: Repolarisation: Efflux of K+.
  • Phase 4: Restoration of RMP: Restoration of Na+ and K+ by Na-K ATPase.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the casualty following a head injury. He is unconscious and is not able to open his eyes. He also has no verbal or motor responses. What will be his GCS score?
questions.solution:
The GCS score in this patient will be 3. The lowest possible Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is 3 and never zero.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score

Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female nurse was on her way to the hospital for her early morning shift. Suddenly she started to notice pain in her fingers which were turning pale and numb after which they turned blue. Which of the following statements are false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Triggered by cold as well as stress
Calcium channel blockers are used for treatment
Mainstay of treatment includes avoidance of triggers
Is not associated with autoimmune diseases

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Raynaud's phenomenon. Secondary causes of Raynaud's phenomenon are seen in association with autoimmune diseases such as scleroderma, systemic lupus erythematosus etc.

Raynaud’s phenomenon is characterized by triphasic color response of the fingers or toes:

  • Digital blanching or pallor
  • Cyanosis
  • Rubor
Primary Raynaud's phenomenon (Raynaud's disease)

Secondary Raynaud's phenomenon
Idiopathic and more common

Secondary to other conditions (autoimmune diseases, vibration injury)
Women are more commonly affected  No gender predisposition
Age of presentation is between 20 to 40 years Present later in life 
Episodic  -
Affects both hands and feet Affects either both hands or both feet

questions.text: While performing bone grafting, which of the following instruments would you use to elevate the periosteum?
questions.solution:
The instrument used in the elevation of the periosteum is a periosteal elevator shown in image A.

It is used to elevate the periosteum, as nerves and vessels are generally on this plane, and once elevated there is a safer plane for surgery.

Option B: The image shows a curette used for curetting a cavity in the bone or removing fibrous tissue from the ends of a fracture. It is used in the management of enchondroma, GCT, and osteomyelitis.

Option C: The image shows an osteotome. It has both sides beveled and is used for cutting bone in surgeries such as McMurray's osteotomy and corrective osteotomy. 

Option D: It shows a bone gouge, a concave-bladed chisel used for cutting round bone surfaces or making holes in the bone.

Related Pearl: Orthopedic Instruments

questions.text: A 42-year-old  daily wage laborer comes to you with discoloration of her legs. She was diagnosed with varicose veins 5 years ago which was left untreated. Identify the feature given in the picture.
questions.solution:
Atrophia blanche is localised white atrophic skin frequently surrounded by dilated capillaries and hyperpigmentation, usually seen around the ankles. This is a sign of chronic venous disease.

Lipodermatosclerosis is changes in the skin of the lower legs due to chronic venous insufficiency. It is a form of panniculitis (inflammation of the layer of fat under the skin). There is swelling and a tapering of the legs above the ankles, leading to 'inverted champagne bottle' appearance.

 

Corona phlebectatica are fan-shaped patterns of small intradermal veins on the medial or lateral aspects of the ankle or foot. It is also called ankle flare or malleolar flare. It is an early sign of advanced venous disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is deficient in a patient with features as shown below:
questions.solution:
The image provided is characteristic of Casal's necklace, seen in pellagra, and indicates a deficiency of Tryptophan.

Pellagra can occur due to:

  • Vitamin B3 (niacin)
    • Niacin is derived from tryptophan and needs B2 and B6 for its synthesis.
  • Hartnup's disease (tryptophan malabsorption)
  • Malignant carcinoid syndrome (↑ tryptophan metabolism)
  • Isoniazid (↓ vitamin B6)

In Hartnup's disease, defective membrane transport of tryptophan across PCT and enterocytes leads to malabsorption of tryptophan. This causes a deficiency of tryptophan.

As a result, the production of niacin from tryptophan is reduced and this manifests as pellagra with dermatitis, diarrhea and dementia (3D's) and glossitis. A characteristic skin rash called the Casal’s necklace may also be seen.

questions.text: Which of the following cannot utilize ketone bodies?
questions.solution:
The liver cannot utilize ketone bodies.

The ketone bodies synthesized in the liver mitochondria are transported in the blood to the peripheral tissues, where they are utilized by the following steps:

  1. β-hydroxybutyrate is oxidized to acetoacetate by β-hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase producing NADH.
  2. Acetoacetate is then activated to acetoacetyl CoA by transferring a CoA molecule from succinyl CoA by succinyl CoA-acetoacetate CoA transferase (thiophorase).
  3. Acetoacetyl CoA is cleaved into two acetyl CoA molecules by thiolase and oxidized into CO2 by the TCA cycle.

RBCs cannot utilize ketone bodies as they lack mitochondria.

The liver cannot utilize ketone bodies as it lacks the enzyme thiophorase.

Related Pearl: Ketone body utilisation

1. 3-Hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase

2. CoA Transferase

3. Thiolase

questions.text: Which of the following is true about instrumental vaginal delivery?

choices.text: Full cervical dilatation is the only prerequisite
Forceps can be used for delivery of the after-coming head  of breech
Ventouse cannot be used in rotational occipitotransverse/ posterior delivery
Engaged head is not a prerequisite

questions.solution:
Forceps can be used for delivery of the aftercoming head of breech. The advantages are as follows:

  • Delivery can be controlled by giving pull directly on the head and the force is not transmitted through the neck.
  • Flexion is better maintained.
  • Mucus can be sucked out from the mouth more effectively.

Prerequisites for instrumental vaginal delivery:

  • Ruptured membranes vertex presentation
  • Cephalopelvic disproportion not suspected
  • No fetal coagulopathy or bone demineralization disorder
  • Completely dilated cervix
  • Precisely assessed fetal head position
  • Engaged head
  • Experienced operator

Note: Ventouse can be used for occipitotranverse or posterior position.

questions.text: A person who had dinner at 8 pm the previous night, tested his blood glucose levels at 7 am the next morning. What is the source of blood glucose in this case?
questions.solution:
The source of blood glucose in a person fasting overnight for 11 hours (8 pm to 7 am) is hepatic glycogenolysis.

First stage of fasting: The fasting state begins two to four hours after the absorptive/well-fed state. In early fasting i.e; 4-18 hours after the well-fed state, the blood glucose level is maintained by hepatic glycogenolysis. The glycogen stores are sufficient for around 18 hours after a meal following which they start to deplete. So the source of blood glucose in a person fasting for 11 hours will be liver glycogenolysis.

Second stage of fasting: Gluconeogenesis begins 4–6 hours after the last meal but becomes fully active only after stores of liver glycogen are depleted (after 18 hours). They can serve as a source of glucose for up to 2 days.

Substrates for gluconeogenesis are:

  • Glucogenic amino acids ( mainly alanine) from the muscle and
  • Glycerol from adipose tissue 

During fasting, the glucogenic amino acids are transported to the liver, transaminated into pyruvate, and converted to glucose.

Third stage of fasting:

  • Lipolysis occurs in the adipose tissue due to the activity of hormone-sensitive lipase, stimulated by increased glucagon:insulin ratio.
  • Free fatty acids are the source of energy in this stage and not glucose. Triacylglycerols will be hydrolyzed to fatty acids and glycerol. 
  • Beta oxidation of fatty acids takes place which provides acetyl CoA. 
  • In prolonged starvation (>3 days), acetyl CoA is converted to ketone bodies in the liver which will act as the main fuel source for skeletal and heart muscle and can meet up to 20% of the brain’s energy needs.

Final stage of fasting: After several weeks of starvation, ketone body synthesis will not take place due to depleted triacylglycerol stores. Proteins remain the only source of fuel. Protein degradation increases, and death results from a loss of heart, liver, or kidney function.

Role of insulin and glucagon:

When blood glucose falls during fasting, there is increased secretion of glucagon and decreased release of insulin. Hence glucagon:insulin ratio is increased.

Effects of increased glucagon:insulin ratio on enzymes of glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis:

  1. It activates glycogen phosphorylase, the key enzyme of glycogenolysis, and deactivates glycogen synthase. This causes a rapid mobilization of liver glycogen stores to be utilized as fuel.
  2. It favors the synthesis of glucose-6-phosphatase which converts glucose-6-phosphate to glucose. The resulting glucose is used by red blood cells (lack mitochondria) and the brain as they are largely dependant on glucose in the fasting state.
  3. Phosphoenol pyruvate carboxykinase and fructose-1, 6-bisphosphatase are induced, leading to increased gluconeogenesis.
Metabolic process         Fasting state      Fed state
Glucagon: insulin   Increased              Decreased
Gluconeogenesis    Increased                Decreased            
Glycogenolysis  Increased                Decreased
Ketogenesis  Increased                Decreased
Glycogen storage  Decreased  Increased             

Other options:

Option C: Muscle glycogen cannot contribute directly to plasma glucose, since muscle lacks glucose-6-phosphatase. So glycogen cannot be converted to glucose to be used as fuel during starvation. 

Option D: In the well-fed state/ absorptive state of two to four hours after a meal, dietary glucose is the main source of fuel.

The below image shows steps of glycolysis and gluconeogenesis.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man came to the urology OPD with complaints of a slow-growing ulcerative lesion in the penis for the past few months. On examination, a fungating mass in his glans penis was seen and lymph nodes were not palpable. He was suspected to have penile carcinoma. Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of the patient?

choices.text: MRI is the investigation of choice for staging
1cm margin of normal tissue must be removed
Sentinel lymph node biopsy should be done
If stump is < 3cm, total amputation of the penis is done

questions.solution:
In penile carcinoma, total amputation of the penis is done if the stump is < 2cm.

The investigation of choice for penile carcinoma is a biopsy from the primary tumor. For staging, MRI is the investigation of choice.

The first lymph node to be involved is the superficial inguinal lymph node and thus, the sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) is helpful for evaluating the spread of penile cancer.

The management is divided into treatment of the primary tumour and the treatment of the lymph nodes. 

The main principles of penile cancer surgery are to remove a 1cm margin of normal tissue and have at least a 2cm stump after surgery.

Surgery is the mainstay treatment of penile cancer. Chemotherapy regime includes 5-fluorouracil and cisplatin. Radiotherapy can be done for inguinal lymph nodes if lymph node dissection is not done.

questions.text: Among the following, what is the function of the marked muscles?
questions.solution:
The muscle marked in the above image is the lateral pterygoid muscle and its primary function is depression of the mandible (opening of the mouth). 

Bilateral contraction of the lateral pterygoid alone causes depression of the mandible (making it the primary function) whereas, protrusion is the result of bilateral contraction of both the medial and lateral pterygoid muscles. 

The lateral pterygoid has the following actions:

  1. Opening of the jaw (depression): Lateral pterygoid has a specialized role in mandibular opening mediated by its horizontal fibres. When left and right lateral pterygoid muscles contract together, the mandibular condyle is pulled forwards and slightly downwards. This protrusive movement alone has little or no function except in assisting the opening of the jaw (Gray's Anatomy 41st edition).
  2. Side-to-side movement: When the lateral pterygoid contracts unilaterally along with the adjacent medial pterygoid the jaw is pulled medially. This is used for grinding food between teeth of the same side. This action is mediated by the inferior head of the lateral pterygoid.

questions.text: You are suspecting organophosphorus poisoning in a farmer who presented with chronic fatigue and urinary incontinence. What would be the most accurate investigation to assess potential toxicity?

choices.text: Urinary levels of organophosphorus compound metabolites

questions.solution:
RBC cholinesterase enzyme activity is the most accurate indicator to assess potential organophosphorus (OP) toxicity. It is an indicator of synaptic cholinesterase inhibition.

However, plasma butyrylcholinesterase is easier to assay and more easily available. Hence, it is more commonly used.

Measurement of parent compound in blood and metabolites urine are rarely carried out in a clinical setting.

Note: The correlation between cholinesterase activity, clinical symptoms, and atropine dose is inconsistent. Hence, treatment should be guided predominately by clinical symptoms.

questions.text: What is known as the time period in which a second stronger impulse can elicit action potential after the application of one stimulus?
questions.solution:
The refractory period is the time period in which a second stronger impulse can elicit action potential after the application of one stimulus. It can be absolute or relative. 

During the rising and much of the falling phases of the spike potential, the neuron is refractory to stimulation. This refractory period is divided into an

  • Absolute refractory period, corresponding to the period from the time the firing level is reached until repolarization is about one-third complete
  • Relative refractory period, lasting from this point to the start of after-depolarization

During the absolute refractory period, no stimulus, no matter how strong, will not excite the nerve. However, during the relative refractory period, stimuli that are stronger than normal can cause excitation.

The absolute refractory period for large myelinated nerve fibers is about 1/2500 second.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with a history of myoclonic jerks, seizures, and rapid decline in cognitive function. The mother gives a history of fever with a rash at 1.5 years of age. The rash had started behind the ears, progressed to involve the whole body, and resolved on its own. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario with a classic history of exanthematous fever suggestive of measles, seizures, myoclonic jerks, and cognitive dysfunction is suggestive of subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE).

SSPE is a chronic, progressive demyelinating disease that develops years after measles infection, most often in patients between 5-15 years of age. Patients have a history of measles infection at <2 years of age. CSF shows elevated measles antibody levels and MRI shows increased T2 intensity in white matter. No definitive treatment is available. 

Other complications of measles:

  • Meningoencephalitis
  • Giant-cell pneumonitis
  • Pneumonia
  • Croup
  • Secondary infections - otitis media
  • Protracted diarrhea

questions.text: When will you use the SOFA score in a patient with acute pancreatitis?

choices.text: To assess the need for surgery
In cases of pancreatic abscess formation
To assess the length of hospital stay

questions.solution:
The Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) score is used to assess organ failure in acute pancreatitis. The three organ systems most frequently involved are the cardiovascular, respiratory, and renal systems. Multiple organ failures are said to exist when 2 or more organs register 2 or more points on these scoring systems.

qSOFA score (quickSOFA) is a bedside prompt that may identify patients with suspected infection who are at greater risk for a poor outcome outside the intensive care unit (ICU). It uses three criteria, assigning one point each for

  • Low blood pressure (SBP≤100 mmHg)
  • High respiratory rate (≥22 breaths per min)
  • Altered mentation (Glasgow coma scale, <15)

The score ranges from 0 to 3 points. The presence of 2 or more qSOFA points is a simple prompt to identify infected patients outside the ICU who are likely to develop sepsis.

Related Pearl: SOFA and qSOFA Scores

Sepsis is defined as a state of life-threatening organ dysfunction that occurs due to an unregulated host immune response to an infection. To objectively define the beginning of organ dysfunction, sequential organ failure assessment (SOFA) scoring is used. The variables in the SOFA score include:

  • Circulation - Systolic BP & need for vasopressors and platelet count
  • Respiration - PaO2/FiO2 & need for mechanical ventilation
  • Mentation - Glasgow coma score (GCS)
  • Hepatic function - Bilirubin
  • Renal function - Creatinine

MAP = mean arterial pressure. Epi = epinephrine. Nonrepi = norepinephrine. ¤ = Adrenergic agents administered for at least 1 h (doses in μg/kg per min).

 

Organ dysfunction is identified by a SOFA score of ≥ 2

A simplified version, recommended by the 'Sepsis 3' taskforce, is known as the quick sepsis-related organ dysfunction assessment "qSOFA" score. It includes:

  • Systolic BP ≤100 mmHg
  • Respiratory rate ≥ 22/min
  • Altered mentation/sensorium

Each criterion carries 1 point. A qSOFA score of ≥ 2 is associated with increased mortality due to sepsis.

SOFA vs qSOFA:

  • SOFA is a more comprehensive and accurate scoring system that is particularly superior to qSOFA in the ICU setting.
  • qSOFA is a simplified derivative of SOFA for bedside assessment that is particularly useful outside the ICU setting (i.e. ward/emergency department).

Thereby, the best description of sepsis would be :

  • Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ≥ 2
    OR
  • Suspected or documented infection with qSOFA score ≥ 2

However, note that these scores were originally designed as a predictive tool that calculates the risk of death from sepsis rather than a diagnostic tool.

questions.text: An unmarried mother purposefully drowned and caused the death of her newborn infant in the bathtub. She will be punished under which of the following?
questions.solution:
The woman will be punished under BNS Section 103 (IPC 302), which deals with the punishment for murder. This offence is punishable with death or imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to a fine.

Other relevant sections include:

  • BNS Section 93 (IPC 317) - Abandoning a child of <12 years
  • BNS Section 94 (IPC 318) - Concealment of birth

Option A: BNS Section 40 (IPC 102) deals with the commencement and continuance of the private defence of the body.

Option C: BNS Section 91 (IPC 315) deals with acts done before birth with the intent to prevent a child from being born alive or to cause to die after birth.

Option D: BNS Section 108 (IPC 306) deals with punishment for abetment to suicide.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presents with burning pain and numbness in his hands, heat intolerance and decreased visual acuity. Further evaluation reveals skin angiokeratomas and a decreased renal function. Which of the following is the mode of inheritance of the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Burning pain and numbness in hands, heat intolerance, decreased visual acuity with skin angiokeratomas and a decreased renal function is suggestive of Fabry’s disease which is inherited as an X-linked recessive disorder.

Fabry’s disease is a lipid storage disorder due to a deficiency of α-galactosidase A, resulting in the accumulation of globotriaosyl-ceramide in tissues. Young boys present with Fabry crises (burning pain in the hands, feet and proximal extremities), angiokeratomas (reddish blue telangiectatic skin lesions between the umbilicus and knees), corneal and lenticular opacities, renal failure and cardiomyopathy.

Note: All sphingolipidoses are inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, except Fabry’s disease.

Most of the common metabolic disorders are autosomal recessive disorders, except:

1. Autosomal dominant disorders:

  • Familial hypercholesterolemia

2. X-linked recessive disorders:

  • Hunter syndrome
  • Fabry disease
  • Lesch-Nyhan syndrome
  • OTC deficiency

questions.text: A young man presents to the emergency with a painful scrotum. On examination, the patient is febrile and a Prehn’s sign is positive. What is the most likely cause of the patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of acute epididymitis. 

A positive Prehn’s sign is used to differentiate epididymis from testicular torsion. A Prehn’s sign is said to be positive when the pain gets relieved on lifting the testis. If it persists, it is likely to be testicular torsion.

Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common cause of acute epididymitis in young, sexually active males. In older men(>40yrs) with bladder outflow obstruction, epididymitis results from urinary infection, most commonly due to Escherichia coli.

Acute epididymitis is managed by antibiotics and scrotal support.

questions.text: A primigravida at 12 weeks of gestation presented with complaints of the expulsion of grape-like vesicles PV for the past day. A diagnosis of molar pregnancy was made on USG examination. Incidentally, the following adnexal lesion was also noted. What is the lesion?
questions.solution:
The given USG image shows theca lutein cysts in the ovary. These cysts are usually seen in patients with complete molar pregnancies. They are usually bilateral and are also seen in multiple pregnancies.

Theca lutein cysts result from the overstimulation of lutein elements by massive amounts of β hCG. The cystic fluid is rich in chorionic gonadotropin, estrogen, and progesterone.

questions.text: A teenage patient presented with a history of dysmenorrhea and chronic pelvic pain. On ultrasonography, a transverse vaginal septum was seen. What is the most common complication that can be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The most common complication that can be seen in this patient is endometriosis.

Transverse vaginal septum leads to obstructed flow of menstrual blood. This may lead to retrograde menstruation, which increases the likelihood of the development of endometriosis, according to Sampson's theory of endometriosis.

Transverse vaginal septum occurs as a result of the failure of Müllerian duct fusion or failure of vaginal plate canalization. It may be obstructive or non-obstructive. The commonest site of a transverse septum is the junction between the upper and middle third of the vagina.

Patients with an obstructive or imperforate vaginal septum present with symptoms similar to the imperforate hymen. Symptoms include amenorrhoea, cyclical abdominal pain, urinary symptoms, and a palpable pelvic mass. The vagina may appear shortened and the cervix may not be identifiable. Secondary sexual characteristics appear normal. The diagnosis can be confirmed with ultrasound or MRI.

There is an increased risk of endometriosis. Other complications such as pyomucocolpos, pyometra, and pyosalpinges can also develop in infants with obstructive vaginal septums. 

Treatment is by manual dilatation of the perforation or surgical excision of the septum. 

Other options:

Option B: Tubo-ovarian abscess develops in pelvic inflammatory disease.

Option C: Dermoid cysts are cystic ovarian tumors that are often associated with mucinous cystadenomas.

Option D: Theca lutein cysts are found in association with hydatidiform moles, choriocarcinoma, and gonadotropin or clomiphene citrate therapy. They regress with the management of the mole and choriocarcinoma and discontinuation of gonadotropin therapy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old professional mountain climber presents with the following lesions over his leg. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows serpiginous or serpent-like skin lesions, which are characteristically seen in cutaneous larva migrans or ground itch.

It is caused by the larvae of various hookworm or Ancylostoma species. The parasite is acquired from direct skin contact with soil contaminated by dog or cat feces. It is common following travel to endemic or tropical areas and symptoms develop within the first 2 weeks. 

The site of entry is marked by an inflamed papule, often located between the toes. Serpentine or linear single-track lines later appear as the larvae migrate through the epidermis. The lesions can enlarge as much as 1 to 2 cm per day.

The first-line treatment is oral ivermectin at 200 μg/kg. Oral albendazole is an alternative treatment.

Note: Larva currens is caused by the migrating larva of Strongyloides stercoralis. It also produces serpiginous lesions and can be differentiated by the faster rate of progression and haphazard distribution of lesions.

The image below shows serpiginous larval tracks over the skin.

questions.solution:

questions.text: A 45-year-old man was brought to the casualty with a history of severe chest pain radiating to the back and difficulty in breathing following several episodes of vomiting. PR- 110bpm and  BP- 80/50 mm of Hg. On examination, there is palpable crepitus over the chest wall. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Most common in lower third of esophagus
Iohexol is used as contrast agent
Cervical esophagostomy and gastrostomy is done in early presentation
Most common cause of mortality is mediastinitis

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario points to Boerhaave's syndrome. Primary closure is done in stable patients presenting within 24 hrs and not cervical esophagostomy with gastrostomy.

Boerhaave syndrome is the spontaneous perforation of the esophagus caused due to episodes of vomiting. During vomiting, the pressure in the esophagus rises rapidly and the esophagus ruptures at the weakest point. They usually have a history of heavy meal intake and alcohol abuse.

Clinical features include Mackler's triad:

  • Retching
  • Chest pain 
  • Subcutaneous emphysema 

The diagnosis is made by contrast esophagogram(iohexol) in unstable patients or contrast-enhanced CT scan, in stable patients.

Treatment includes primary closure within 12 hours of the injury for a better prognosis. If the patient is unstable or presents late, the perforated part is resected and cervical esophagostomy is performed. A T-tube is placed into the esophagus along with appropriately located drains and a feeding jejunostomy or gastrostomy is performed for nutrition.

Most common cause of mortality in Boerhaave syndrome is mediastinitis (40% to 50%).

questions.text: A woman whose obstetric score is G2 P1 L1 had an LMP of Jan 9th 2017. Calculate the EDD according to Naegele’s rule.
questions.solution:
As per Naegele’s rule, the EDD (expected date of delivery) of this woman is October 16, 2017.

Naegele’s rule states that EDD is obtained by adding 7 days and subtracting 3 months from the LMP (the 1st day of the last menstrual period). Another method is adding 9 months and 7 days to LMP. Less than 5% of births follow Naegele's rule. 

It is based on a 28-day regular cycle. If the cycle is shorter/longer than 28 days, corrected EDD is calculated as follows:

  • For a 35-day cycle, add another 7 (35-28=7) days to the calculated EDD to get the corrected EDD.
  • For a 25-day cycle, subtract 3 (28-25=3) days from the calculated EDD to get the corrected EDD.

Naegele’s rule cannot be followed in IVF pregnancies. Considering the human embryo takes 266 days to develop, EDD is calculated in IVF pregnancies by the following method:

  • Same day as fertilization (day 0): EDD = date of transfer + 266 days 
  • 3 days after fertilization (day 3): EDD = date of transfer + 263 days
  • 5 days after fertilization (day 5): EDD = date of transfer + 261 days

questions.text: A young woman presented with the following lesion on her vulva. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of condyloma acuminata that shows cauliflower-like masses of tissue on and around the female anogenital region. 

Condyloma acuminatum is an epidermal manifestation of the human papillomavirus (HPV). 

HPV is transmitted through contact with infected skin or mucosa. The virus invades the cells of the epidermal basal layer through microabrasions. However, anogenital HPV infection is almost always acquired through sexual contact. 

Warts are not required for transmission but are highly infectious because of their high viral load.

Option B: The image given below shows shiny, pearly white, umbilicated papules with a characteristic dimple at the centre. These are seen in molluscum contagiosum caused by the pox virus.

Option C: The image given below shows firm papules with a rough horny surface. These are seen in verruca vulgaris caused by the human papillomavirus type 2.

Option D: The image given below shows condyloma lata which is the characteristic feature of secondary syphilis. It is caused by Treponema pallidum.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the procedure shown in the image?

choices.text: The concept of the procedure was introduced by Goldmann.
It is used to treat after cataract
It is based on the Imbert-Fick law
It is used to investigate glaucoma

questions.solution:
The instrument shown is an applanation tonometer, which is used to measure intraocular pressure (IOP). 

The concept behind the procedure was introduced by Goldmann. It is based on Imbert-Fick law, which states that the pressure inside a sphere(P) is equal to the force (W) required to flatten its surface divided by the area of flattening (A).

P = W/A

The different types are Goldmann tonometer, Perkin’s tonometer, pneumatic tonometer, pulse air tonometer, tono-pen.

questions.text: In patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome, which of the following cells are the major cause of tissue injury?
questions.solution:
In acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), acute tissue injury is caused mainly by neutrophils.

ARDS is a clinical syndrome manifested as a result of severe lung injury. The initiating event is alveolar epithelial cell damage. It is characterized by acute inflammation, causing increased pulmonary vascular permeability and edema. 

Neutrophils adhere to the activated endothelium and migrate into the interstitium and the alveoli. Here, they degranulate and release inflammatory mediators. These include:

  • Proteases
  • Reactive oxygen species
  • Cytokines

Macrophages are involved in the stage of resolution.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about herd immunity?

choices.text: It refers to group protection beyond what is afforded by the protection of immunized individuals
Vaccination allows the possibility of 100% herd immunity against a disease
It is affected by presence and distribution of alternative animal hosts
It doesn’t protect the individual in the case of tetanus

questions.solution:
It is not possible to achieve 100% herd immunity against a certain disease but studies have shown this is not necessary for disease control.

Herd structure is never constant. It is subject to constant variation because of new births, deaths and population mobility. An ongoing immunization programme will keep up the herd immunity at a very high level.

Related Pearl: Herd Immunity

  • Herd immunity is the level of protection of a community against a particular disease brought about by vaccination or immunization.
  • It refers to group protection beyond what is afforded by the protection of immunized individuals.
  • It is difficult to maintain the chain of infection if a large portion of the population is immune to a certain disease.
  • Elements which contribute to herd immunity are:
    • Occurrence of clinical and sub-clinical infection in the herd
    • Immunization of the herd
    • Herd structure
  • The herd structure not only includes the primary species but also the presence and distribution of alternative animal hosts, vectors and other environmental/social factors that are related to disease spread.
  • It is not possible or necessary to achieve 100% herd immunity in a population.
  • The proportion of immune individuals above which a disease may no longer spread is called herd immunity threshold.
  • This threshold depends upon the virulence of the disease, efficacy of the vaccine and contact parameter for the population.
  • Herd immunity is determined by serological surveys.
  • Herd immunity doesn’t offer protection against diseases like tetanus.

questions.text: AIDS-defining malignancies include all except :
questions.solution:
Melanoma is not an AIDS-defining malignancy.

AIDS-defining malignancies are those cancers that a human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infected person is at a high risk of developing. When a HIV-infected person develops one of the AIDS-defining malignancies it suggests that he has AIDS.

AIDS-defining malignancies include the following:

  • Kaposi sarcoma - It is a multicentric neoplasm of vascular origin and has a strong association with HHV - 8.
  • Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma
  • Invasive cervical cancer

Given below is the image of kaposi sarcoma:

Note : The FDA has approved pomalidomide, a thalidomide analogue to be included in treating adult patients with AIDS-related Kaposi's sarcoma after failure of highly active antiretroviral therapy and Kaposi's sarcoma in adult patients who are HIV-negative.

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasm

Infections:

  • Protozoal and helminthic infections-
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal infections-
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial infections-
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral infections-
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms:

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix 

Related Pearl: Opportunistic Infections/HIV related conditions and ART initiation

Clinical scenario Action 
Any undiagnosed active infection with fever Diagnose and treat first; start Anti-Retroviral Therapy (ART) when stable
Tuberculosis (TB) Start TB treatment first; start ART as soon as possible after 2 weeks and before 2 months. For those with CD4 less than 50/cmm, start ART within 2 weeks Caution is needed for PLHIV with TB meningitis, since immediate ART is associated with more severe adverse events than initiating ART 2 months after the start of TB treatment

Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP)

 Treat PCP first; start ART when PCP treatment is completed
Invasive fungal diseases: Oesophageal candidiasis, penicilliosis, histoplasmosis Start treatment for oesophageal candidiasis first; start ART as soon as the patient can swallow comfortably. Treat penicilliosis, and histoplasmosis first; start ART when the patient is stabilized or opportunistic infection treatment is completed.
Cryptococcal meningitis Treat cryptococcal meningitis. ART initiation should be deferred until there is evidence of sustained clinical response to anti-fungal therapy and after 4 weeks of induction and consolidation treatment with amphotericin B containing regimen.
Bacterial pneumonia Treat pneumonia first; start ART when treatment is completed
Malaria Treat malaria first; start ART when treatment is completed
Acute diarrhoea which may reduce absorption of ART Diagnose the cause and treat diarrhoea first; start ART when diarrhoea is stabilized or controlled
Non-severe anaemia (Hb< 9 g/dl) Start ART if no other causes for anaemia are found (HIV is often the cause of anaemia) 
Skin conditions such as PPE and seborrhoeic dermatitis, psoriasis, HIV-related exfoliative dermatitis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems) 
Suspected Mycobacterium Avium Complex (MAC), Cryptosporidiosis and Microsporidiosis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems)
Cytomegalovirus retinitis Start treatment for CMV urgently and start ART after 2 weeks of CMV treatment 
Toxoplasmosis Treat toxoplasmosis; start ART after 6 weeks of treatment and when the patient is stabilized

questions.text: An elderly man was diagnosed with hypertension 2 years ago and has been on losartan. During a routine health checkup, his HbA1c was found to be 7.3%. Which of the following is a better alternative to losartan for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has hypertension and diabetes mellitus (HbA1c >6.5% is diagnostic for diabetes). Telmisartan would be a better alternative to losartan in patients with both hypertension and diabetes, due to its additional PPAR gamma agonist action.

PPAR gamma agonists act by inducing several insulins sensitizing genes and thereby reducing the overall insulin resistance. 

While other angiotensin receptor blockers have been found to have PPAR gamma action, telmisartan has the highest and has been extensively studied in diabetes.

questions.text: The given life cycle belongs to which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
The given life cycle belongs to Leishmania donovani.

The definitive hosts are man, dog, and other mammals and the vector/intermediate host is female sandfly. Promastigotes are infective forms to man.

L. donovani exists in 2 forms:

  • Amastigote form- in humans and other mammals
  • Promastigote form- in the sandfly and artificial culture

When the infected sandfly bites a person, infectious promastigotes are released into the host dermis along with the sandfly saliva, which potentiates parasite infectivity.

Amastigote form (as shown in the image below) is also known as Leishman-Donovan (LD) body. It is an intracellular form found inside macrophages, monocytes and reticuloendothelial cells. It contains a kinetoplast which consists of a parabasal body and a blepharoplast. Flagellum is absent.

Promastigote form (as shown in the below image) is present in the midgut of the female sandfly. The kinetoplast lies transversely near the anterior end. A single flagellum is seen. It is the infective form of Leishmania donovani for humans.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presented with dwarfism and skeletal abnormalities. Upon examination, the abdomen was distended with no hepatosplenomegaly. The child was assessed and was found to be of normal intelligence. Which of the following mucopolysaccharidoses could be a likely cause?
questions.solution:
The key features in the above scenario are the absence of hepatosplenomegaly and the preservation of intelligence. Both of these features make the diagnosis of Morquio’s disease most likely. All the other conditions above are associated with hepatosplenomegaly.

Morquio disease (MPS-IV) is caused by a deficiency of N-acetylgalactosamine-6-sulfatase (MPS-IVA) or of β-galactosidase (MPS IVB). Both lead to defective degradation of keratan sulfate. 

Early symptoms:

  • Genu valgus
  • Kyphosis
  • Growth retardation with short trunk and neck
  • Waddling gait
  • Preservation of intelligence
  • Instability of the odontoid process and ligamentous laxity is regularly present and can result in life-threatening atlantoaxial instability and dislocation.

It is of two types:

 Type

 Enzyme involved

Chromosome 

 Morquio syndrome A

  Galactosamine 6-sulfatase Chromosome 16

 Morquio syndrome B

 β-Galactosidase

Chromosome  4

 Note:

  • MPS with no mental retardation: Scheie’s disease, Morquio syndrome, and Maroteaux–Lamy syndrome.
  • MPS with no visceromegaly: Morquio’s disease

questions.text: What type of tympanogram would you expect to see in a patient with serous otitis media?
questions.solution:
B-type tympanogram is expected in a case of serous otitis media.

Here, compliance decreases i.e., mobility of tympanic membrane is restricted due to the effusion, usually secondary to negative middle ear pressure (eustachian tube obstruction). This results in a B-type tympanogram. 

Hearing tests suggestive of conductive hearing loss as seen in serous otitis media:

  • Rinne negative (BC>AC).
  • Weber - lateralized towards the worse ear
  • Audiogram - AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
  • Impedance audiometry - flat curve (reduced compliance, shift to the negative side)

Note: Tympanograph is Flat when there is Fluid in the middle ear.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: What is the upper limit of serum lithium above which a patient is said to have lithium toxicity?
questions.solution:
Lithium toxicity is considered when the blood concentration reaches 1.5 mEq/L (or more). 

Blood concentration of lithium in the treatment of mood disorders:

  • For treatment: 0.8 - 1.2 mEq/L
  • For prophylaxis: 0.5 - 0.8 mEq/L
  • Toxic levels: >/= 1.5 mEq/L

Manifestations of lithium toxicity:

  • Acute: Coarse tremors (most common), delirium, dementia, seizures, and increase in deep tendon reflexes
  • Chronic: Nephrotoxicity (lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus), hypothyroidism

The most effective means of treating lithium toxicity is dialysis. It is necessary for severe poisoning cases, where:

  • The patient is exhibiting symptoms of toxicity, or
  • Lithium concentration is 4 mEq/L or more. 

Related Pearl: Lithium in bipolar disorder

Guidelines for Lithium therapy
Indications:
Mania, hypomania, bipolar disorder, etc.

Blood levels of lithium:

For therapeutic purpose (treatment of acute mania) : 0.8-1.2 mEq/L

For prophylaxis (to prevent relapse of bipolar disorder): 0.5-0.8 mEq/L

Toxic levels of lithium: >/= 1.5 mEq/L
Contraindications:
  • CKD
  • Heart disease
  • Hyponatremia or diuretic use
Baseline studies:
  • BUN (Blood Urea Nitrogen), Creatinine, Calcium, Urine analysis
  • Thyroid function test
  • ECG in patients with coronary risk factors
Acute adverse effects:
  • Tremor, ataxia, weakness
  • Polyuria, polydipsia
  • Vomiting, diarrhea
  • Cognitive impairment
Chronic adverse effects:
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
  • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Hyperparathyroidism

questions.text: A woman had gone on a trip to West African countries. She ate some fruit while trying out the local cuisine. After some time she developed severe nausea and vomiting. She was taken to a nearby clinic and on examination her blood sugar levels were low. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with hypoglycemia as the predominant feature is most likely Jamaican vomiting sickness.

Ackee fruit grows on the Blighia sapida tree, and it is a common ingredient in West African and Jamaican cuisine. Unripe ackee fruit contains heat-stable toxins hypoglycin A and B. The resulting clinical syndrome, which is characterized by severe vomiting and hypoglycemia, is Jamaican vomiting sickness.

Option A: Hippus is an abnormal exaggeration of the rhythmic contraction and dilatation of the pupil seen in aconite poisoning.

Option C: Ophitoxemia is snake envenomation.

Option D: St. Anthony's fire is the burning pain seen in gangrene caused by ergot poisoning.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to your clinic for routine immunization. According to the National Immunisation Schedule, which of the following  would you administer?
questions.solution:
At 5 years of age, the 2nd booster dose of DPT must be given along with the 9th (final) dose of vitamin A.

1st booster dose of DPT is given at 16 – 24 months of age.

1st dose of vitamin A is given at 9th month and the 2nd dose is given at 16 months followed by one dose every 6 months thereafter until the age of 5.

Note: DPT booster + Vitamin A is a better answer than DPT booster + OPV because the 9th (final) dose of vitamin A must be given at 5 years but OPV at 5 years is an optional vaccine.

questions.text: A patient describes the image below on the Amsler grid test. In which of the given conditions is this phenomenon noted?
questions.solution:
The image shows metamorphopsia seen in posterior uveitis.

Metamorphopsia is a condition in which patients perceive distorted images of the object. It is measured using the Amsler grid, which tests the central 10 degrees of vision. In posterior uveitis, metamorphopsia occurs due to macular edema.

Posterior uveitis is a painless inflammation of the choroid. Patients present with various visual symptoms like defective vision, black spots floating in front of the eye, micropsia/macropsia and positive scotomas.

questions.text: A worried mother brings her 2-year-old child with the complaints that he hasn't begun walking or talking. On examination, there is microcephaly, fair hair, light-colored skin, and blue eyes. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical manifestations point to the diagnosis of Phenylketonuria (PKU).

Characteristic clinical findings in Phenylketonuria:

  • Mental retardation
  • Failure to walk or talk
  • Seizures
  • Hyperactivity
  • Tremor
  • Microcephaly
  • Failure to grow
  • Deficiency of pigmentation (fair hair, light skin color, and blue eyes)

Oculocutaneous albinism (OCA) is a group of inherited disorders characterized by a reduction or complete lack of melanin pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes.

Its symptoms are albinism with vision problems, which include:

  • Strabismus
  • Photophobia
  • Nystagmus
  • Impaired vision or blindness
  • Astigmatism

Neuropsychiatric manifestations are not seen.

Related Pearl: Phenylketonuria

  1. BH4 - tetrahydrobiopterin (or sapropterin, a synthetic form of BH4)

questions.text: A 6-year-old child abruptly develops fever, oliguria, periorbital edema and smoky cola-colored urine 2-weeks after recovery from sore throat. His renal biopsy image is given below. Which of the following statements is false about the given condition?

choices.text: A rapidly progressive form with oliguria develops in 50% of children
It is a form of proliferative glomerulonephritis
Granular IgG and C3 deposits are seen on immunofluorescence
Dome-shaped subepithelial humps are seen on electron microscopy

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histopathology image showing hypercellular glomeruli are suggestive of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). Rapidly progressive disease with oliguria is very rare (< 1% of patients). 

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is a type of diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis. It is usually preceded by an acute streptococcal sore throat or impetigo around 1-4 weeks prior.

It usually presents with features of nephritic syndrome including:

  • Hematuria
  • Red cell casts in the urine
  • Azotemia, oliguria
  • Hypertension
  • Mild to moderate proteinuria
  • Edema

On microscopy, the following findings are seen:

  • Light microscopy - enlarged, hypercellular glomeruli with influx of leucocytes (endocapillary proliferation)
  • Electron microscopy - subepithelial humps 
  • Immunofluorescence - granular IgG and C3 deposits on glomerular basement membrane and mesangium

Majority (> 95%) of affected children eventually recover renal function with conservative therapy.

questions.text: You are performing an ultrasound abdomen and notice the below finding. Which of the following conditions is it associated with?
questions.solution:
The given ultrasound abdomen depicts the target sign suggestive of intussusception.

Intussusception occurs when a portion of the bowel is telescoped into an adjacent segment. The most common location of intussusception is ileocolic. Clinically, it presents with cramping abdominal pain, palpable sausage-shaped abdominal mass, and passage of red currant jelly stools.

A plain radiograph may show a meniscus sign, i.e. soft tissue mass contrasting the bowel that is air-filled. The target sign of intestinal intussusception, also known as the doughnut sign or bull's eye sign, is a diagnostic feature observed on abdominal ultrasound. This appearance is due to concentric alternating echogenic and hypoechogenic bands. The echogenic bands are formed by the mucosa and muscularis, and the hypoechoic bands are formed by the submucosa.

Other ultrasound signs of intussusception include:

  • Pseudokidney sign - This is seen in the longitudinal section of the bowel. The edematous bowel resembles renal parenchyma, and the mesentery, which is dragged into the intussusception, resembles renal hilum.
  • Crescent in a doughnut sign - A hyperechoic semilunar structure caused by mesenteric fat pulled into the intussceptum.

The below images show USG films depicting the target sign and pseudo-kidney sign respectively.

questions.text: A neonate was brought with tachypnoea and feeding difficulties 2 days after birth. Later he developed focal seizures that progressed to coma. The plasma ammonia level is 300 µg/dL. The argininosuccinate level is high but the arginine level is low. What is the enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
This infant with feeding difficulty,  tachypnea and seizures, combined with an elevated arginosuccinate level and low arginine levels most likely has argininosuccinic aciduria. This is associated with an argininosuccinate lyase deficiency.

This condition is accompanied by high levels of argininosuccinate levels in blood, CSF, and urine. Like other classical urea cycle disorders, it presents 1-4 days after birth with lethargy and failure to thrive that progresses to coma and even death. It is also associated with friable, tufted hair known as trichorrhexis nodosa.

Diagnosis is by measurement of erythrocyte argininosuccinate lyase activity and can be performed on umbilical cord blood or amniotic fluid.

Mutations in the ASL gene causes a deficiency of argininosuccinate lyase. As a result, nitrogen is not broken down efficiently. The excess nitrogen accumulates in the blood in the form of ammonia which in-turn damages the brain and other tissues and causes neurological problems & other related symptoms.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: The X-ray of a patient with a spinal fracture following a road traffic accident is given below. Which of the following statements about the injury seen is false?

choices.text: It is an inherently stable horizontal fracture
It is horizontal avulsion fracture of vertebral bodies
It is seen in people who wear a seat belt without shoulder harness
Associated abdominal injuries are seen in 50% of these injuries

questions.solution:
The X-ray image shows a Chance fracture, which is by definition unstable as it can involve middle and posterior columns. 

Chance fracture is also known as seat-belt injury or the jack-knife injury. This injury is typically located in the upper lumbar spine in people involved in motor vehicle collisions while wearing a lap seat-belt without a shoulder harness. The sudden deceleration causes flexion and posterior distraction of the spine. This causes the mid-lumbar spine to bend like a jack-knife around an axis anterior to the vertebral column.

There is a tear in the vertebra that passes transversely through the bones (bony Chance fracture), or the ligamentous structures (soft Chance fracture), or both. There is little or no crushing of the vertebral body. However, it is an unstable injury as the posterior and middle columns are distracted. Neurological damage is uncommon. Associated intra-abdominal injuries are seen in 50% of these injuries. 

X-rays may show a horizontal fracture with the split running through the vertebra. It may involve the spinous process, the transverse processes, pedicles and the vertebral body. There may be opening up of the disc space posteriorly. 

Most Chance fractures can be managed conservatively with bed rest and bracing. If posterior fixation is done, it will allow early mobilization. Ligamentous Chance fractures require posterior instrumented fusion. 

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the vertebra

Burst fracture - Vertical compression injury

Chance fracture - horizontal fracture of the vertebral body

Clay-shoveller's fracture - spinous process fracture of C6, C7 or T1

Dens fracture - Odontoid process fracture

Hangman's fracture - fracture of both pedicles of C2

Holdsworth fracture - unstable spinal fracture-dislocation at the thoracolumbar junction

Jefferson's fracture - fracture of first cervical vertebra

Motorcyclist's fracture - transverse fracture across base of the skull

Whiplash's injury - hyperextension followed by flexion 

Undertaker's fracture -Post-mortem fracture of the lower cervical spine with C6-C7 disc disruption

questions.text: The splint shown in the image is used in the palsy of which nerve?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a knuckle bender splint which is used in the management of ulnar nerve palsy.

In ulnar claw hand, there is loss of function of intrinsic muscles of the hand. So, knuckle bender splint is used to flex the metacarpophalangeal joint and extend the interphalangeal joint.

The following is an image of the cock-up splint used for radial nerve palsy:
