questions.text: The imaginary plane passing through the bony prominences marked in red in the image below lies at the level of________.
questions.solution:
The structures marked in red are the tubercles of the iliac crest. An imaginary line passing through them forms the trans-tubercular plane which lies at the upper border of L5. 

The abdomen is divided into 9 regions based on the following:

  • Two transverse planes:
    • Subcostal plane which is indicated by a line that joins the lowest point of the costal margin on each side. It corresponds to the level of 10th costal cartilage and lower border of second lumbar vertebra(L2) or upper border of third lumbar vertebra (L3) 
    • Trans-tubercular plane is indicated by a line that joins the tubercles of the iliac crests. It corresponds to the level of fifth lumbar vertebra (L5).
  • Two vertical planes on both sides:
    • Right and left lateral planes passing from mid-clavicular point to the mid-inguinal point.

Related Pearl: Abdominal planes and their landmarks

Planes that divide the abdomen into 9 regions are:

  • Horizontal planes 
    • At the level of L3 - Subcostal plane (between 10th costal cartilages). It corresponds to the 3rd part of the duodenum
    • At the level of L5 - Transtubercular plane (between tubercles of iliac crests). It corresponds to the origin of inferior vena cava. 
  • Vertical planes (paramedian or lateral planes)
    • From mid-clavicular point to mid-inguinal point on both sides 

The nine regions of the abdomen include:

  • Right hypochondriac, epigastric, left hypochondriac
  • Right lumbar, umbilical (central), left lumbar
  • Right iliac, hypogastric (suprapubic), left iliac

Other planes and angles in the abdomen are:

  • Transpyloric (Addison's) plane - passes midway between the suprasternal notch and the upper border of the pubic symphysis.
  • Supracristal plane - passes through the highest point of the iliac crest on both sides. It corresponds to the level of the L4 body or L4/5 disc and its spinous process. It is an important landmark when performing a lumbar puncture or spinal injection. The bifurcation of the abdominal aorta lies approximately in this plane.
  • The plane of the pubic crest - passes through the upper border of the pubic symphysis. In supine, this plane intersects the tip of the coccyx and the femoral head.
  • Renal angle - between the 12th rib and the outer border of erector spinae muscle. The lower border of normal kidneys may occasionally be felt here. 
  • Lumbar triangle of Petit - formed below by the iliac crest, anteriorly by external oblique, and posteriorly by latissimus dorsi. Lumbar hernia can occur here.

questions.text: Which sampling method is used for assessing the immunization status of children under the immunization program?
questions.solution:
Cluster sampling is the method of sampling done in immunization programs for assessing the immunization status of children.

Related Pearl: Sampling

1. Simple random sampling

  • In simple random sampling, samples are drawn in such a way that every element in a population has equal chances of being included.
  • Randomness refers to the method of picking the sample and not the outcome.

2. Stratified random sampling

  • In stratified random sampling, the population is first divided into homogeneous groups, or strata. From these strata, random samples are drawn.
  • For example, dividing a population into the strata of men, women, and children and then picking samples randomly from these strata.

3. Cluster sampling

  • In cluster sampling, the population is divided into internally heterogeneous groups. Then a simple random sampling is done of these clusters and taken as the samples.
  • In other words, the clusters are the sampling unit.
  • This is usually done when large-scale simple random sampling or stratified sampling is laborious or expensive.
  • This is the method used in assessing the immunization status of children.
  • Cluster sampling involves a design effect, which is an adjustment to allow for design structure. It aids in the correlation between clusters.
  • Multistage sampling is a form of cluster sampling, where sampling clusters are chosen from the already divided clusters.

4. Systematic random sampling

  • In systematic sampling, there is a systematic pattern to selecting the elements of a sample.
  • For example, every 3rd baby to be born can be selected.

questions.text: While performing an autopsy, you notice honeycombing of the liver. What does it signify?
questions.solution:
Honeycombing of the liver is a sign of putrefaction.

In putrefaction, Clostridium welchii produces small clumps in tissue space and produce gas. This tends to increase the size of the liver and it becomes soft and studded with blisters. As bubbles develop in the liver, the organ develops a honeycombed vesicular and foamy appearance.

questions.text: A 54-year-old farmer from Assam presented with the finding shown in the image.  He had also developed a painless swelling in his elbow 2 years back which has gradually been increasing in size.  Which of the following is the drug of choice to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
A painless swelling in the elbow and image showing sclerosing keratitis are suggestive of onchocerchiasis (river blindness). The drug of choice is ivermectin. 

Onchocerchiasis is caused by Onchocerca volvulus. It is also known as convoluted filaria or blinding filaria. The vector is blackfly (Simulium species) which breeds in fast-flowing rivers. Thus, the disease is most commonly seen along the course of rivers and is also called river blindness.

Patients usually present with a subcutaneous nodule or onchocercoma. It is a firm,non-tender nodule arising from bony sites like scalp, elbow, ribs, and iliac crest. It is associated with pruritus and rashes. The presence of microfilaria in the eyes causes photophobia and gradual loss of vision. The most severe manifestations are sclerosing keratitis and chorioretinitis, leading to blindness. It is the 2nd major infective cause of blindness in the world after trachoma.

Suramin and diethylcarbamazine (DEC) were used earlier for its treatment but are not used nowadays. DEC destroys microfilariae but usually causes Mazzotti reaction consisting of pruritus, rash, lymphadenopathy, fever, hypotension, and occasionally, eye damage.

Note: Onchocerciasis is not endemic in India but sporadic cases have been reported from North-Eastern India.

questions.text: A 30-year-old psychiatric patient consumed some liquid from a bottle accidentally. Clinical examination shows a peculiar rash as shown in the image. What is the likely cause of this presentation?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the characteristic boiled lobster appearance. It is seen in poisoning with boric acid.

In severe poisoning with boric acid, a beefy red skin rash, most often affecting palms, soles, buttocks, and scrotum, is seen. The intense erythema is followed by extensive exfoliation.

Boric acid is used as an antiseptic and insecticide.

questions.text: Abnormally high plasma hCG levels are found in all except
questions.solution:
In ectopic pregnancy, hCG levels are lower than normal.

Substantively high levels of hCG detected in:

  • Multiple pregnancy
  • Hydatidiform mole or choriocarcinoma and
  • Pregnancy with a trisomy 21 fetus (Down’s syndrome)
  • Erythroblastosis fetalis associated with fetal hemolytic anemia

Relatively lower levels of hCG detected in:

  • Ectopic pregnancies
  • Spontaneous abortion

questions.text: Which is the incorrect statement regarding the condition shown in the image?

choices.text: Inframammary area  and intermammary folds may be involved
TNF alpha inhibitors can be used in treatment
Obesity and smoking are associated with it
Surgery cannot be done for this condition.

questions.solution:
The given image shows hidradenitis supurativa or inverse acne. Surgical excision is the best treatment that offers a cure.

Hidradenitis suppurativa is a chronic, inflammatory, recurrent, debilitating, follicular disease that usually presents after puberty.

There are painful, deep‐seated inflamed lesions in the apocrine gland‐bearing areas of the body, most commonly the axillary, inguinal, and anogenital regions.

This definition is based on the San Francisco modification of the Dessau criteria.

The following three criteria must be met for the diagnosis to be made:

  1. Typical lesions - deep‐seated, painful nodules or ‘blind boils’; abscesses, draining sinuses, bridged scars, and paired or multiheaded open pseudocomedones in secondary lesions.
  2. Typical topography - axillae, groin, perineal and perianal region, buttocks and infra‐ and intermammary folds.
  3. Chronicity and recurrence of lesions. 

More common in young women of ages 20-29 years. Obesity and smoking are the two main factors associated with hidradenitis suppurativa.

Treatment includes: 

  • Antibiotics - tetracycline, clindamycin
  • Intralesional corticosteroids
  • Immunosuppressants
  • Acitretin
  • Anti-TNF alpha therapy
  • Surgery

questions.text: A pregnant woman from a rural area registers under Janani Suraksha Yojana. Which of the following services would not be provided to her under this scheme?

choices.text: Safe motherhood services under Vandematharam scheme

questions.solution:
The Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) does not provide STD counseling.

Janani Suraksha Yojana is a safe motherhood intervention launched under National Rural Health Mission (NRHM) to reduce maternal and neonatal mortality by promoting institutional delivery among poor pregnant women. The services provided by the JSY are:

  • Cash is disbursed to the mother at the institution for having an institutional delivery.
  • Safe motherhood services (IFA tablets, TT vaccination) under the Vandemataram scheme. 
  • Village health and nutrition day
  • Maternal death review
  • Pregnancy tracking: ASHA worker/Anganwadi Worker (AWW) or any other link worker help in monitoring antenatal check-ups, and post-delivery care.
  • Safe abortion services: mifepristone followed by misoprostol and manual vacuum aspiration.

questions.text: A 25-year-old is admitted to the ER after being involved in a road traffic accident. Which type of IV cannula would achieve the maximum flow rate to provide fluid resuscitation?
questions.solution:
The orange cannula (14 Gauge) has the maximum flow rate of 270 mL/min.

Tip:

A simple mnemonic to remember these in descending order of their numbering is nature. The mantle zone of the earth is orange, the land is grey, the grass is green, the butterfly on the grass is pink, the sky is blue, and the sun is yellow.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient came to ED with complaints of weakness, paresthesia, and breathing difficulty. Relevant investigations were done. The ECG obtained is suggestive of :
questions.solution:
The symptoms of weakness, paresthesia, and dyspnea along with the given ECG showing depression of the ST segment, a decrease in the amplitude of the T wave (flattening or inversion), and an increase in the amplitude of U waves (at the end of the T wave) are characteristic of hypokalemia.

In the given ECG, leads V1-V6 exhibit T wave inversion. U waves are well appreciated in leads V2-V5.

Hypokalemia leads to dynamic ECG changes. The image given shows the sequence of changes observed:

Hypokalemia is defined as plasma K+ concentration of <3.5meq/L. It can also cause premature atrial and ventricular beats, sinus bradycardia, paroxysmal atrial or junctional tachycardia, atrioventricular block, and ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation.

Other options:

Option B: Hyperkalemia causes tall peaked T waves with a shortened QT interval. There is a progressive lengthening of the PR interval and QRS duration with an increase in potassium levels, eventually leading to the disappearance of the P wave; and widening of the QRS complex to a sine wave pattern.

Option C: Hypocalcemia causes prolongation of the QT interval. There is a lengthening of the ST segment, while the T wave (which correlates with the time for repolarization) remains unaltered.

Option D: Hypercalcemia causes shortening of the QT interval and a decrease in the ST segment duration.

questions.text: A 23-year-old primigravida at 32 weeks of gestation presents to the labour room with lower abdominal pain. Her vitals are BP - 90/60 mmHg and PR - 120 bpm. Fetal distress was noted and she was taken up for a caesarean section. The uterus appears as shown below.  Which of the following is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is seen in revealed abruptio placenta
It is an indication for hysterectomy
It is a case of uteroplacental apoplexy

questions.solution:
The given image shows a couvelaire uterus or uteroplacental apoplexy which is seen in severe forms of concealed abruptio placenta. 

There is massive extravasation of blood into the uterine musculature up to the serosa. Thus, the uterus has a port wine colour, which can be patchy or diffuse. They can also extend to the broad ligament, ovaries and peritoneal cavity.

It is usually observed during caesarean section. It is not an indication of hysterectomy.

questions.text: A father runs to a PHC with a baby wrapped in a towel. The neonate was delivered a few hours back, at home, by the local dai. On initial examination, the medical officer notes cyanosis and severe tachypnoea. Which of the following features would favor a diagnosis of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome in this child?

choices.text: Patchy coarse infiltrates on chest X-ray
Emaciated appearance with palmar and plantar creases
Onset of distress after 6 hours of birth

questions.solution:
Air bronchogram on chest x-ray is suggestive of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome.

Other chest x-ray findings in respiratory distress syndrome (RDS):

  • Fine reticulogranular pattern
  • Bilateral diffuse ground-glass opacities
  • White-out lung (severe disease)

Option A: Patchy coarse infiltrates are associated with meconium aspiration syndrome.

Option C: Reduced fat under the skin resulting in an emaciated appearance as well as prominent creases is a feature of post-term babies. Respiratory distress syndrome is more common among preterm babies 

Option D: Onset of respiratory distress syndrome is within 6 hours of birth. 

Related Pearl: Radiologic features of the major respiratory distress disorders in newborns

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia

  • Mediastinal shift
  • Bowel loops in the left hemithorax

 

Respiratory Distress Syndrome

  • Low lung volume
  • Symmetric ground-glass opacity (reticulogranular pattern)
  • Air bronchogram
  • White-out lung (severe disease)

Chest radiograph (A) on Day 2: shows reticulogranular opacities throughout both lungs with prominent air bronchograms. The cardiac silhouette is preserved and both lungs are hypoaerated.

Chest radiograph (B) on Day 9 (untreated): shows more severe changes. There is obliteration of the cardiac and diaphragmatic contours due to marked opacification, giving a complete ‘white out’ appearance

 Meconium Aspiration Syndrome

  • Hyperinflation
  • Patchy infiltrates
  • Coarse streaking

questions.text: A man was rushed to the casualty after getting stabbed in the back with a knife. On MRI, a complete transection of one side of the spinal cord is suspected. Which of the following is likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Pain and temperature loss on the opposite side
Fine touch lost on the opposite side
Pain and temperature lost on the same side
Only pain lost on the same side

questions.solution:
This patient most likely has Brown-Sequard syndrome. It is characterized by loss of pain and temperature on the opposite side.

Hemisection of the spinal cord causes damage to ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway, ventrolateral spinothalamic tract) and descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways, which is called the Brown-Séquard syndrome.

The lesion to fasciculus gracilus or fasciculus cuneatus leads to ipsilateral loss of discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception below the level of the lesion.

The loss of the spinothalamic tract leads to contra­lateral loss of pain and temperature sensation beginning one or two segments below the lesion.

Damage to the cor­ticospinal tract produces weakness and spasticity in certain muscle groups on the same side of the body.

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text:
A 30-year-old albino woman presents with a characteristic finding as shown below. Which of the following statements are true regarding the suspected condition?
  1. It is due to the deposition of copper in the Descemet's membrane
  2. It requires screening for underlying lipid disorder
  3. It is seen in patients with the neurological form of Wilson’s disease
  4. If seen unilaterally it is suggestive of ipsilateral carotid stenosis
  5. It is also called limbus sign
questions.solution:
A 30-year-old individual with corneal changes, as shown above, known as gerontoxon or arcus lipoides, may require screening for underlying lipid disorder.

Arcus senilis (AS), also known as gerontoxon, arcus lipoides or arcus cornealis, is usually an age-related lipid degeneration of the peripheral cornea that forms a light grey or bluish ring. It is the most common peripheral corneal opacity, typically benign, occurring bilaterally and prevalent among the elderly.

However, when observed in individuals under 50, termed arcus juvenilis, it may indicate underlying lipid disorder and an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, warranting lipid profile screening. Unilateral cases of arcus senilis may indicate contralateral carotid artery stenosis due to decreased ophthalmic blood flow on the ipsilateral side, resulting in protection from forming arcus in the ipsilateral eye.

The condition results from the leakage of lipoproteins (phospholipids and cholesterol) from limbal capillaries into the corneal stroma, initiating deposition at the superior and inferior cornea. Over time, the ring progresses circumferentially, sparing a clear corneal zone adjacent to the limbus called the interval of Vogt.

The following opacities and rings can resemble arcus senilis:

  • Kayser- Fleischer (KF) ring: A dark brown ring caused by the deposition of excess copper in Descemet's membrane, classically seen in Wilson's disease. It may also be seen in certain chronic, cholestatic liver conditions such as primary biliary cirrhosis. 
  • Limbus sign: Caused by dystrophic calcification, seen as a "milky precipitate" at the corneal limbus. It can sometimes be confused with AS in the elderly population.
  • Pseudo-gerontoxon: A greyish peri-limbal band of superficial scarring adjacent to a previously inflamed segment of the limbus resembling AS, seen in vernal keratoconjunctivitis.

The image below depicts the Kayser–Fleischer ring and anterior capsule of the crystalline lens (Sunflower cataract) seen in Wilson's disease.

questions.text: While examining a patient with a suspected bone tumour, you find that the swelling is pulsatile in nature. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, osteosarcoma is the most likely diagnosis as it is a pulsatile bone tumour. Pulsations in the tumour occur due to hypervascularity.

Pulsatile bone tumours include:

  • Osteosarcoma
  • Aneurysmal bone cyst
  • Angioendothelioma of bone
  • Osteoclastoma/Giant cell tumour
  • Metastases from kidney and thyroid carcinoma

questions.text: You come across a child with growth hormone deficiency during your ward rounds. Which of the following features would you not expect in this child?

choices.text: History of short stature at birth

questions.solution:
Children with growth hormone deficiency usually have normal growth at birth. Growth retardation (decline in growth velocity) becomes apparent around 1 year of age. 

Growth in-utero is dependant on genetic, environmental, nutrition and growth factors. GH levels peak at mid-gestation, increase at birth, and then reduce by 2 weeks of life. At around 6 months of age, GH levels reach pre-pubertal levels and from there on have a major influence on growth. Thus the deficiency becomes apparent after a significant period of GH-dependent growth has occurred. 

Characteristic features of growth hormone deficiency (Pituitary Dwarfism):

  1. Normal growth at birth with growth retardation becoming apparent around 1 year of age
  2. Proportionate short stature
  3. Hypoglycemic seizures in newborn
  4. Small larynx with a high-pitched voice
  5. Small genitalia (micropenis)
  6. Delayed skeletal maturation
  7. Delayed dentition
  8. Delayed puberty (sexual infantilism)
  9. Doll-like facial appearance: small, round facies, frontal prominence, depressed nasal bridge (saddle nose), eyes may bulge, underdeveloped mandible and chin, normal head circumference but craniofacial disproportion due to small facies
  10. Short neck
  11. Normal intelligence.

questions.text: What is the average maternal requirement of iron during a singleton pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Maternal requirement of iron during a singleton gestation averages close to 1000 mg.

Iron requirement during pregnancy
Fetus and placenta 300 mg
Expansion of maternal hemoglobin mass 500 mg
Losses through normal excretion routes 200 mg
Total 1000 mg

The average iron stores in a non-pregnant female is around 300 mg. This falls short of the requirement of iron during pregnancy which is 1000 mg. Hence iron supplementation is necessary to prevent iron deficiency anemia during pregnancy. This also forms the basis for prophylactic iron supplementation during pregnancy.

Note: The Federation of Obstetrics and Gynaecology (FOGSI) states that the iron requirement in pregnancy is 840 mg, as about 160 mg of iron is saved due to amenorrhea during pregnancy.

questions.text: A 26-year-old batsman was rushed to the ER when he fell unconscious after a cricket ball hit his head. He regained consciousness later but started to deteriorate rapidly. A plain CT of the patient is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of lucid interval in this patient and the CT image are suggestive of extradural hematoma. The above CT scan shows a large extradural hematoma (hyperdense biconvex/lentiform shape) with a mass effect.

Extradural hemorrhage (EDH) is the accumulation of blood between the skull and the dura. It usually results from arterial disruption, especially of the middle meningeal artery. It lies behind the pterion, which is the thinnest part of the skull. 

In EDH, the patient is initially unconscious from the concussive aspect of the head trauma. The patient then awakens and has a “lucid interval,” while the hematoma sub-clinically expands. As the volume of the hematoma grows, intracranial pressure (ICP) increases, and the patient rapidly becomes lethargic and herniates.

Uncal herniation from an EDH classically causes ipsilateral third nerve palsy and contralateral hemiparesis.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: A multiparous woman at term presents to the labour room with bleeding per vaginum and ruptured membranes. NST shows fetal distress and sinusoidal heart rate pattern. How will you manage this patient?

choices.text: Rapid induction and delivery by vacuum
Rapid induction and delivery by forceps
Adopt Vagos method and rapid vaginal delivery

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of vasa previa since bleeding is associated with fetal distress and sinusoidal pattern in NST. Actively bleeding vasa previa in a term gestation is managed by immediate LSCS.

Sinusoidal pattern in CTG is a regular, smooth, undulating signal resembling a sine wave. It can be seen in conditions associated with severe fetal anemia like: 

  1. Anti-D allo-immunisation
  2. Fetal-maternal haemorrhage
  3. Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome
  4. Ruptured vasa previa
  5. Acute fetal hypoxia
  6. Infection
  7. Cardiac malformations
  8. Hydrocephalus
  9. Gastroschisis

Sinusoidal pattern on CTG:

Management of vasa previa:

  • No bleeding
    • 28-32 weeks - antenatal corticosteroids
    • 30-34 weeks - admission for surveillance
    • ≥37 weeks - elective caesarean section
  • Bleeding present
    • Emergency caesarean section

Note: Vagos method is used in the management of umbilical cord prolapse.

questions.text: A patient with deep vein thrombosis was started on a new drug. After 2 days, he presented with the given finding. Which of the following drugs is implicated in causing the above condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of the development of purple toe syndrome, after starting a new drug for the treatment of deep vein thrombosis, is suggestive of the adverse effect of warfarin.

Purple toe syndrome is a rare complication of warfarin therapy. It occurs due to cholesterol microemboli released from atheromatous plaques, which cause arteriolar occlusion. Warfarin must be immediately stopped and replaced with an oral factor Xa inhibitor (e.g. apixaban).

Activation of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X and proteins C and S are done by carboxylation of their glutamate residues, with the help of the reduced form of vitamin K as a co-factor. This reduced form of vitamin K needs to be constantly recycled back from its oxidized form for the reaction to continue. This recycling is done by the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase, which is competitively inhibited by warfarin. Hence, there will be a reduction in the activation of coagulation factors.

The image below shows warfarin's mechanism of action.

The half-life of proteins C and S are 8 and 24 hours, respectively, which is relatively shorter than the half-lives of other clotting factors, particularly factor II. Therefore, the full antithrombotic effect of warfarin is not achieved for 4 to 5 days. For this reason, warfarin must be bridged with a rapidly acting parenteral anticoagulant, such as heparin, low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH), or fondaparinux, in patients with thrombosis or at high risk for thrombosis.

Uses of warfarin are acute deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, and preventing stroke or systemic embolization in patients with a mechanical heart valve. 

Adverse effects of warfarin are bleeding, skin necrosis, purple toe syndrome, and fetal warfarin syndrome (hypoplasia of the nose, eye socket, hand bones, and growth retardation).

The therapeutic dose of warfarin is monitored by an INR range of 2-3. Warfarin toxicity can occur when the INR exceeds 4 and can lead to fatal bleeding. Treatment includes withholding warfarin, with vitamin K, and blood transfusions or fresh frozen plasma to replenish clotting factors.

Warfarin, LMWH, and UFH do not accumulate in breast milk and do not have an anticoagulant effect in the newborn. They are compatible with breastfeeding.

Warfarin is mainly metabolized by the CYP2C9 enzyme. Drugs that affect the CYP2C9 enzyme can alter the anticoagulant function of warfarin and these include the following:

Reduced efficacy:

  • CYP2C9 activation by drugs: barbiturates, carbamazepine, rifampin
  • Oral contraceptives: increase blood levels of clotting factors

Increased efficacy:

  • Drugs causing CYP2C9 inhibition:
    • Amiodarone
    • Azole antifungals
    • Cimetidine
    • Clopidogrel
    • Cotrimoxazole
    • Disulfiram
    • Isoniazid
    • Metronidazole
    • Fluoxetine
    • Sulfinpyrazone
    • Zafirlukast

Other options:

Option B: Heparin acts by activating antithrombin III, thereby inactivating the active form of clotting factors II, IX, X, XI, XII, and XIII. Adverse effects are bleeding and heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) due to the formation of antibodies against the heparin-platelet complex.

Option C: Dabigatran is a direct thrombin inhibitor. It is used for the prevention of embolism and stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation. Bleeding and dyspepsia are the most important adverse effects.

Option D: Rivaroxaban is a direct inhibitor of factor Xa. It is used for prophylaxis and treatment of deep vein thrombosis. Side effects reported are bleeding, nausea, hypotension, tachycardia, and edema.

Related Pearl: Classification of Anticoagulants

Classification of anticoagulants
1) Vitamin K antagonist Warfarin
2) Direct thrombin inhibitors (DTI)   

Parenteral: Monovalent DTI- Argatroban

Bivalent DTI- Lepirudin, Desirudin, Bivalirudin

Oral: Dabigatran 
3) Indirect thrombin inhibitors 

Unfractionated heparin

Low molecular weight heparins: Enoxaparin, Dalteparin, Tinzaparin, Nadroparin
4) Indirect factor Xa inhibitors Fondaparinux
5) Oral Direct factor Xa inhibitors Rivaroxaban,Apixaban, Edoxaban,Betrixaban

Related Pearl: Specific reversal agents for anticoagulants

  • Heparin: protamine sulfate
  • Warfarin: vitamin K
  • Rivaroxaban and other oral Xa inhibitors: andexanet alfa
  • Dabigatran: idarucizumab

questions.text: A 50-year-old fisherman presented with complaints of blood in the urine. A diagnostic cystoscopy was done and the microscopic view of the biopsied specimen is given below. Which of the following is most likely to be associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing keratin pearls are suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma of the urinary bladder. It is associated with chronic Schistosoma hematobium infection. 

Chronic schistosomiasis presents as painless hematuria, dysuria, and proteinuria. Fibrosis may cause obstructive uropathies like hydronephrosis and hydroureter. It has been associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder. Such malignancy is detected in a younger age group as compared to transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder.

The following parasites cause malignancies:

  • Schistosoma hematobium - bladder carcinoma
  • Clonorchis sinensis and Opisthorchis viverrini - bile duct carcinoma

questions.text: A mother brings her 4-month-old infant to the ENT department with complaints of difficulty in breathing. On examination, you notice  biphasic stridor. Rigid bronchoscopy shows subglottic hemangioma. Which of the following is not included in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is of congenital subglottic hemangioma. Embolization is not preferred in congenital laryngeal conditions. All congenital laryngeal conditions tend to regress with growth.

The principal management is conservative as many hemangiomas involute spontaneously. Depending on the status of the airway, treatment can involve:

  • To wait and watch
  • Steroid therapy
  • Tracheostomy and observation

If the condition does not regress with time, the modalities of treatment include:

  • LASER excision
  • Laryngofissure and excision
  • -pexy and -plasty procedures (epiglottopexy, supraglottoplasty, etc)

questions.text:
A middle-aged man presents with fever, cough with scanty sputum, and fatigue. He had a throat infection a week ago. His blood investigations and chest X-ray are given below. Which is the most likely causative agent for his condition?
Parameter Values
Hb 8.3 g/dl
LDH 560 U/L
AST 23 IU/L
ALT 24 IU/L
Unconjugated bilirubin 1.8 mg/dl
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with chest X-ray and lab values is suggestive of atypical pneumonia caused by Mycoplasma pneumoniae. The blood investigations show decreased hemoglobin, elevated LDH, and elevated unconjugated bilirubin suggestive of hemolytic anemia. 

Mycoplasma is the most common bacteria causing atypical pneumonia and the second most common cause of pneumonia.

Clinical Presentation: 

  1. Pulmonary manifestations:
    • URTI- tracheobronchitis/ pharyngitis
    • Pneumonia( seen in only 10% patients)
  2. Extrapulmonary manifestations:
    • Cold agglutinin disease( IgM mediated autoimmune hemolytic anemia)
    • Erythema multiforme or Steven Johnson syndrome
    • Arthralgia with adenopathy
    • Guillain Barre Syndrome
    • Myocarditis
    • Pericarditis
    • Encephalitis
    • Bullous myringitis

Chest X-ray shows patchy consolidation at the hilum and fanning to the periphery.

Azithromycin is the drug of choice. Doxycycline is the second-best drug for the management of atypical pneumonia.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes with complaints of fever and increasing fatigue for the past week. On examination, he is febrile, hypotensive and tachycardic. The findings of microscopic examination of his peripheral blood smear is given below. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Fever, fatigue, hypotension, tachycardia and the blood smear showing multiple ring forms in RBCs are suggestive of malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum.

Falciparum malaria, or malignant tertian malaria, is the most serious malaria. Plasmodium falciparum infects both young and mature erythrocytes, resulting in a large population of erythrocytes affected. Affected erythrocytes display cytoadherence, form rosettes and cause capillary plugging in vital organs like the brain, kidney, lungs etc. Diagnosis is by demonstration of P. falciparum in peripheral blood smear. The peripheral smear findings of falciparum malaria include:

  • Multiple ring forms: Multiple delicate rings are visible within the erythrocytes
  • Double chromatin: Binucleate ring forms resembling stereo headphones
  • Accole form or form applique: Ring forms are attached to the margins of red cells
  • Maurer's dots or clefts: Coarse brick red dots within erythrocytes
  • Banana shaped gametocytes within erythrocytes
  • Absent schizont

The below image shows banana shaped gametocyte:

Related Pearl: Difference between plasmodium species

Feature P.vivax P.ovale P.falciparum P.malaria
Discovered by Grassi & Feletti Stephens Welch Laveran
Erythrocyte preference Reticulocytes Reticulocytes All stages Old erythrocytes
Stages found in peripheral blood Trophozoite, schizonts, gametocytes As in vivax Ring form, accole form, gametocytes Band forms
Infected erythrocyte Enlarged pale with Schuffner’s dots Pear-shaped, fimbriated, Schuffner’s dots (Jame’s dots) Normal size, Maurer’s cleft Normal size, Ziemann’s stippling
Gametocyte Spherical, fills the cell Similar to but smaller than vivax Crescent, Banana shaped Similar to but smaller than vivax

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with symptoms suggestive of Achilles tendon rupture. He had undergone renal transplantation and is now being treated with an antimicrobial agent. Which of the following antimicrobials might he be on?
questions.solution: Among the following options, the most likely drug to have caused this condition is ciprofloxacin, since Achilles tendon rupture and tendinitis are side effects of quinolones. Elderly patients (>60 years), patients on corticosteroids and solid organ transplant recipients are at higher risk.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy presents with the following finding after a trivial fall. His lab investigations are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Platelet count - 4,00,000 /μL

Bleeding time - normal

PT - normal

aPTT - prolonged
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing hemarthrosis and elevated aPTT is suggestive of hemophilia. 

Specific tests for measuring levels of factor VIII and factor IX can determine whether it is hemophilia A or hemophilia B respectively.

Clinical features of hemophilia:

  • Hemarthroses - joint hemorrhages, later causing progressive deformities
  • Recurrent bleeding
  • Pseudotumour syndrome - fascial hemorrhages that occur as blood-filled cysts with calcification and proliferation of fibroblasts, giving the appearance of the tumor

It is associated with elevated aPTT and normal platelet count, bleeding time, and PT.

Option A: In ITP, the platelet count is low and bleeding time is prolonged.

Option B: In functional platelet disorders, like Bernard Soulier syndrome, the platelet count is normal and bleeding time is prolonged.

Option D: In vitamin K deficiency, both PT and aPTT are prolonged. PT is relatively more prolonged than is the aPTT.

Related Pearl: Differences between Bleeding Disorders and Coagulation disorders

Finding Bleeding disorders Coagulation disorders
Cause

Quantitative/ Qualitative platelet abnormality

 Deficiency of clotting factors
Sex More common in females (commonly autoimmune) More common in males (commonly X-linked)
Family history Rare (except in VWD) Common
Petechiae Characteristic  Rare
Superficial ecchymosis Small and Multiple Large and Solitary
Bleeding from superficial cuts  Profuse Minimal persistent
Hemarthrosis Rare Characteristic (most common-knee)
Deep dissecting hematomas Rare Characteristic (most common-iliopsoas)
Laboratory tests Bleeding time is prolonged PT and/or PTT are prolonged
Most common Inherited: VWD

Inherited: Hemophilia A

Acquired: Hemorrhagic diathesis of liver disease

VWD: von Willebrand disease

PT: Prothrombin time

PTT: Partial thromboplastin time

questions.text: A patient from a hilly area was referred with a partial small bowel obstruction confirmed on CECT. Conservative management was tried for a week, but he continued to deteriorate and was taken up for emergency laparotomy. On post-operative day 7, he developed atrial fibrillation. Investigations revealed elevated free T3 and free T4 levels. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of the Jod-Basedow phenomenon, likely due to the administration of an iodine-containing contrast agent during CECT.

This phenomenon is characterized by hyperthyroidism due to enhanced thyroid hormone production following the administration of contrast agents and other iodine-containing substances. This occurs in:

  • Patients with autonomous thyroid nodules
  • Patients with pre-existing subclinical hypothyroidism (endemic iodine deficiency in hilly areas)

Option B: Wolff-Chaikoff effect is characterized by the transient inhibition of thyroid iodide organification by excess iodine, thereby decreasing thyroid hormone synthesis.

Option C: Basedow disease is another name for Graves' disease.

Option D: Plummer disease is another name for toxic multinodular goitre.

questions.text: Confusion assessment test is used in:
questions.solution:
Confusion assessment test is used in detection of delirium.

Delirium is reported to occur in a wide range of mechanically ventilated ICU patients and can be detected by the Confusion Assessment Method (CAM)-ICU or the Intensive Care Delirium Screening Checklist. These tools are used to ask patients to answer simple questions and perform simple tasks and can be used readily at the bedside.

questions.text: All are ocular manifestations of dengue except ________.
questions.solution:
Cataract is not an ocular manifestation of dengue.

Dengue has varied manifestations, in different organ systems, mainly of inflammation and bleeding. The mechanisms for ocular manifestations in dengue include a direct viral effect on the eye, an immune-mediated vasculitis, and a variety of secondary effects related to dengue-induced vascular leakage and hemostatic abnormalities.

Ocular manifestations of dengue are:

  • visual impairment which can be either painless or painful
  • Retro orbital pain
  • Conjunctival injection and subconjunctival hemorrhage(option B)
  • Uveitis(option C)
  • Complications such as retinal hemorrhage(option D), retinal edema, macular ischemia, macular edema, vitreous hemorrhage, vitritis, and optic neuritis or papillitis.

Depending on the severity of the disease, gradual improvement in vision occurs, although in rare cases permanent visual impairment may be seen.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with hypertension, on treatment with methyldopa, comes for routine evaluation. She is found to have a positive Coombs test but is asymptomatic. What is the next course of action for this patient?
questions.solution:
The best course of action for the patient is close monitoring for any signs or symptoms of hemolysis.

Coombs test is done to test the presence of antibodies against Rh antigens on the red blood cells, which result in hemolysis. Positive Coombs test is seen in 20% of patients who receive methyldopa.

However, only 1-5% of such patients develop hemolytic anemia and hence, a positive Coombs test is not a necessary indication for stopping methyldopa treatment. They must be monitored closely and any signs that indicate hemolytic anemia needs prompt discontinuation of the drug.

questions.text: After suffering from a myocardial infarction, a patient was started on two drugs X and Y. The drug X inhibits the COX-1 enzyme and drug Y inhibits thrombin-induced platelet aggregation. Identify the drugs.
questions.solution:
X- Aspirin and Y- Vorapaxar are the drugs administered to the patient.

Aspirin reduces thromboxane A2 production by inhibiting the COX-1 enzyme. 

Vorapaxar is a competitive antagonist of PAR-1 and inhibits thrombin-induced platelet aggregation. Vorapaxar is indicated in combination with aspirin and/or clopidogrel to reduce thromboembolic events in patients with MI or peripheral vascular disease.

Related Pearl: Classification of anti-platelet drugs

Class Drugs
Cyclooxygenase- I inhibitors Aspirin
Irreversible P2Y12 inhibitors

Ticlopidine, Clopidogrel, Prasugrel
Reversible P2Y12 inhibitors Ticagrelor, Cangrelor
GpIIb/IIIa inhibitors Abciximab, Eptifibatide, Tirofiban
Thrombin (PAR-1) receptor antagonist Vorapaxar 
Phosphodiesterase inhibitors

Dipyridamole

questions.text: Which of the following parameters is used to assess the extent of drug absorption in a plasma concentration vs. time graph?
questions.solution:
The area under the curve of plasma concentration vs. time curve gives the extent of absorption, which is calculated by the trapezoidal rule. 

The following image shows a plasma concentration vs. time graph:

Two drugs may have the same rate of absorption but a different extent of absorption or bioavailability. 

The factors upon which the extent of drug absorption depends are:

  • Lipophilicity - If too lipophilic (e.g., acyclovir), the drug is not soluble enough to cross the water layer adjacent to the cell.
  • Hydrophilicity - If too hydrophilic (e.g., atenolol), the drug cannot cross the lipid cell membrane.

questions.text: You advise a reproductive age woman to vaccinate against HPV. What is this type of prevention called?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of immunisation is an example of primary prevention.

Primary prevention is an action taken before the onset of disease. This reduces the possibility of disease occurrence. Hence, immunization is a form of primary prevention, through specific protection.

Examples of primary prevention include immunization, sanitation, solid and liquid waste management etc.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is admitted with fever and polyarthritis. He had a bout of streptococcal sore throat infection two weeks back. His ESR on admission was 80mm/hr and fever 39°C. What is the mechanism of tissue injury in this condition?

choices.text: Type II and type III hypersensitivity
Type II and type IV hypersensitivity

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with polyarthritis (1 major) along with fever and ESR elevated (2 minor) is suggestive of acute rheumatic fever. It is an example of type II hypersensitivity.

This condition classically occurs a few weeks after an episode of group A streptococcal pharyngitis or, less commonly, skin infections. The antibodies to streptococcal cell-wall antigen cross-react with myocardial antigen resulting in macrophage activation and inflammation.

Acute rheumatic carditis is a common manifestation of active RF and may progress over time to chronic rheumatic heart disease (RHD), mainly manifesting as valvular abnormalities. Damage to heart tissue may be caused by a combination of antibody and T-cell-mediated reactions.

Related Pearl: Types of Type II Antibody-Mediated Hypersentivity

There are 3 mechanisms involved in type 2 hypersensitivity reactions- 

  1. Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction- antibodies react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions
    1. Myasthenia gravis (against acetylcholine receptor)
    2. Graves’ disease (against TSH receptor)
    3. Pemphigus Vulgaris (against epidermal cadherin)
    4. Pernicious anemia (against intrinsic factor)
    5. Insulin resistant diabetes (against insulin receptor
  2. Antibody-mediated opsonization and phagocytosis -antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement and Recruiting Phagocytes
    1. Transfusion reactions
    2. Erythroblastosis fetalis
    3. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
    4. Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
  3. Complement and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation- antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement
    1. Goodpasture syndrome
    2. Vasculitis due to ANCA
    3. Acute rheumatic fever
    4. Vascular rejection in organ graft

questions.text: You are a junior resident in the ENT department asked to examine a patient’s larynx. The patient has complete paralysis of vocal cords following a total thyroidectomy procedure. What is the expected position of the vocal cords?
questions.solution:
Intermediate (cadaveric) position is seen in complete paralysis of the vocal cord.

  • This is a neutral position of the cricoarytenoid joint.
  • Abduction and adduction take place from this position.
  • It is not always seen in cadavers (misnomer).

Related Pearl: Positions of the Vocal Cord

Position Distance from median Seen in
Median 0 During speech/ swallowing
Paramedian 1 mm Recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
Intermediate/ Cadaveric 3 mm Complete paralysis
Slight abduction 7 mm Normal respiration
Full abduction 9 mm Strained respiration

questions.text: An infant is being assessed for hypotonia, seizures, and neurodevelopmental delay. Clinical examination reveals facial deformities, hyporeflexia, and hepatomegaly. A congenital disorder affecting extramitochondrial lipid metabolism is suspected. Which of the following processes is impaired in this patient?

choices.text: H2O2 mediated breakdown of fatty acids
Transport of fatty acyl CoA using shuttle mechanism
Peroxisomal alpha oxidation of fatty acids

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of Zellweger (cerebrohepatorenal) syndrome in which H2O2-mediated peroxisomal beta-oxidation of very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFA) is impaired.

Beta-oxidation in peroxisome is differentiated from that occurring in mitochondria by the formation of H2O2.

Beta-oxidation of fatty acid in peroxisomes is not coupled to ATP synthesis. The high-potential electrons are transferred to O2, which yields H2O2 (instead of FADH2). The enzyme catalase, found exclusively in peroxisomes, converts the hydrogen peroxide to end products water and oxygen. 

Zellweger syndrome is a rare inherited disorder characterized by the absence of peroxisomal enzymes in all tissues leading to the accumulation of C26—C38 polyenoic acids in brain tissue. The clinical manifestation of Zellweger syndrome includes:

  • Facial deformities resembling Down syndrome (Mongoloid facies, Hypertelorism, Frontal bossing, Upslanting palpebral fissure)
  • Brush field spots
  • Hypotonia and hyporeflexia
  • Seizures
  • Neurodevelopmental delay
  • Liver enlargement

Related Pearl: Types, Location and Properties of Fatty acid oxidation

Types of Oxidation

Location

Properties

Associated Disease

Beta oxidation

Mitochondria

A catabolic process by which two-carbons are cleaved from the fatty acid molecule and released as acetyl CoA starting from the carboxyl end.

The chain is broken between the α(2) and β(3) carbon.

1 round of beta-oxidation yield 1FADH2, 1NADH, and 1 Acetyl CoA.

  

Alpha oxidation

Peroxisome

The presence of the 3-methyl group of phytanic acid prevents degradation by beta-oxidation.

The chain is broken between the terminal carboxyl group and α(2) carbon removing that carbon as CO2. The remaining chain is activated with CoA and then undergoes β-Oxidation.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Classic Refsum's Disease

Defective enzyme- Phytanoyl Coa hydroxylase.

Clinical features include:

Ichthyosis, Retinitis pigmentosa, Decreased vision, Peripheral neuropathy, Ataxia

 

Omega oxidation

Endoplasmic Reticulum

An alternative pathway to beta-oxidation occurs in microsomes.

Involves the oxidation of the ω carbon (terminal methyl group) resulting in dicarboxylic acid.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

  

Peroxisomal Beta oxidation

Peroxisome

Very-long-chain fatty acids undergo preliminary β-oxidation in peroxisomes up to octanoyl CoA. The shortened fatty acids undergo further β-oxidation in the mitochondria.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Zellweger (cerebrohepatorenal) syndrome

A rare inherited absence of peroxisomes in all tissues.

They accumulate C26—C38 polyenoic acids in brain tissue and also exhibit a generalized loss of peroxisomal functions. The disease causes severe neurologic symptoms, and most patients die in the first year of life.

questions.text: Identify the lesion of vocal cord in the image given below :
questions.solution:
The image showing grape-like projections, involving the anterior part of the vocal cords depicts a laryngeal papilloma.

Laryngeal papilloma is a benign tumor of the larynx caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV type 6 and 11). They can occur in children, most commonly around 3 -5 years of age (juvenile papillomatosis), as well as in adults. They involve the supraglottic and glottic regions of the larynx. Seeding of the lesions can occur during invasive laryngeal procedures, such as intubation. They have a high recurrence rate and very low potential for malignancy. 

Adult-onset laryngeal papillomatosis is less common and usually seen in males aged 30-50 years. It is less aggressive and involves the anterior part of the vocal cords. The treatment is the same as juvenile papillomatosis.

Patients present with hoarseness, aphonia, dyspnea, or stridor. Laryngoscopy shows pinkish to white grape-like projections that can be sessile or pedunculate with a visible central vascular core. The diagnosis is confirmed by direct laryngoscopy and biopsy. Treatment consists of micro-laryngoscopy and CO2 laser excision.

The image below depicts laryngeal papillomatosis on laryngoscopy:

Reinke's edema (Option A) is a collection of fluid in the subepithelial space of Reinke. It generally occurs in patients with vocal abuse or smoking. The vocal cords will show diffuse, symmetrical swelling. 

The laryngoscopic image below shows Reinke's edema:

questions.text: The CT of a patient with cervical carcinoma revealed a lesion of 6 cm, extending to the upper part of the vagina and parametrium. What is the stage of the disease?
questions.solution:
The stage of cervical carcinoma is II B as it involves the upper part of the vagina and parametrium.

Related Pearl: Staging of Carcinoma Cervix

Stage I - limited to the cervix

  • A: Microscopic lesion
    • A1 - stromal invasion <3mm depth
    • A2 - a stromal invasion of ≥3 and <5mm depth
  • B: Macroscopic lesion
    • B1 - stromal invasion ≥5mm depth & tumor size <2cm 
    • B2 - tumor size ≥2cm to <4cm 
    • B3 - tumor size ≥4cm 

Stage II - involves upper 2/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to the upper two-thirds of the vagina without parametrial involvement
    • A1 - tumor size <4cm 
    • A2 - tumor size ≥4cm 
  • B: Extends to parametrium but not upto the pelvic wall.

Stage III - spreads to lower 1/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to lower 1/3 of the vagina
  • B: Extends to the pelvic wall (hydronephrosis/non-functioning kidney)
  • C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or para-aortic lymph nodes, irrespective of the tumor size and extent
    • C1: pelvic lymph node involved
    • C2: para-aortic lymph node involved

Stage IV - metastasis

  • A: Bladder/bowel involvement (adjacent pelvic organs)
  • B: Distant metastasis

Note: The involvement of vascular/lymphatic spaces does not change the staging. The lateral extent of the lesion is no longer considered.

Stage IIIB is the most common stage of presentation.

questions.text: Transport of lipid-soluble substances across the cell membrane occurs via which of the following?
questions.solution:
Lipid-soluble substances are transported across the cell membrane via diffusion.

  • The rate of diffusion depends directly on lipid solubility.
  • Characteristics of simple diffusion
    • The only form of transport that is not carrier-mediated
    • Occurs down an electrochemical gradient (“downhill”)
    • Does not require metabolic energy and therefore is passive
  • Permeability
    • Describes the ease with which a solute diffuses through a membrane
    • Depends on the characteristics of the solute and the membrane
  • Small hydrophobic solutes (e.g., O2) have the highest permeabilities in lipid membranes.
  • Hydrophilic solutes (e.g., Na+) must cross cell membranes through water-filled channels, or pores. If the solute is an ion, then its flux will depend on both the concentration difference and the potential difference across the membrane.

Related Pearl: Transport across the cell membrane

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was brought to the OPD with a painless deformity. A radiograph of the child's legs is shown below. The most common cause of this deformity is ______.
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows bow legs or genu varum which is most commonly seen in rickets. 

Rickets is a bone mineralization disorder that primarily affects children with open growth plates, resulting from a deficiency of vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate.

In toddlers, genu varum is one of the most common initial sign of rickets. In older children, genu valgum or coxa vara might be present.

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth plate is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

The below image shows bowing of legs in rickets.

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Scurvy

Radiological features of scurvy:

  • Generalised osteopenia
  • Pencil-point cortex: Cortical thinning
  • Periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • Scorbutic rosary: Expansion of the costochondral junctions
  • Hemarthrosis
  • Wimberger ring/ Wimberger sign: Circular, opaque radiological shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification, which may result from bleeding
  • Frenkel line: Dense zone of provisional calcification 
  • Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelken spur: Metaphyseal spurs which result in cupping of the metaphysis

Related Pearl: Important differences between vitamin D and vitamin C deficiencies

 
Vitamin D     deficiency  
Vitamin C     deficiency
Pathology Poor mineralization of bone Poor osteoid          formation
Clinical features

No/less irritability

Rachitic rosary (nodularity at the costochondral junction)

Irritability is predominant

Scorbutic rosary (angular & sharp costochondral junction)
Radiological features

Cupping 

Fraying

Splaying

White line of Frankel

Pelkan spur

Wimberger ring sign

Subperiosteal hemorrhage

Note: Irritability in scurvy is due to hampered neurotransmitter production (conversion of dopamine to norepinephrine and tryptophan to serotonin requires vitamin C).

questions.text: Which of the following is a mortality indicator?
questions.solution:
Life expectancy is a positive mortality indicator. 

A set of values that measure the rate of mortality or death is known as mortality indicators.

Disability-adjusted life years (DALY), health adjusted life expectancy (HALE), and Sullivan’s Index are disability rates.  

Related Pearl: Mortality and morbidity indicators in epidemiology

Mortality Indicators

Morbidity Indicators

Universal indicators:

  • Crude death rate
  • Life expectancy
  • Age-specific death rates
  • Disease-specific mortality rate
  • Proportional mortality rate
  • Case fatality rate
  • Years of potential life lost
  • Adult mortality rate

Maternal and child-related indicators:

  • Infant mortality rate
  • Child death rate
  • Under-5 proportionate mortality rate
  • Maternal mortality rate
  • Incidence and Prevalence
  • Notification rates
  • Attendance rates at OPD
  • Admission, discharge & re-admission rates
  • Duration of stay in hospital
  • Spells of sickness or absence from work or school

questions.text: Transbronchial biopsy from a patient showed the following microscopic finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image above shows alveolar spaces filled with balls of fibroblasts (Masson bodies). This is characteristically seen in cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP).

Masson bodies are polypoid plugs of loose organizing connective tissue within alveolar ducts, alveoli, and bronchioles along with foci of fibrosis.

The clinical presentation of COP is the development of nonspecific systemic and respiratory symptoms. It is associated with filling of the lung alveoli that is visible on a chest X-ray as patchy unilateral or bilateral consolidation.

COP was previously known as bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP).

questions.text: Which of the following is unlikely to be seen in individuals suffering from heat stress?
questions.solution:
Numbness is an effect of cold stress, not heat stress.

Effects of heat stress include:

  • Heatstroke
  • Heat hyperpyrexia
  • Heat exhaustion
  • Heat cramps 
  • Heat syncope

questions.text: A 24-year-old patient presents with a high-grade fever, headache, and weakness for 5 days. He gives a history of blood transfusion 4 months back. The microscopic examination of the thin blood smear is given below. What is the most probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
High-grade fever, headache, weakness and microscopy showing Maltese crosses or tetrads are suggestive of babesiosis caused by Babesia microti.

The definitive host for babesia is the ixodid tick and the reservoir hosts are wild or domesticated animals. Man is an incidental, dead-end host. It is transmitted to man through the bite of an ixodid tick or blood transfusions. Patients present with fever, malaise, headache, myalgia. 

On microscopic examination of Giemsa stained peripheral smears, babesia trophozoites appear as intraerythrocytic round or pyriform or ring forma. The ring form is the most common and it lacks the central hemozoin deposit present in P. falciparum. Other distinguishing features are the absence of schizonts and gametocytes and the presence of tetrads/Maltese crosses, which are pathognomic of B. microti. 

The below image shows Maltese cross appearance of Babesia microti.

questions.text: A 5 year old boy was suffering from low grade fever, inspiratory stridor and barking cough for past 5 days. His chest X-ray is given below. What is the cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Barking cough is a feature of laryngotracheobronchitis, which is caused by the parainfluenza virus. The X-ray finding is the 'Steeple sign' due to subglottic narrowing.

The age of presentation of laryngotracheobronchitis ranges from 6 months-6 years. The clinical features include barking cough, inspiratory stridor, hoarseness, low-grade fever.

Management:

  • Racemic epinephrine nebulization leads to the rapid improvement of upper airway obstruction. Epinephrine constricts pre-capillary arterioles in the upper airway mucosa and decreases capillary hydrostatic pressure, leading to fluid resorption and improvement in airway edema.
  • Dexamethasone-by the least invasive route (Oral>IV>IM ). It is indicated in all the grades of croup.
  • Oxygen should be administered to children who are hypoxemic (SpO2 <92 %)

Antibiotics are not indicated in laryngotracheobronchitis.

questions.text: An adolescent boy with schizophrenia had witnessed his parents fighting with each other for the past several years. He is overly close with his mother and she convinced him to take her side in the divorce. He always blamed his father for all their family problems. Which of the following best describes the abnormal family dynamics?
questions.solution:
This scenario describes an abnormal family dynamic, where one parent is overly close to the child of the opposite gender. This is known as marital schism.

Marital schism, marital skew, expressed emotions, and double-bind refer to abnormalities of family dynamics. They act as psychosocial stressors, hampering the adaptive capacity of the individual, thus contributing to the development of schizophrenia.

Marital schism- one parent is overly close to the child of the opposite gender.

Marital skew- a disharmonious situation where one parent dominates over the other.

Expressed emotions- parents or other caregivers may behave with overt criticism, hostility, or over-involvement towards a person with schizophrenia, which further worsens the illness.

Double bind- a hypothetical family in which children receive conflicting parental messages about their behavior, attitudes, and feelings.

questions.text: While on rounds in the NICU, you notice a newborn baby with a zig-zag dermatomal cicatrix on the forehead and left side of the face. The limbs are small and atrophied. Microcephaly is noted. Which maternal infection are these findings characteristically associated with?
questions.solution:
Microcephaly, limb hypoplasia and a cicatrix are suggestive of congenital varicella syndrome. Hence, these findings are associated with an antenatal history of maternal infection with varicella zoster virus (VZV) infection.

If the mother gets infected during the first half of pregnancy, fetal infection may be asymptomatic. However, some infants develop congenital varicella syndrome. Clinical features include:

  • Cicatricial skin scarring in a zigzag shape in a dermatomal distribution
  • Limb hypoplasia
  • CNS abnormalitites: Microcephaly, cortical atrophy, seizures, intellectual disability
  • Ocular abnormalities: Microphthalmia, cataracts, chorioretinitis
  • Renal abnormalities: Hydroureter, hydronephrosis

questions.text: Blood bag is to be disposed in:
questions.solution:
Blood bag should be disposed off in the yellow bin.

questions.text: On examining the oral cavity of a patient who presented with fever and a sore throat, you notice a greyish-white membrane over the tonsils. Which of the following conditions would you not consider as a differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ludwig’s angina is not associated with the formation of a grey-white membrane. It is characterized by rapidly spreading infection of the sublingual space initially and later the submaxillary space, often dentogenic in origin.

D/D for membrane over tonsil:

  • Streptococcus & other pyogenic organisms
  • Diphtheria
  • Infectious mononucleosis
  • Vincent’s angina
  • Leukemia
  • Candida
  • Agranulocytosis
  • Malignancy
  • Apthous ulcer
  • Traumatic ulcer

questions.text: A patient with a known history of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, presents to the ER with a sudden, severe headache, photophobia and nausea. What type of aneurysm would you suspect in this patient?
questions.solution:
In a patient with a known history of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, the most common type of intracranial aneurysm is saccular aneurysm. 

Although the majority occur sporadically, genetic factors may be important in their pathogenesis of saccular aneurysms. There is an increased incidence of saccular aneurysm in individuals with certain Mendelian disorders like autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, Ehlers–Danlos syndrome type IV, neurofibromatosis type 1 [NF1], and Marfan syndrome, fibromuscular dysplasia of extracranial arteries, and coarctation of the aorta. Other predisposing factors include cigarette smoking and hypertension.

The most frequent cause of clinically significant subarachnoid hemorrhage is rupture of a saccular (berry) aneurysm in a cerebral artery.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with abdominal pain, nausea, and bilious vomiting. CT scan revealed obstruction of the third part of the duodenum by a large vessel. Which of the following blood vessels is most likely to cause the compression?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of superior mesenteric artery syndrome or Wilkie syndrome. In this condition, the third part of the duodenum is compressed by the superior mesenteric artery causing bowel obstruction.

The mid-portion of the third part of the duodenum lies in the angle between the superior mesenteric artery anteriorly and the abdominal aorta posteriorly.

Parts of the duodenum and their characteristics:
