questions.text: Patients with which of the following diseases have the highest risk of developing colorectal cancer?
questions.solution: Patients with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) have the highest risk of developing colorectal cancer. 100% of untreated patients with FAP develop colorectal carcinoma, often before the age of 30 years.

questions.text: A 3-year child is brought to the pediatrician for the evaluation of the lateral neck mass. On examination, a painless, soft, fluctuating mass is found in the lateral side of the neck, as shown in the image. The slip sign is negative, and the swelling is brilliantly transilluminant. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A soft, painless, brilliantly transilluminant, fluctuating mass found in the posterior part of the neck in a child, is most likely to be a cystic hygroma.

Cystic hygroma is a lymph-filled sac that results from the obstruction of the lymph vessels during their development. It is most commonly present in the posterior triangle of the neck. The mass may be apparent at birth or may appear in early childhood due to the increased accumulation of lymph. Since the sac is filled with lymph, it is soft, fluctuating, and brilliantly transilluminant.

Treatment:

  • Aspiration of the contents, followed by excision once the sac or capsule gets thickened by fibrous tissue.
  • Single cysts can be treated with sclerosing therapy. Commonly used sclerosants include OK–432 or Picibanil, which is a mixture of group A Streptococcus pyogenes strain, pure ethanol, interferon alpha-2a, and doxycycline.
  • Complete excision is done in case of multiple cysts.

Option B: A branchial cleft cyst also presents as soft fluctuant swelling. It is present in the anterior neck and at the junction of the upper third and middle third of the sternocleidomastoid muscle.

Option C: Lipoma is less commonly seen in children. The swelling is non-fluctuant and when palpated, the edge slips under the finger. This is known as the slip sign.

Option D: Cervical lymphadenopathy is seen in children with infections of the parotid and upper respiratory tract infections. On palpation, they are firm and non-fluctuant.

questions.text: What is implied if a drug has more renal clearance than GFR?

choices.text: Drug is reabsorbed by the renal tubules
Drug is secreted in the renal tubules
Drug is excreted in renal tubules
Drug is neither excreted nor reabsorbed in renal tubules

questions.solution:
If drug has more renal clearance than GFR, then drug is secreted in renal tubules. 

Excretion rate= (filtration rate- reabsorption rate)+ secretion rate.

The clearance of the substance:

  • Equals the GFR if there is no net tubular secretion or reabsorption.
  • Exceeds the GFR if there is net tubular secretion.
  • Less than the GFR if there is net tubular reabsorption.

questions.text: Alkali disease of livestock is caused by an excess of which of the following minerals?
questions.solution:
Excess of selenium causes alkali disease in livestock.

Clinical types of selenium intoxication 

  • Acute selenosis
  • Subacute selenosis (i.e., blind staggers type)
  • Chronic selenosis (i.e., alkali disease type)

Alkali disease occurs when animals consume moderate levels of selenium for a period of weeks to months.

The common clinical signs of chronic selenosis in horses, cattle, and swine are loss of hair (horses and cattle lose long hair from the mane and tails), emaciation, hoof lesions, weight reduction, and lameness.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not an indication for functional endoscopic sinus surgery?
questions.solution:
Cavernous sinus thrombosis is not an indication for functional endoscopic sinus surgery(FESS).

Indications of FESS:

  • Chronic bacterial sinusitis unresponsive to adequate medical treatment
  • Recurrent acute bacterial sinusitis
  • Fungal sinusitis with fungal ball
  • Nasal polyps
  • Mucocele 
  • Control of epistaxis 
  • Removal of foreign body from the nose or sinus
  • Barotrauma sinusitis (pain in the face during descent in aircraft or descent whilst scuba diving)

questions.text: A patient with secondary amenorrhea and infertility is diagnosed to have Asherman syndrome. Hysteroscopic evaluation revealed 30% adhesions of the endometrial surfaces, but no agglutination of the uterine wall. How would you classify this patient?

choices.text: Cannot be classified with the given information

questions.solution:
This patient would be classified as a case of moderate Asherman syndrome as 30% adhesions of the endometrial surfaces are present.

Asherman syndrome (uterine synechiae) is classified as follows:

  • Minimal: <25% adhesion involves the uterine cavity, flimsy adhesions involving the fundus and tubal ostia.
  • Moderate: 25–70% adhesion of the endometrial surfaces, but no agglutination of the uterine wall.
  • Severe: 75% adhesions with agglutination and thick adhesions.

Asherman syndrome can present in the following ways:

  • Secondary amenorrhea
  • Oligomenorrhoea
  • Dysmenorrhoea
  • Habitual abortions
  • Infertility

The causes of Asherman syndrome are:

  • Dilatation and curettage (D&C)
  • Medical termination of pregnancy (MTP), spontaneous abortions, recurrent abortions
  • Uterine packing in postpartum haemorrhage
  • Uterine infection
  • Tubercular endometritis

questions.text: Which of the following components of the fungal cell wall is not seen in mucormycosis?
questions.solution:
Beta-(1,3)-d-glucan (BG), a common component of many pathogenic fungi is absent in Zygomycetes/ Mucormycosis. 

Fungal cell wall: 

The fungal cell wall is rigid and determines the shape of the fungi. These protect them from osmotic and environmental stresses. They are composed of glycoproteins and lipids. Some sugar polymers such as chitin, glucans, and mannans are also found in the cell wall. All these components remain cross-linked to form a multilayered cell wall matrix. They exhibit pathobiological properties and are responsible for provoking an inflammatory response during infections. These are also species-specific and release immunodominant antigens that could aid in immunological testing. In addition, some yeasts and molds are described as dematiaceous because their cell walls contain melanin which forms host defenses.

Clinical significance of Beta-1, 3-d-glucan:

G-test:

G-test is done for detection of α-3 glucan. It is helpful in establishing a diagnosis of candidiasis. 

Tests for beta-d-glucan:

The presence of an elevated level of β-d-glucan in the serum can be seen in candidiasis, aspergillosis, and pneumonia due to Pneumocystis carnii pneumonia. The same test cannot be effectively applied in the evaluation of Mucorales. This assay is also not evaluated in routine in cases of cryptococcosis, not because of the absence of BG but because the capsule captures BG even before it is released into the bloodstream.

Effectiveness of echinocandins:

Echinocandins inhibit the synthesis of glucan synthase, since there is no much of a role for beta-glucans in mucormycosis, this class of drugs is seldom effective in the management of mucormycosis. The drug of choice for the management of mucormycosis is amphotericin-B.

questions.text: In which of the following types of nerve damage would the sprouting axons form an end neuroma?
questions.solution:
Sprouting axons can form an end neuroma in neurotmesis. 

A neuroma is an overgrowth of fibrous tissue and randomly sprouting axons following nerve injury. A neuroma may form following axonotmesis and neurotmesis. In neurotmesis, neuroma does not bridge the break in continuity and is called end neuroma. In axonotmesis, the neuroma formed bridges the continuity and is called neuroma in continuity. 

Tinel's sign is used to assess nerve regeneration following injury. The nerve is percussed along its course to elicit a tingling sensation. The point of tingling marks the site of newly sprouting axons.

Related Pearl: Seddon's classification of nerve injuries

Seddon's classification includes 3 groups:

  1. Neuropraxia
  2. Axonotmesis
  3. Neurotmesis

Neuropraxia:

  • Reversible physiologic conduction block
  • Occurs due to mechanical pressure causing segmental demyelination
  • Examples: Saturday night palsy, tourniquet, and crutch palsy

Axonotmesis: 

  • Axonal interruption
  • Conduction is lost but the nerve is in continuity and neural tubes are intact
  • Examples: Closed fractures and dislocations

Neurotmesis: 

  • Division of the nerve trunk
  • Endoneurial tube destruction also occurs
  • Example: Complete section of nerve in open fractures

questions.text: A middle-aged man with a history of chronic alcohol comsuption presented to the casualty with confusion, ataxia and diplopia. What is the protocol to treat this patient?

choices.text: Thiamine injection followed by glucose infusion

questions.solution:
Diplopia, ataxia and confusion in a patient with chronic alcohol consumption  is suggestive of Wernicke's encephalopathy. The current standard of treatment for patients with symptoms of Wernicke's encephalopathy is to give thiamine 100 mg intravenously before administering glucose-containing IV fluids.

Thiamine deficiency leads to the following:

  1. Wernicke’s encephalopathy: It is more commonly seen in alcoholics with chronic thiamine deficiency. It is characterized by global confusion, truncal ataxia, ophthalmoplegia and horizontal nystagmus.
  2. Korsakoff psychosis: Symptoms in addition to those of Wernicke's encephalopathy include memory loss and confabulation
  3. Beriberi: It can be either -
    • Dry beriberi: Sensorimotor peripheral neuropathy, muscle weakness
    • Wet beriberi: Tachycardia, cardiomegaly, high-output cardiac failure

Related Pearl: Vitamin Deficiency States (Water-soluble Vitamins)

Vitamin

Deficiency State

Thiamine (B1)

Beriberi

Wernicke–Korsakoff’s syndrome

Riboflavin (B2)

Cheilosis, Magenta-coloured tongue, 

Glossitis, Seborrheic dermatitis

Niacin (B3)

Pellagra

Dermatitis, Diarrhea, Dementia

Pantothenic acid (B5)

Burning foot syndrome (historically called as "Nutritional melalgia")

Dermatitis, enteritis, alopecia, ataxia

Pyridoxine (B6)

Microcytic anemia, convulsions, depression

Biotin (B7)

Relatively unknown

Dermatitis, atrophic glossitis, alopecia, paraesthesia, muscle pain, anorexia, hallucinations

Folic acid (B9)

Megaloblastic anemia, neuropathy, neural tube defects, atrophic glossitis

Cobalamin (B12)

Pernicious anemia, dementia, spinal cord degeneration, homocysteinemia

Ascorbic acid (C)

Scurvy

Ecchymosis, bleeding gums, poor wound healing, fatigue, joint effusion, Scorbutic rosary

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman with a history of type 1 diabetes is brought to the ER with confusion, vomiting, and abdominal pain. Investigations show blood glucose of 520 mg/dl and urine positive for ketone bodies. Which of the following is the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for controlling hyperglycemia in a patient with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is short-acting insulin, preferably regular insulin.

Intermediate (such as lente insulin and NPH), long-acting insulins, and oral hypoglycemic agents are never used in the initial management of DKA. 

The mainstay of treatment is the administration of normal saline followed by infusion of short-acting insulin. The precipitating event must be identified and treated. Careful monitoring of K+ levels and replacement in the later stages is required, as insulin therapy causes hypokalemia.

questions.text: A farmer was diagnosed with brucellosis. Which of the following patterns of fever will be seen in this disease?
questions.solution:
Brucellosis is a bacterial zoonosis caused by Brucella sp which presents with undulant fever. It is referred to as undulant fever because of the rising and falling of fever like a wave (remittent fever). Patients may also have arthralgia, muscular pain, sweating, loss of weight, and appetite. CNS symptoms such as fatigue, irritability, and depression might also occur. 

Other options

Option A: Pel-Ebstein fever is seen in Hodgkin's lymphoma. It is characterized by fever lasting 3–10 days followed by afebrile periods of 3–10 days.

Option C: Relapsing fever is seen in infection with Borrelia recurrentis in which days of fever are followed by a several-day afebrile period and then relapse into additional days of fever. A similar picture is also seen in malaria.

Option D: Saddleback fever is seen in dengue.  Saddleback fever is defined as temperature >37.5°C  with defervescence of at least one day, followed by a second peak lasting at least one day.

questions.text: A patient with a suspected neurocutaneous syndrome was referred to ophthalmology. His ocular findings are given. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image given shows Lisch nodules of the iris, which is suggestive of neurofibromatosis type 1.

Neurocutaneous syndrome Ocular manifestations
Neurofibromatosis type 1
  • Eyelid plexiform neurofibroma gives a characteristic S-shaped deformity of the upper lid, and classically, it is texturally reminiscent of a "bag of worms."
  • Optic nerve glioma - A pilocytic astrocytoma that typically occurs in young children.
  • Bilateral Lisch nodules (at least 95%) are hamartomas that develop during the second–third decades.
  • Congenital ectropion uveae
  • Prominent corneal nerves
  • Congenital glaucoma
  • Spheno-orbital encephalocele - due to dysplasia of the greater wing of the sphenoid
Neurofibromatosis type 2
  • Posterior subcapsular cataract
  • Hamartomas of the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) and retina
Sturge–Weber syndrome
  • Choroidal hemangioma
  • Iris heterochromia
  • Ipsilateral glaucoma
Tuberous sclerosis
  • Atypical iris coloboma
  • Iris hypopigmentation
  • Retinal astrocytoma
von Hippel–Lindau syndrome
  • Retinal hemangiomas
  • Optic nerve haemangioma

questions.text: A 47-year-old man presented to the hospital with the findings shown in the image below. He also complained of pain in the upper and lower limbs. On examination, his BP was 160/100 mmHg and his peripheral pulses were palpable. Serology was negative for ANCA. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is polyarteritis nodosa.

The image shows the gangrene of the fingers. The presence of myalgia, the involvement of cutaneous vessels (gangrene with palpable peripheral pulses), renal vessels causing hypertension and serology negative for ANCA make polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) the most probable diagnosis.

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is necrotizing arteritis of the medium-sized blood vessels. It can affect the skin, peripheral nerves, renal vessels, mesenteric vessels, heart, and brain. Lungs are usually spared in PAN.

The disease initially starts with non-specific symptoms like fever, malaise, arthralgia, and myalgia. Later, depending on the artery involved, patients may develop the following symptoms:

  • Skin findings - ulcers, digital gangrene, and livedo reticularis
  • Renal arteries - hypertension and renal failure
  • Mesenteric arteries - abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, bleeding, and a bowel perforation

Other options:

1) Takayasu arteritis- It is a large vessel vasculitis. Also known as pulseless disease as it may be associated with weak upper extremity pulses.

2) Microscopic polyangiitis- It is a small vessel vasculitis. It is positive for p-ANCA. Presentation is similar to granulomatosis with polyangiitis but without upper airway involvement.

3) Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis- It is frequently associated with hepatitis C. Circulating cryoglubulins and rheumatoid factor can be found in blood. Most common clinical manifestations are cutaneous vasculitis, peripheral neuropathy, glomerulonephritis and arthritis.

questions.text: A child with a midline swelling on the neck is being prepared for a Sistrunk procedure. Along with en bloc cystectomy, which of the following structures will be resected?

choices.text: Thyroglossal tract and part of thyroid
Central hyoid bone and thyroglossal tract
Thyroglossal tract and associated cervical lymph nodes

questions.solution:
Sistrunk operation involves en bloc cystectomy with excision of the entire thyroglossal tract till the base of the tongue along with the central hyoid bone.

It is the procedure of choice for the surgical management of thyroglossal duct cysts. It is done to prevent recurrence and malignant transformation. 

The most common malignancy in thyroglossal cysts is papillary thyroid carcinoma. In such a case, Sistrunk operation with total thyroidectomy is considered.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is being evaluated for suspected infertility. His semen analysis shows a decrease in sperm count and motility. On physical examination, a 'bag of worms'-like structure is palpated in his scrotum, suggestive of varicocele. Which of the following is the most likely reason behind his decreased sperm count?

choices.text: Lowered scrotal temperature, compared to core temperature
Rise in scrotal temperature, compared to core temperature

questions.solution:
The most likely reason behind decreased sperm count in this patient is rise in scrotal temperature, secondary to varicocoele.

Normally, the testes occupy the scrotum, which lies outside the body cavity and is maintained at 35° to 36°C, or 1° to 2°C below body temperature. This lower temperature is essential for normal spermatogenesis. It is maintained by a countercurrent arrangement of testicular arteries and veins, which facilitates heat exchange. 

Enlarged veins around the testes, called varicoceles, cause infertility by raising the temperature in the scrotum and decreasing sperm production.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the image below.
questions.solution:
The structure marked is the lacunar ligament.

Lacunar (Gimbernat's) ligament - It is a thick triangular band of tissue formed from fibres of the medial end of the inguinal ligament and fascia lata.  It forms the medial wall of the femoral canal. The apex of the triangle is attached to the pubic tubercle.

Inguinal (Poupart’s) ligament - The thick external oblique aponeurosis stretched between ASIS (anterior superior iliac spine) and pubic tubercle. 

Pectineal (Astley-Cooper's) ligament - A strong fibrous band that extends laterally along the pectineal line from the pectineal attachment of the lacunar ligament.

Conjoint tendon - It is a condensation of tissue that runs through the lateral edge of the lower rectus sheath. It is formed from the common aponeurosis of the internal oblique muscle and transverse abdominis muscle. The fibers turn inferiorly and insert into the crest of the pubis at the pectineal line immediately deep to the superficial inguinal ring.

questions.text: A man from Chattisgarh presented with progressive muscle weakness and leg spasms. Pure motor paresis was seen on examination. What is the most appropriate history to be elicited in this patient?

choices.text: History of similar illness in the past

questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of neurolathyrism and excessive consumption of the pulse Lathyrus sativus is the main cause. Hence, a diet history should be elicited in this patient to confirm the diagnosis. 

Lathyrism is a paralyzing disease of humans and animals. It is due to the consumption of Khesari dal/Lathyrus sativus. When the husk is removed, it looks similar to red gram dal or Bengal gram dal. It is more prevalent in parts of Madhya Pradesh, Uttar Pradesh, Odisha, and Bihar.

In humans, it is referred to as neurolathyrism because it affects the nervous system. It is characterized by gradually developing spastic paralysis of the lower limbs.

In animals, it is referred to as osteolathyrism/odoratism because the pathological changes in the bones lead to skeletal deformities. 

It usually affects young males aged 15-45 years and it is manifested in stages: 

  • Latent stage
  • No-stick stage
  • One-stick stage
  • Two-stick stage
  • Crawler stage

BOAA (Beta oxalyl amino alanine) is the toxic compound causing Lathyrism. The water-soluble property of the toxin is used in removing it from the pulses by soaking it in hot water and rejecting the soaked water. 

Parboiling can be used for detoxifying the crop on large-scale operations. Overnight soaking in lime water followed by boiling is also effective in destroying the toxin.

Vitamin C in doses of 500-1000mg can be used for the prevention and treatment of lathyrism. 

The Prevention of Food Adulteration Act in India has banned Lathyrus sativus in all forms (whole/split/flour).

Related Pearl: Food adulteration diseases

questions.text: During a routine check-up of a multigravida at 32 weeks of gestation, the fetus was found to be in breech presentation. The obstetrician planned to do an external cephalic version.  What is the ideal time to do this procedure?
questions.solution:
The ideal time to do external cephalic version is 37 weeks. This procedure is attempted in a woman who has completed 36 weeks of gestation and has a breech fetal presentation.

Before 37 weeks, a breech presentation has a high likelihood of correcting spontaneously. Moreover, if performed too early, there is time to return back to breech.

After 37 weeks, the success rates of ECV are very low. Although it can be performed until the early stages of labour, it is not recommended.

questions.text: Below is an X-ray of an infant with cyanotic heart diease. Which is not a finding seen here?
questions.solution:
Cyanosis and boot-shaped heart (cœur en sabot in French) points towards tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) and the atrial septal defect is not a finding seen in TOF.

Clinical findings in TOF:

  • Right ventricular hypertrophy causing left anterior hemithorax bulge. 
  • Single S2 or soft P2 because of the stenotic pulmonary valve 
  • Systolic thrill in the left sternal border in 3rd and 4th parasternal spaces.
  • The large 'a' wave in the jugular pulse is a reflection of the forceful contraction of the right atrium at the end of diastole as there is reduced distensibility of the hypertrophic right ventricle.
  • There is a loud and harsh systolic murmur due to the right ventricular outflow tract (RVOT) obstruction. It becomes louder, longer, and harsher as obstruction increases in severity from mild to moderate. 
  • However in severe obstruction, especially during tet spell, the murmur becomes less prominent as the blood is shunted towards the aortic valve and not through RVOT. 

X-Ray in TOF showing boot shaped heart:

Acyanotic/pink tetralogy of Fallot: This occurs when obstruction to the right ventricular outflow is mild to moderate. The blood would flow more through the mildly obstructed RVOT and less through the VSD. Hence, there is less cyanosis. 

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in some congenital heart defects

Boot shaped heart - Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

Egg on string appearance - Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA)

 

Snowman's heart appearance or figure of 8 appearance - Supracardiac TAPVC

 

Box Shaped Heart - Ebstein's Anomaly

questions.text: At a waste treatment facility,  pharmaceutical waste was mixed with cement, lime, and water before disposal. What is this method known as?
questions.solution:
Inertization is the process of mixing biomedical waste with non-toxic substances to reduce the toxicity of the waste and to reduce the contamination of groundwater. It is most commonly done for incineration ash with high metal content.

The typical composition of the inertization mixture is:

  • 65% pharmaceutical waste
  • 15% cement
  • 15% lime
  • 5% water

questions.text: In which of the following diseases should active and passive immunisation not be done together?
questions.solution:
Active and passive immunization should not be done together for measles as the vaccine used is a live vaccine.

Live vaccines should generally be avoided for 12 weeks following an injection of normal human immunoglobulin (Ig). If a live vaccine has already been administered, the injection of normal human Ig should be delayed for 2 weeks.

Note: In the case of measles alone, the recommended interval between administration of Measles immunoglobulins and Live measles vaccine is about 6 months in a non-immunocompromised individual and 8 months in an immunocompromised individual.

questions.text: In a woman diagnosed with infertility, which of the following antihormonal substance can be used to induce ovulation?
questions.solution:
Clomiphene citrate is an antihormonal substance used to induce ovulation in a patient diagnosed with infertility. Ovulation can be induced by giving clomiphene citrate 50 mg daily, starting from day 2 to day 6 of the menstrual cycle for 5 days.

Related Pearl: Management of female infertility for different causes are as follows

Etiology Investigations Management  
Tubal cause
  • Hysterosalpingography or sonosalpingography
  • Falloscopy
  • Salpingography
  • Laparoscopic chromotubation
  • Laparoscopic adhesiolysis
  • Tuboplasty
  • Hysteroscopic cannulation and balloonplasty
  • If all the above procedures fail or not feasible go for IVF/GIFT 
Ovulation related           
  • Ovulation monitoring by ultrasound (BBT, BBI) And  Endometrial Biopsy for tuberculosis done    
  • If the above steps are abnormal, do a hormonal study
  • FSH, LH, Prolactin
  • E2, P level
  • Thyroid and diabetes

  • If it fails, give FSH, LH, GnRH
  • Check for a response; if there is no response do IVF Donor egg.
  • If all the above measures fail, the final option is to adopt

questions.text: A patient who was admitted for blood transfusion developed transfusion-related acute lung injury. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?

choices.text: Pre-existing lung diseases are a risk factor
Incidence with platelet transfusion is more than that with whole blood
Symptoms develop after 2 days of transfusion
Subsequent transfusions from the same donor increases the incidence

questions.solution:
Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) is sudden-onset respiratory failure that occurs during or soon after the transfusion. It occurs within 6 hours, and not after 2 days following transfusion.

TRALI is a severe fatal complication of blood transfusion. The incidence of TRALI is low (1 per 10,000 transfusions). However, it may occur more frequently in patients with preexisting lung disease.  

The pathogenesis involves a two-hit hypothesis:

  • Priming event - increased sequestration and sensitization of neutrophils in the microvasculature of the lung
  • Second hit - the factor (most commonly MHC class I antigens) present in the transfused blood product activates the primed neutrophils

TRALI can occur in transfusions with all plasma-containing blood products. However, it is more likely to occur following the transfusion of fresh frozen plasma and platelets. This is because these products contain high levels of donor antibodies.  

Note: TRALI is important to recognize because donor products that induce complications in one patient are much more likely to do so in a second. Indeed, recent measures to exclude multiparous women from plasma donation have resulted in reduced incidence of TRALI.

questions.text: During the examination of a neonate with documented hearing defects and bilateral zonular cataracts, you hear a continuous machinery murmur. The mother gives a history of viral exanthem during the first trimester of the pregnancy. By when should the underlying defective channel that is responsible for the murmur anatomically close?
questions.solution:
The given vignette is suggestive of Patent ductus arteriosus in a child with congenital rubella syndrome. The anatomical closure of the ductus arteriosus occurs at 10-21 days.

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is the most common congenital heart disease associated with rubella, followed by pulmonary artery stenosis (PS). PDA presents with a continuous machinery murmur.

Triad of congenital rubella syndrome

  • Sensorineural deafness
  • Congenital heart defects – MC is PDA
  • Cataracts

Classical rubella syndrome consists of:

  • Ocular defects: Congenital cataract, salt and pepper chorioretinopathy, microphthalmos, Glaucoma, and anterior uveitis
  • Ear defects: Sensorineural hearing loss due to destruction of organ of Corti
  • Heart defects: Patent ductus arteriosus, pulmonary stenosis, and ventricular septal defects
 Fetal circulatory adjustment  Functional closure Anatomical closure
Ductus venosus After removal of the placenta from fetal circulatory unit 7 days 

Foramen ovale

At birth - after breathing is initiated

 Months to years 
Ductus arteriosus 10–15 hours  10–21 days 

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text:
Choose the parameters used to stage colorectal carcinoma according to Duke's classification ?

1. Lymph node involvement

2. Site of the tumor

3. Size of the tumor 

4. Depth of the tumor

5. Age of the patient
questions.solution:
Duke’s classification is based on the depth of tumor and lymph node status.

Related Pearl: Dukes’ staging for colorectal cancer

  • Stage A - Invasion of but not breaching the muscularis propria
  • Stage B - Breaching the muscularis propria but not involving lymph nodes
  • Stage C - Lymph nodes involved

Dukes himself never described a stage D, but this is often used to describe metastatic disease

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman was rushed to the ER with chest pain, palpitations, and sweating. On examination, her respiratory rate was 32/min, and carpopedal spasm was noted while measuring BP. Her ECG was normal. Which of the following acid-base disorders is she likely to have?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of a panic attack. The patient is likely to have respiratory alkalosis. 

Panic attacks are characterized by hyperventilation which leads to a washout of CO2 (reduced PaCO2). This further increases the ratio of bicarbonate concentration to PaCO2 and, thereby, increases the pH level causing alkalosis. 

Alkalosis promotes the binding of calcium to albumin and reduces the fraction of ionized calcium in the blood. This leads to hypocalcemia without reducing the total calcium levels. Thus, alkalosis can precipitate tetany and laryngospasm, especially in calcium-deficient patients. 

Induction of carpopedal spasm when the BP cuff is inflated 20 mm Hg over the systolic BP for three minutes or more is called Trousseau sign. It is a clinical manifestation of hypocalcemia. 

Causes of respiratory alkalosis:

  • Central nervous system stimulation:
    • Pain
    • Anxiety, psychosis
    • Fever
    • Cerebrovascular accident
    • meningitis, encephalitis
    • Tumor
    • Trauma
  • Hypoxemia or tissue hypoxia:
    • High altitude
    • Pneumonia, pulmonary edema
    • Aspiration
    • Severe anemia
  • Drugs or hormones:
    • Pregnancy
    • Salicylates
    • Cardiac failure
  • Stimulation of chest receptors:
    • Hemothorax
    • Flail chest
    • Cardiac failure
    • Pulmonary embolism
  • Miscellaneous:
    • Septicemia
    • Hepatic failure
    • Mechanical hyperventilation
    • Heat exposure
    • Recovery from metabolic acidosis

Note: While metabolic alkalosis can also cause hypocalcemia, the above scenario of hyperventilation is more suggestive of respiratory alkalosis. Furthermore, hypocalcemic symptoms are more common with respiratory alkalosis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient with chronic constipation is diagnosed with Type 7 Gilbert hernia. This refers to ______
questions.solution:
Femoral hernia is classified under type 7 Gilbert hernia.

As per Nyhus classification system, femoral hernia is classified under type 3C.

Related Pearl: Modified Gilbert's classification of hernia

Type 1 Indirect hernia with peritoneal sac passing through an intact internal ring that will not admit 1 fingerbreadth (ie,<1 cm.); the posterior wall is intact.

Type 2 Indirect hernia (the most common indirect hernia) with peritoneal sac coming through a 1-fingerbreadth internal ring (ie, ≤2 cm.); the posterior wall is intact.

Type 3 Indirect hernia with peritoneal sac coming through a 2-fingerbreadth or wider internal ring (ie, >2 cm.).They are frequently complete and often have a sliding component. They begin to break down a portion of the posterior wall just medial to the internal ring.

Type 4 Direct hernia with full floor posterior wall breakdown or multiple defects in the posterior wall. The internal ring is intact, and there is no peritoneal sac.

Type 5 Direct hernia with a diverticular defect. There is no peritoneal sac and the internal ring remains intact.

Type 6 Both direct and indirect inguinal hernia (a pantaloon hernia)

Type 7  Femoral hernia.

Related Pearl: Nyhus classification of groin hernia

  • Type I - Indirect inguinal hernia: internal inguinal ring normal (e.g., pediatric hernia)
  • Type II - Indirect inguinal hernia: internal inguinal ring dilated but posterior inguinal wall intact; inferior deep epigastric vessels not displaced
  • Type III - Posterior wall defect
    • A- Direct inguinal hernia
    • B - Indirect inguinal hernia: internal inguinal ring dilated, medially encroaching on or destroying the transversalis fascia of Hesselbach triangle (e.g., scrotal, sliding, or pantaloon hernia)
    • C - Femoral hernia
  • Type IV - Recurrent hernia
    • A - Direct
    • B - Indirect
    • C - Femoral
    • D - Combined

questions.text:
For which of the following would you use the instrument shown in the image?
  1. To hold the fundus of the gall bladder 
  2. To hold a mass of hemorrhoids 
  3. To hold the cervix 
  4. To grasp the products of conception
  5. To hold the spermatic cords
questions.solution:
The image shows a sponge holding forceps. It is used to:

  • Clean skin with a swab dipped in antiseptic solution during all operations
  • Remove laminated membrane and daughter cysts during operation of hydatid cyst.
  • Hold the fundus and Hartmann’s pouch of gall bladder during cholecystectomy
  • Swab an abscess cavity
  • Hold the cervix during cerclage.

Ovum forceps is shown below. It is used to grasp products of conception and prevent the crushing of the conceptus. They have no catch and the blades are slightly bent and fenestrated. The absence of catch minimizes uterine injury if accidentally caught.

It is introduced with the blades closed and opened up inside the uterine cavity to grasp the products. The instrument is taken out with a slight rotatory movement. The rotatory movement not only facilitates detachment of the products from the uterine wall, but also minimizes the injury of the uterine wall if accidentally grasped.

Pile holding forceps are used to hold haemorrhoids.

Cord holding forceps are typically used to hold spermatic cords.

questions.text: A  newborn had hypoplasia of the mandibles and zygomatic bones, malformed external ears, and slanted palpebral fissures. Abnormality in the development of which of the following pharyngeal arches will most likely​ lead to the given condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of Treacher Collins syndrome that results from abnormal development of the 1st pharyngeal arch (mandibular arch). 

First arch syndromes are congenital defects caused due to the failure of the neural crest cells to migrate into the 1st pharyngeal arch. They are:

  • Treacher-Collins syndrome (mandibulofacial dysostosis) - Autosomal dominant genetic disorder characterized by:
    • Craniofacial bone defects - Involves mandible (causing micrognathia), maxilla, and zygomatic arches
    • Ear defects - Involves the external ear, atresia of auditory canals, and abnormalities of the middle ear ossicles leading to bilateral conductive hearing loss
    • Eye defects - Down-slanting palpebral fissures and lower eyelid colobomas
  • Pierre Robin sequence (or Robin sequence) - Caused due to genetic defects or due to environmental factors. It can also be seen in oligohydramnios when the chin gets compressed against the chest in utero. 
    • It is characterized by a triad of micrognathia, glossoptosis (posteriorly placed tongue), and cleft palate
    • The primary defect is poor growth of the mandible (micrognathia)
    • As a consequence of this, the tongue is posteriorly placed (glossoptosis)
    • Additionally, the tongue remains in between the palatal shelves and they fail to fuse (cleft palate)

questions.text: A trial is being conducted to determine the efficacy of a myofilament calcium sensitizer in patients with heart failure. Which among the following is the drug likely being studied?
questions.solution:
Levosimendan is a myofilament calcium senstizer. 

Calcium sensitizers bind and induce a conformational change in thin-filament regulatory protein troponin C. Thus increasing the sensitivity of contractile myofilaments to calcium. The result is an increased force of contraction for a given cytosolic calcium concentration. 

Option B: Omapatrilat is a dual ACE and neprilysin inhibitor that failed clinical trials due to increased risk of angioedema. 

Option C: Sacubitril is a neprilysin inhibitor approved in combination with valsartan for CHF. 

Option D: Enoximone is a PDE-3 inhibitor.

Drugs used for rapid symptom relief

Bumetanide

Furosemide

Torasemide

Morphine Opioid - to calm the patient and decreases cardiac O2 consumption
 
Drugs used in chronic heart failure:
Drugs Uses

ARBs Used in case of intolerance to ACE inhibitors

questions.text:
Match the images shown with the refractive errors they represent.
Image Refractive error
1 a. Mixed astigmatism
2 b. Simple myopic astigmatism
3 c. Compound myopic astigmatism
4 d. Simple hypermetropic astigmatism
  e. Compound hypermetropic astigmatism
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1 - d, 2 - b, 3 - c, 4 - a. 

Image Refractive error
1 d. Simple hypermetropic astigmatism
2 b. Simple myopic astigmatism
3 c. Compound myopic astigmatism
4 a. Mixed astigmatism

Astigmatism is a refractive error in which the rays of light entering the eye are refracted differently in different meridia of the eye. Meridia of the eye correspond to the lines of longitude on a globe. There are two types of astigmatism - regular and irregular.

In regular astigmatism, refractive power changes uniformly from one meridian to another. Thus, two principal meridia are present. The rays of light from infinity form two focal points due to the difference in curvature of the two principal meridia. Based on the relation of the two focal points to the retina, regular astigmatism has the following types:

  1. Simple astigmatism: One focal point lies on the retina. In simple myopic type, the second focal point lies in front of the retina while in simple hypermetropic type, the second focal point lies behind the retina.
  2. Compound astigmatism: In compound hypermetropic type, both focal points lie behind the retina. In compound myopic type, both focal points lie in front of the retina. 
  3. Mixed astigmatism: One focal point lies in front of while the second focal point lies behind the retina.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the OPD with complaints of bluish discoloration of the skin on the sun-exposed areas. He has been on medication for monomorphic ventricular tachycardia for the past 3 years. Which drug is most likely implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The scenario is suggestive of blue man syndrome which is most likely caused by amiodarone.

One of the side effects of amiodarone is photosensitivity. In some cases, bluish discoloration of the skin is seen, predominantly in the sun-exposed areas. This could be due to the immune response in dermal layers by amiodarone or the accumulation of amiodarone in superficial layers of skin.

The symptoms are reversible on drug discontinuation. The syndrome is related to both dose and photosensitivity.

The side effects of amiodarone include:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis
  • Hypotension, depressed ventricular function
  • Torsades de pointes
  • Corneal microdeposits
  • Hepatotoxicity
  • Neuropathies
  • Photosensitivity
  • Thyroid dysfunction

Other such syndromes associated with drugs are:

  • Red man syndrome - Vancomycin
  • Gray baby syndrome - Chloramphenicol

questions.text: The given life cycle belongs to which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
The given life cycle belongs to Trypanosoma cruzi.

T. cruzi is the causative organism of Chagas disease or South American trypanosomiasis. They are intracellular parasites. It passes its life cycle in two hosts- the definitive host is the man, and the intermediate host (vector) is a reduviid bug or triatomine bugs.

Metacyclic trypomastigotes are the infective forms to the man that are found in feces of reduviid bugs. Transmission occurs when mucus membranes, conjunctiva, or wounds on the surface of the skin are contaminated by feces of the bug.

Inside the definitive host, the trypomastigotes differentiate into intracellular amastigotes. The amastigotes multiply by binary fission and differentiate into trypomastigotes, which are then released into the bloodstream. These are the infective stages for the triatomine bug. No multiplication occurs in this stage. Inside the triatomine bug, the trypomastigotes are transformed into epimastigotes and then into metacyclic trypomastigotes in the hindgu,t which are excreted in feces.

Note: Amastigote forms resemble the Leishmania species; hence, they are frequently known as Leishmanial forms. They are found in muscular tissue, nervous tissue, andthe  reticuloendothelial system.

questions.text: A 4-year-old unimmunized child presents with whooping cough. Which of the following constituents of the causative organism is responsible for facilitating its adhesion to the respiratory epithelium?
questions.solution:
Whooping cough is caused by Bordetella pertussis. Filamentous hemagglutinin (FHA) is responsible for facilitating the adhesion of Bordetella pertussis to the respiratory epithelium.

Bordetella pertussis produces 3 hemagglutinins: Pertussis toxin (PT), lipid factor and FHA. FHA is a surface protein and is readily shed. Along with fimbrae, it helps in the adhesion of B. pertussis to the cilia of the respiratory epithelium and to erythrocytes. FHA and PT also promote secondary infection by coating other bacteria such as Haemophilus influenzae and Pneumococci. They then assists their binding to respiratory epithelium. This phenomenon has been termed 'piracy of adhesins'.

questions.text: A patient on digoxin, potassium chloride, clarithromycin, atenolol, and triamterene developed atrial fibrillation with controlled ventricular rate. Serum digoxin levels were raised. Which of his medications is responsible for the same?
questions.solution:
Elevated serum digoxin levels and the development of atrial fibrillation with controlled ventricular rate are suggestive of digoxin toxicity. Clarithromycin when given along with digoxin can cause digoxin toxicity.

P-glycoprotein pumps play a major role in the elimination of digoxin. Drugs that inhibit P-glycoprotein can thereby decrease the elimination of digoxin and lead to digoxin toxicity. Macrolide antibiotics like clarithromycin and erythromycin are inhibitors of the P-glycoprotein. So clarithromycin when given along with digoxin can cause digoxin toxicity.

Other drugs that inhibit P-glycoprotein are - Amiodarone, quinidine, verapamil, diltiazem, cyclosporine, itraconazole, propafenone, and flecainide.

Digoxin is one of the cardiac glycosides which is derived from the digitalis plant and used clinically.

It inhibits Na+/K+ ATPase, a membrane-bound transporter to increase intracellular sodium. As a result, there is less expulsion of calcium from the cell by sodium-calcium exchanger (NCX). Increased calcium inside the myocyte leads to an increase in cardiac contractility.

The most common cardiac manifestations of digitalis toxicity include atrioventricular junctional rhythm, premature ventricular depolarizations, ventricular bigeminy, ventricular tachycardia, and second-degree AV blockade.

Factors that increase the risk of digoxin toxicity are:

  • Hypercalcemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypokalemia- It increases the binding of the digoxin to the Na+/K+ ATPase pump. 
  • Drugs causing hypokalemia- loop and thiazide diuretics, amphotericin B, corticosteroids
  • Drugs that decrease digoxin elimination (inhibitors of P-glycoprotein)
  • Renal failure
  • Hypothyroidism

 Triamterene, atenolol, and potassium chloride cause hyperkalemia, and therefore do not cause digoxin toxicity.

questions.text: A pathology resident notes flask-shaped ulcers in an intestinal biopsy sample. This is characteristic of infections caused by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Flask-shaped ulcers are characteristic of amoebiasis, which is caused by Entamoeba histolytica. 

It most often affects the cecum and ascending colon. Parasites may also penetrate splanchnic vessels and embolize to the liver to produce amoebic liver abscesses. 

Image showing flask-shaped ulcers of amoebiasis:

Option A: In TB, ulcers are perpendicular to the axis of the intestine (transverse ulcers).

Option B: In typhoid, ulcers are oriented along the axis of the intestine (longitudinal ulcers).

Option C: Ulceration is not a feature of giardiasis.

questions.text: A patient presents to your clinic with the following deformity. In which of the following conditions is this deformity seen?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a swan-neck deformity seen in a patient with established rheumatoid arthritis(RA). Swan-neck deformity is hyperextension at the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint and flexion at the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint.


Some of the other small joint deformities of the hand in a patient with RA include:


Boutonnière deformity with flexion at the PIP joint and hyperextension at the DIP joint. 


Z-line deformity with hyperextension at the DIP joint and subluxation of the 1st metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint.

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. 

 

Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Z line deformity: Radial deviation of the wrist with ulnar deviation of digits. 

Eversion at hindfoot (subtalar joint), hallux valgus (shown below), hammertoe.

Windswept deformities of toes - Valgus deformities of toes in one foot and varus in the other foot. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an early sign of malignant hyperthermia?
questions.solution:
Hyperthermia is a late sign of malignant hyperthermia.

Clinical Manifestations of Malignant Hyperthermia:

Early Signs:

  • Elevated end-tidal carbon dioxide
  • Tachypnea and/or tachycardia
  • Masseter spasm, if succinylcholine has been used
  • Generalized muscle rigidity
  • Mixed metabolic and respiratory acidosis
  • Profuse sweating
  • Mottling of skin
  • Cardiac arrhythmias
  • Unstable blood pressure

Late Signs

  • Hyperkalemia
  • Rapid increase of core body temperature- body temperature rises by 1°C every 5 minutes
  • Elevated creatine phosphokinase levels
  • Gross myoglobinemia and myoglobinuria
  • Cardiac arrest
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding tracking of blood pressure?

choices.text: BP increases with age in all individuals
BP falls steadily in the elderly
Hypertensive children become hypotensive as they grow
BP of hypotensive children tends to remain low in adult life

questions.solution:
If the blood pressure of individuals is followed up over years from early childhood to adult life, low blood pressures tend to remain low and high blood pressures become higher as the individuals grow older. This phenomenon of persistence of the rank order of blood pressure is described as tracking.

This is helpful in identifying children and adolescents who are at risk of developing hypertension in the future.

Although blood pressure is known to increase with age in both sexes, some communities have been identified whose mean blood pressure does not rise with age. This is because their salt intake and calorie consumption are at a subsistence level.

questions.text: Identify the pathology in the below image.
questions.solution:
The image depicts a bacterial corneal ulcer with hypopyon.

Hypopyon in a bacterial ulcer:

  • It is due to the outpouring of leucocytes from the vessels and their gravitation to the bottom of the anterior chamber to form a hypopyon.
  • Sterile: Consists of leucocytes
  • Mobile

questions.text: Which of the following is false about scurvy?

choices.text: The beading on ribs is non-tender and round
There is impaired formation of mature connective tissue

questions.solution:
The beading of ribs in scurvy is sharp and tender.

A deficiency state of vitamin C results in scurvy. The clinical features are:

  • Fatigue, irritability, loss of appetite
  • Loose and spongy gums along with loose teeth
  • Swollen joints
  • Perifollicular hemorrhages
  • Bleeding into the skin - ecchymosis, purpura, petechiae
  • Pseudoparalysis
  • Microcytic anemia (due to decreased absorption of iron from the intestine)
  • Scorbutic rosary - sharp, tender beading at the costochondral junctions.

Many of the deficiency symptoms can be attributed to deficient collagen synthesis caused due to an inability to hydroxylate the prolyl and lysyl residues of collagen.

Related Pearl: Vitamin Deficiency States (Water-soluble Vitamins)

Vitamin

Deficiency State

Thiamine (B1)

Beriberi

Wernicke–Korsakoff’s syndrome

Riboflavin (B2)

Cheilosis, Magenta-coloured tongue, 

Glossitis, Seborrheic dermatitis

Niacin (B3)

Pellagra

Dermatitis, Diarrhea, Dementia

Pantothenic acid (B5)

Burning foot syndrome (historically called as "Nutritional melalgia")

Dermatitis, enteritis, alopecia, ataxia

Pyridoxine (B6)

Microcytic anemia, convulsions, depression

Biotin (B7)

Relatively unknown

Dermatitis, atrophic glossitis, alopecia, paraesthesia, muscle pain, anorexia, hallucinations

Folic acid (B9)

Megaloblastic anemia, neuropathy, neural tube defects, atrophic glossitis

Cobalamin (B12)

Pernicious anemia, dementia, spinal cord degeneration, homocysteinemia

Ascorbic acid (C)

Scurvy

Ecchymosis, bleeding gums, poor wound healing, fatigue, joint effusion, Scorbutic rosary

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Scurvy

Radiological features of scurvy:

  • Generalised osteopenia
  • Pencil-point cortex: Cortical thinning
  • Periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • Scorbutic rosary: Expansion of the costochondral junctions
  • Hemarthrosis
  • Wimberger ring/ Wimberger sign: Circular, opaque radiological shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification, which may result from bleeding
  • Frenkel line: Dense zone of provisional calcification 
  • Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelken spur: Metaphyseal spurs which result in cupping of the metaphysis

questions.text: Visual field examination of a 52-year-old stroke patient reveals the finding shown in the image. During examination, you notice that he is not able to comprehend your instructions and sometimes gives irrelevant replies. What is the likely site of arterial occlusion?

choices.text: Left M2 segment of MCA – inferior division
Right M2 segment of MCA – superior division

questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of homonymous right superior quadrantanopia (pie in the sky appearance) and sensory aphasia. These are seen in occlusion of the inferior division of the opposite side middle cerebral artery (MCA).

Parts of the middle cerebral artery:

  • The MCA originates from the internal carotid artery. The stem of the MCA is referred to as the M1 segment.
  • In the Sylvian fissure, the MCA divides into superior and inferior divisions. These branches are referred to as the M2 segments of the MCA.

Occlusion of the following sites and their effects are given below:

  • MCA stem (M1) - leads to contralateral hemiplegia, hemianesthesia and homonymous hemianopia amongst other features
  • Superior division of MCA (M2) on the dominant side - leads to motor aphasia (Broca's) and facio-brachial weakness
  • Inferior division of MCA (M2) on the dominant side - leads to sensory aphasia (Wernicke's) and contralateral superior quadrantanopia

The following image of coronal section of cerebral hemisphere shows the segments of MCA:

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady who was a victim of rape was brought by the lady constable to the gynecologist for examination. During the genital examination, the doctor obtained a sample from in and around the vagina. What test needs to be done on this sample to identify the presence of semen?
questions.solution:
The acid phosphatase test is used to identify seminal stains.

The prostatic secretion contains acid phosphatase. Semen recovered from the vagina retains acid phosphatase concentrations up to 36 hours after its deposition. It is expressed in Bodansky units. The acid phosphatase test is conclusive in case of the absence of demonstrable sperms or aspermia. 

The absolute proof of semen is finding at least one unbroken spermatozoon or electrophoretic LDH isoenzyme detection of sperms.

Related Pearl: Tests to detect seminal and blood stains

Tests for seminal stains

  • Barberio's test
  • Florence test
  • Acid phosphatase test
  • Creatine phosphokinase test
  • Immunological test to detect Prostate Specific Antigen

Tests for blood stains  

  • Benzidine test
  • Phenophthalein (Kastle Meyer) test
  • Takayama hemochromogen crystal test
  • Teichmann’s hemin crystal test
  • Spectroscopic test

questions.text: A mother is concerned about her 3-week-old baby having yellowish discolouration of skin and eyes. On examination, the baby is chubby and playful. Stools are pale in color. Further evaluation with USG shows triangular cord sign and liver biopsy shows bile duct proliferation. The most likely diagnosis is ______.
questions.solution:
Neonatal jaundice in a neonate without a sick-looking appearance and with acholic stools, USG showing triangular cord sign, and liver biopsy showing bile duct proliferation is suggestive of biliary obstruction, which may be seen in biliary atresia.

Wilson disease and Hallervorden Spatz disease (neurodegeneration with iron accumulation in the brain) do not present with jaundice in the neonatal stage. Hence, they can be excluded.

Differentiation between neonatal hepatitis and EHBA

Neonatal hepatitis  Extrahepatic biliary atresia (EHBA) 

It implies intrahepatic cholestasis which includes:

Hepatic injury due to metabolic, viral, or idiopathic cause

Intrahepatic bile duct injury

Obliteration of the entire extrahepatic biliary tree at or above the porta hepatis(85% cases)  OR

Distal segmental bile duct obliteration with patent
extrahepatic ducts up to the porta hepatis (uncommon)
 Clinical features 

Family history is present

Premature or LBW baby

Pigmented stools 

Family history absent

Normal appearance, without looking sick

Persistent acholic stools 

Investigations
Liver biopsy: Loss of liver architecture 

USG: triangular cord sign

HIDA scan: screening test 

Liver biopsy: bile duct proliferation 

Liver biospy:

  • Biliary atresia is characterized by proliferation of the bile ductule, presence of bile plugs, and portal or perilobular edema and fibrosis, with the basic hepatic lobular architecture intact.
  • In neonatal hepatitis, there is severe, diffuse hepatocellular disease, with distortion of lobular architecture, marked infiltration of inflammatory cells, and focal hepatocellular necrosis.

questions.text:
In which of the following conditions do secondary sexual characters appear to be normal?
  1. Resistant ovary syndrome
  2. Androgen insensitivity syndrome
  3. Mayer–Rokitansky–Küster–Hauser syndrome
  4. Imperforate hymen
  5. Transverse vaginal septum
questions.solution:
Secondary sexual characters appear normal in the following:

  • Imperforate hymen
  • Transverse vaginal septum
  • Absent vagina and functioning uterus 
  • Absent vagina and nonfunctioning uterus - Mayer–Rokitansky–Küster–Hauser syndrome [MRKH]
  • Resistant ovary syndrome

In androgen insensitivity syndrome, secondary sexual characteristics may or may not develop normally. The genotype is XY, however a female phenotype develops. These patients have well-developed breasts, but they have scanty body hair. This is because growth of sexual hair is only mediated via androgens. Thus, secondary sexual characters cannot be considered normal.

questions.text: A farmer who works in paddy fields presented with fever, intense myalgia, and hematochezia. Lab investigations showed sharply elevated creatinine levels and liver enzymes. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario  of a farmer who works in close contact with water and fever and myalgia with deranged liver and renal profiles suggests a diagnosis of Weil's disease which is caused by Leptospira interrogans.

Long hours of working in a field with water (paddy field), is a high-risk factor for the development of leptospirosis. 

Weil’s syndrome is the severe form of leptospirosis that encompasses the triad of hemorrhage, jaundice, and acute kidney injury.

The treatment of choice is IV penicillin or IV ceftriaxone.

questions.text: A patient who is on anti-glaucoma therapy presents with corneal findings as shown in the image below. This finding is most commonly observed with which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
The bilateral whorl-like pattern of cream-colored lines on the cornea seen in the image is called cornea verticillata or vortex keratopathy. It is observed with the use of netarsudil. It is usually mild and reversible and not associated with any significant visual abnormalities. 

Netarsudil is approved for lowering intraocular pressure in patients with open-angle glaucoma or ocular hypertension.

Other causes of corneal verticillata are: 

  • Fabry’s disease
  • Amiodarone
  • Chloroquine
  • Hydroxychloroquine
  • Indomethacin
  • Phenothiazines.

questions.text: The following image depicts:
questions.solution:
The given image shows raised, brownish thread-like lesions in the interdigital distribution (burrows), typically seen in scabies.

Scabies is an ectoparasitic infection caused in humans by Sarcoptes scabiei. It is transmitted by close personal contact. Pruritis with nocturnal exacerbation and contact cases within a family should raise the suspicion of scabies. Typical locations of lesions are the finger webs, the flexor surfaces of the wrists, the elbows, the axillae, the buttocks and genitalia and the breasts of women (Circle of Hebra). In adults, the face is often spared. Pruritic papules and nodules on male genitalia and breasts serve as valuable diagnostic clues in the absence of burrows. 

Dermoscopy of the burrows shows jet‐with‐contrail appearance. Microscopy of scraping from burrows can be done to demonstrate mites.

A single overnight application of 5% permethrin cream from neck to toe in adults and from head to toe in children is the drug of choice for the treatment of scabies in all ages including infants (at least 2 months old) and pregnant women. All family members, even if asymptomatic, need to be treated simultaneously for this condition to prevent reinfection. Oral ivermectin can also be used.

questions.text: Which of the following is used for the classification of the endoscopic appearance of bleeding peptic ulcers in a patient with peptic ulcer disease?
questions.solution:
Forrest classification is used for classifying the endoscopic appearance of bleeding peptic ulcers. It stratifies the risk of rebleeding based on observed stigmata of recent hemorrhage. 

Stigmata of Recent Hemorrhage

Forrest Classification

Active Spurting

I A

Active Oozing

I B

Non-bleeding vessel

II A

Adherent Clot

II B

Flat Pigmented Spot

II C

Clean Based Ulcer

III

Forrest classification is clinically very significant as it provides prognostic information to the surgeon about the need for endoscopic therapeutic intervention and the risk of rebleeding.

Option B: The Glasgow–Blatchford bleeding score (GBS) is a screening tool to assess the likelihood that a patient with acute upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB) will need medical intervention such as a blood transfusion or endoscopic intervention. It incorporates the patient’s blood urea level, hemoglobin level, blood pressure, and other clinical parameters.

Option C: Rockall score assesses the risk of rebleeding and in-hospital mortality in patients with an upper GI bleed.

Option D: The Bismuth–Corlette classification system provides an anatomic description of the tumor location and longitudinal extension in the biliary tree.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with acute pain in the chest which radiates to the interscapular region of the back. He is a known hypertensive for the past 7 years. His CT is shown below. Which of the following statements regarding the condition is false?

choices.text: Men are affected more than women
In Stanford type B ascending aorta is affected
Pleural effusion associated with aortic dissection is usually left sided
Sensitivity of transthoracic echocardiography in diagnosing proximal ascending aortic dissections is higher

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the CT image showing the double-lumen of the aorta are suggestive of aortic dissection. Stanford type A is when ascending aorta and arch are affected while Stanford Type B involves descending aorta only, commencing after the origin of the left subclavian artery.

Aortic dissection occurs when a defect or flap occurs in the intima of the aorta. Predisposing factors include increasing age, hypertension, Marfan syndrome.

The most typical presentation of aortic dissection is a tearing interscapular pain. Aortic dissection affects men more than women by a ratio of 2:1. Pleural effusion associated with aortic dissection is usually left-sided.

Transthoracic echocardiography has an overall sensitivity of 60–85% for aortic dissection. For diagnosing proximal ascending aortic dissections, its sensitivity exceeds 80%. It is less useful for detecting dissection of the arch and descending thoracic aorta.

questions.text: A woman who had delivered a healthy baby 3 weeks ago was brought to the psychiatry OPD. She intently stares at you and says that her baby was stolen from the womb by her sister. On examination she has labile mood, and is mumbling to herself. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
From the given clinical scenario the patient is showing features of postpartum psychosis (depression with psychotic features). It can often begin within a few days following delivery, although the mean time of onset is usually within 2 to 4 weeks of delivery. 

Characteristically, the patient begins to complain of fatigue, episodes of tearfulness, and emotional lability. Later develops, suspiciousness, confusion, irrational statements, and obsessive concerns about the baby's health and welfare may be present. Patients eventually develop delusions that involve the idea that the baby is dead or defective. Hallucinations if present may involve voices telling the patient to harm the baby or herself. 

Related Pearl: Postpartum mood disorders

Disorders and features Incidence and timeline Harmful thoughts Treatment

Postpartum blues:

Depressed affect, tearfulness and fatigue

30-75%

Starts 2-3 days after delivery. Resolves within 10 days.

 No thoughts of harming the baby Support and follow up

Postpartum depression:

Depressed affect, anxiety, and poor concentration

10-15%

Starts within 4 weeks from delivery (DSM 5) or 6 weeks (ICD 11) and persists for ≥ 2 weeks. 

 Thoughts of harming the baby often present CBT and SSRIs 

Postpartum psychosis:

Mood-congruent delusions, hallucinations

0.1-0.2%

Onset within 4 weeks postpartum (DSM 5) or 6 weeks (ICD 11)

 Thoughts of harming the baby or self Hospitalization, atypical antipsychotics and ECT for refractory cases

Note: Zuranolone is the first-ever oral drug to be FDA-approved specifically for the treatment of postpartum depression. It is a neuroactive steroid that enhances the action of GABA in the brain and regulates mood.

questions.text: Capitonnage is used in the treatment of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Capitonnage is used in the treatment of hydatid cyst disease. It is the spiral suturing of the cavity upward from the base of the cavity to the edge of the cyst wall.

Pyogenic liver abscess is treated with antibiotics and percutaneous drainage.

Hepatic tuberculosis is treated with quadruple therapy (isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol)

questions.text: The following test was performed with blood sample from a patient with anaemia. What is this test used for?
questions.solution:
The given image shows NESTROFT i.e. Naked Eye Single Tube Red cell Osmotic Fragility test. It is a very useful screening tool for thalassemia, particularly in poor resource settings.

The principle is based on the decreased osmotic fragility of red cells in thalassemia. It is performed as follows:

  1. Mix EDTA blood and 0.36% buffered saline solution.
  2. Shake the tube and leave it at room temperature for 30 minutes.
  3. Shake the tube again and immediately hold the tube in front of a piece of paper with text or lines.
NESTROFT Inference Reason
Lines visible (negative) Normal Hemolysis has occurred
Lines not seen (positive) Thalassemia Stable RBC, unable to lyse

The image given below shows the NESTROFT.

questions.text: A patient presented to the gynecology OPD with the following finding. Which structure in men is homologous to the affected structure?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Bartholin's cyst, which involves the Bartholin's glands. These glands are homologous to the male bulbourethral or Cowper glands.

The ducts of Bartholin's glands open in the groove between the hymen and the labia minora at approximately 5 and 7 o’clock positions. They are stimulated by sexual arousal. The glands contain columnar cells that secrete mucus with lubricant properties. Contraction of the bulbospongiosus muscle expresses gland secretions.

Bartholin's cyst occurs due to obstruction of the ducts of the Bartholin's glands by proteinaceous material, or due to infection. Symptomatic or recurrent cysts may require marsupialization or gland excision. An infected Bartholin's cyst can lead to an Bartholin's abscess. This requires surgical drainage.

questions.text: What is the minimum amount of proteinuria required to diagnose a patient with nephrotic syndrome?
questions.solution:
The minimum amount of proteinuria required to diagnose a patient with nephrotic syndrome is 3.5 g/day. 

Related Pearl: Nephrotic and nephritic syndromes

 

Nephrotic Syndrome

Nephritic Syndrome (Glomerulonephritis)

Primary pathology

Damage and dysfunction of glomerular filtration barrier, causing significant leakage of plasma proteins without much glomerular inflammation

Significant inflammatory injury of the glomerulus resulting in passage of RBCs, inflammatory cells & plasma proteins

The principal site of glomerular injury

 Visceral epithelial cell (Podocyte) Endothelial cells, glomerular basement membrane (GBM), Mesangial cells, Parietal epithelial cells (>Crescents)

Clinical features

Hallmark:

Heavy Proteinuria: 3.5 g/24 h or Urine protein:creatinine ratio >3) 

Hypoalbuminemia, 

Edema

Lipiduria, Hyperlipidemia

Microscopic hematuria

Hypertension

Hypercoagulability                                                    

Hallmark:

Hematuria (RBC casts/dysmorphic RBCs)

Varying degrees of proteinuria and pyuria

Renal dysfunction

Hypertension

Associated Glomerular pathology

Minimal change disease (Primary and secondary)

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) (Primary and secondary)

Membranous-nephropathy (Primary and secondary)

Diabetic nephropathy

Amyloidosis

Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (crescentic)

IgA nephropathy (Berger disease)

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis

Alport syndrome

These syndromes, however, are not mutually exclusive. Some glomerular diseases may progress from one pattern to another or may present with considerable overlap between them, as a nephritic–nephrotic syndrome; features of nephrotic syndrome can concurrently occur with any form of nephritic syndrome but are most commonly seen with diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (seen in systemic lupus erythematosus) and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases primarily involves the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in this transverse section of the brain at the level of superior colliculus is substantia nigra. Degeneration of substantia nigra is seen in Parkinson's disease, also known as paralysis agitans.

Substantia nigra is pigmented due to the presence of neuromelanin granules, which help in the synthesis of dopamine. In Parkinson's disease, there is an absence/reduced pigmentation of the substantia nigra.

Bradykinesia, rigidity, and resting tremor are classic features of Parkinson's disease. Because of motor disability, it is also referred to as paralysis agitans.

Other options:

Option B: Depression is often a comorbid finding with Parkinson's disease, but is not due to damage to the substantia nigra.

Option C: Alzheimer’s disease is the most common cause of dementia. It is due to atrophy of the entorhinal cortex, located in the medial temporal lobe.

Option D: Huntington’s chorea is an autosomal dominant disorder of movement and cognition primarily involving the striatum (caudate nucleus and putamen).

questions.text: The following spot film was taken while performing a voiding cystourethrogram for a 2-year-old girl. Which of the following investigations will be useful for the evaluation of renal scarring in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) shows a unilateral grade 4 vesicoureteric reflux (VUR). The investigation of choice to evaluate for renal scarring in reflux nephropathy is the Tc-99m DMSA (dimercaptosuccinic acid) scan.

It is used in renal imaging to evaluate renal structure and morphology, particularly in paediatric imaging for the detection of scarring and pyelonephritis. DMSA is an ideal agent for the assessment of the renal cortex as it binds within the proximal tubules of the cortex with longer retention than other agents.

It allows a better assessment of differential renal function. It is a static scan as opposed to dynamic DTPA or MAG3 scans. Other common renal scans include:

  • Tc-99m DTPA (diethylene-triamine-pentaacetate) - used for direct measurement of GFR as it is cleared only via glomeruli with no tubular excretion (option B). 
  • Tc-99m MAG3 (mercaptoacetyltriglycine) - excreted through the renal route via both glomeruli infiltration and tubular excretion. Hence, in pediatric patients and patients with poor renal function, this test is considered superior to a DTPA scan. (option C).
  • In renovascular hypertension, captopril DTPA is used for screening and the gold standard investigation is renal angiography.

The following image shows a DMSA scan of a patient with renal failure with reduced uptake in both kidneys.

questions.text: A middle-aged obese man has presented to the OPD with acute pain around his left first metatarsophalangeal joint. He has a history of similar episodes in the past. X-ray is given below. Which drug is commonly used as initial treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the X-ray showing Martel's sign point towards a diagnosis of acute on chronic presentation of gout. Indomethacin is commonly used in the initial treatment of gout.

In addition to inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis, indomethacin and other NSAIDs also inhibit urate crystal phagocytosis.

Option A - Aspirin is not used because it causes renal retention of uric acid at low doses. It is uricosuric only at higher doses that are poorly tolerated.

Option C - Allopurinol is used for prophylaxis of gout.

Option D - NSAIDs are selected over colchicine because of troublesome diarrhea associated with colchicine.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the gynecology OPD for a routine Pap smear. The histopathology slide is shown below. Identify the cell marked as "A".
questions.solution:
The cell marked A is the superficial cell. 

ACOG guidelines recommend cervical exfoliative cytology every 3 years starting 21 years as screening for cervical cancer.

The image below shows a superficial cell (a) and an intermediate cell (b):


The image below shows parabasal cells (marked by black arrows):

 

Koilocytes are epithelial cells that contain eccentric, hyperchromatic, moderately enlarged nucleus that is displaced by large perinuclear vacuole. It is a feature of HPV infection.
