questions.text: Which of the following protozoan parasites is found in the lumen of the human small intestine?
questions.solution:
Image 2 shows the trophozoite of Giardia lamblia, which is the only protozoan parasite found in the lumen of the human small intestine. It lives in the duodenum and upper jejunum.

Other protozoan parasites found in the human small intestine do not occur in the lumen but are present in the epithelial cells lining the small intestine. These include:

  • Isospora belli
  • Cyclospora cayetanensis
  • Cryptosporidium parvum
  • Sarcocystis hominis

Other options:

Options A and C: Entamoeba histolytica and Balantidium coli are found in the human large intestine.

Option D: Trichomonas vaginalis is found in the genital tract.

The image given below shows the trophozoite of Giardia lamblia.

 

The image given below shows the trophozoite of Entamoeba histolytica.

 

The image given below shows the trophozoite of Balantidium coli.

 

The image given below shows the trophozoite of Trichomonas vaginalis.

questions.text: A patient presented with fever and painful neck swelling. She gives a history of sore throat and cough one week ago. Lab investigations revealed elevated T3 and T4 levels and elevated ESR. Which of the following statements about this condition is false?

choices.text: Treatment of choice is supportive care and NSAIDs
Women are generally affected three times more often than men
Both thyrotoxic and hypothyroid phases can be observed

questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of De Quervain’s thyroiditis, and it is not autoimmune in origin. It is subacute granulomatous thyroiditis that occurs secondary to viral infections.

Many viruses such as mumps, influenza, coxsackie, adenoviruses, and echoviruses have been clinically implicated in this condition. Peak incidence is observed at 30-50 years and women are generally affected three times more often than men.

Clinically, it presents as a painfully enlarged thyroid and is sometimes accompanied by fever.

It has three distinct phases:

  • Thyrotoxic phase
  • Hypothyroid phase
  • Recovery phase

Treatment includes large doses of aspirin, NSAIDs, steroids and/or beta-blockers to relieve the observable clinical symptoms. Antithyroid drugs do not have any role. In case the hypothyroid phase is prolonged - levothyroxine can be used.

questions.text: While filling the preoperative diet recommendations on the chart of a 22-year-old patient scheduled to undergo elective surgery, you would recommend fasting of at least

choices.text: 4 hours for solids, 2 hours for clear liquids
2 hours for solids, 4 hours for clear liquids
8 hours for solids, 2 hours for clear liquids
2 hours for solids, 8 hours for clear liquids

questions.solution:
Recommended preoperative fasting periods for all above 1 year of age are

  • 2 hours for clear liquids
  • 6 hours for light meal/milk
  • 8 hours for fried, fatty food

Recommended preoperative fasting period for neonates and infants are

  • 4 hours for breast milk
  • 6 hours for solids/formula feeds/cow's milk

Preoperative fasting is intended to reduce the risk of pulmonary aspiration.

Note: Clear liquids include, but are not limited to - water, tea & coffee without milk, fruit juices without pulp, carbonated drinks & carbohydrate-rich nutritional drinks.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman presents with a lower abdominal mass for the past 2 years. She had undergone uterine artery embolisation for fibroids 5 years ago. Ultrasound showed a homogeneous mass near the uterine fundus. On exploratory laparotomy,  the mass was observed to be attached to the greater omentum and it was excised. Histopathology of the mass is shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of a parasitic fibroid.  The given histopathological image shows interlacing bundles of uniform spindle-shaped smooth muscle cells with blunted nuclei that are characteristic of a fibroid.

A parasitic fibroid or a wandering fibroid gets cut off from its uterine origin and derives its blood supply from the vessels of the organ it is attached to. Thus, it can continue to grow in spite of uterine artery embolisation. It is managed by complete resection.

Option A: Pedunculated fibroids have a pedicle with which they're attached to the myometrium. 

Option C: Leiomyosarcoma commonly presents in postmenopausal women with sudden increase in size and postmenopausal bleeding. It would show nuclear atypia on histology.

Option D: Disseminated intraperitoneal leiomyomatosis involves large areas of sub peritoneal surfaces. It is seen during pregnancy and while on oral contraceptives.

questions.text: Which of the following does not occur in patients developing pre-eclampsia?

choices.text: Abnormal trophoblastic invasion of uterine vessels
Maladaptive immunological tolerance to fetal antigens
Maladaptation to cardiovascular changes of normal pregnancy
Increased placental perfusion due to inflammation

questions.solution:
Placental perfusion is reduced in patients developing pre-eclampsia.

The development of pre-eclampsia may be explained by:

  • Abnormal trophoblastic invasion of uterine vessels, leading to decreased placental perfusion.
  • Maternal inflammatory response directed against foreign fetal antigens leading to immunological maladaptation.
  • Maternal maladaptation to cardiovascular and inflammatory changes of normal pregnancy.
  • Genetic factors and epigenetic influences.

questions.text: You are evaluating a patient for the following painless and indurated ulcer. It developed 3 weeks ago and did not respond to oral antibiotic treatment. On examination, you note non-tender left axillary lymphadenopathy. A detailed history reveals digital penetration during sexual activity. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario of an indurated, painless ulcer is suggestive of an extragenital syphilitic chancre. They can occur over fingers, hands, and the oral cavity.

The incubation period of syphilis is 9-90 days. The primary chancre is a painless, indurated, button-like ulcer, as seen below, with painless lymphadenopathy. 

Option B: Chancroid or soft chancre presents with single or multiple painful ulcers.

Option C: Lymphogranuloma venereum presents with transient painful or painless ulcers later followed by painful lymphadenopathy.

Option D: Donovanosis presents with a beefy red, non-indurated painless ulcer that bleeds easily.

questions.text:
Match the following:
Parasite Organ of locomotion
A. Balamuthia mandrillaris  1. Flagella
B. Balantidium coli 2. Cilia
C. Trichomonas vaginalis 3. Pseudopod
D. Toxoplasma gondi 4. No Particular organ
questions.solution:
Parasite Organ of locomotion
Balamuthia mandrillaris  Pseudopod
Balantidium coli Cilia
Trichomonas vaginalis Flagella 
Toxoplasma gondi No Particular organ

Identification features of Trichomonas vaginalis:

  • Pear-shaped or ovoid
  • Short undulating membrane reaching upto the middle of the body
  • It has four anterior flagella and fifth running along the outer margin of the undulating membrane, which is supported at its base by a flexible rod, costa
  • A prominent axostyle runs throughout the length of the body and projects posteriorly like a tail
  • The cytoplasm shows prominent siderophillic granules, which are most numerous alongside the axostyle and costa
  • Jerky or twitching type of mobility

 

The above image shows Trichomonas vaginalis : 1-anterior flagella, 2-kinetosomes, 3-parabasal body, 4-costa, 5-parabasal fibers, 6-undulating membrane, 7-posterior flagellum, 8-hydrogenosomes, 9-axostyle, 10-nucleus, 11-pelta.

Obligate parasite - Organism cannot survive outside host

  • No cystic stage. Trophozoites are infective forms
  • Sexual transmission is the main route of infection. Other modes are fomites, babies during passage through infected birth canal
  • Affects squamous epithelium - Intracellular edema and so called chicken-like epithelium, is the most characteristic feature of trichomoniasis
  • Habitat: Vagina and cervix in female and urethra in males
  • Clinical features: Often asymptomatic in males. In females, it leads to pruritic vaginitis with greenish yellow discharge, strawberry mucosa and dysuria
  • Diagnosis: By wet mount microscopy of vaginal or urethral discharge, Culture (gold standard - Cysteine-peptone-liver-maltose (CPLM) medium and plastic envelope medium (PEM)), PCR, and by demonstration of antigen in vaginal smear by ELISA
  • Treatment: Metronidazole is the drug of choice and simultaneous treatment of both partners is recommended

The given image is the trophozoite form of the Balantidium coli. 

Balantidium coli occurs in two stages

  • Trophozoites are oval in shape and contain two nuclei. There is the presence of cilia over the entire surface and are larger around the mouth. Its anterior end is narrow and the posterior end is broad.  At the anterior end, there is a groove leading to the mouth (cytostome). Posteriorly, there is a small anal pore (cytopyge).
  • Cysts are smaller, round with a micronucleus, a macronucleus and many contractile vacuoles.

Living trophozoites/cysts are yellowish or greenish in color on wet mount.

The image given above shows Toxoplasma gondii which has two types of life cycles:

  • Enteric cycle
  • Exoenteric cycle

The enteric cycle occurs in definitive hosts such as cats. Exoenteric cycle occurs in intermediate hosts such as humans, mice, rats, etc.

Both sexual reproduction (gametogony) and asexual reproduction (schizogony) occur within the mucosal epithelial cells of the small intestine of the cat.

Sporozoites from the oocysts and bradyzoites from the tissue cysts enter the intestinal mucosa and multiply asexually. Tachyzoites are formed within the intermediate host.

Tachyzoites continue to multiply and spread locally by lymphatic system and blood, while the bradyzoites multiply slowly inside the tissue cyst.

The dormant bradyzoites inside the cyst may be reactivated in immune suppression causing renewed infection in the host.

Images b-1 and b-3 showing the Trophozoite and Cystic form of Balamuthia mandrillaris in Salmonella Shigella (SS) Agar respectively.

Balamuthia Mandrillaris

B. mandrillaris is a free-living ameba, which is a newly identified species reported to cause granulomatous amebic encephalitis (GAE).

Morphology
It exists in ameboid trophozoite stage. The flagellate stage is absent

  • It is relatively large (12-60 μm), irregular in shape and actively motile by broad pseudopodia.
  • Cyst of B. mandrillaris are usually spherical (6-20 μm), surrounded by a three-layered cyst wall: (1) outer irregular ectocyst, (2) a middle mesocyst and (3) an inner endocyst round wall. Under light microscopy, it appears to have two walls: (1) an outer irregular wall and (2) an inner smooth wall.
  • Infection is transmitled through respiratory tract, skin lesions, or eyes.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms causes the following disease?
questions.solution:
The image shows vesicles on the palms, soles, and oral mucosa, consistent with hand-foot-and-mouth disease. It is caused by coxsackievirus.

Hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD) is an exanthematous fever affecting mainly young children, characterized by oral and pharyngeal ulcerations and a vesicular rash of the palms and soles that may spread to the arms and legs. Vesicles heal without crusting, which clinically differentiates them from the vesicles of herpesviruses and poxviruses. It is usually a benign illness resolving in 1-2 weeks.

Coxsackie A16, A9, and B 1-3 are common causative agents.

Other diseases caused by Coxsackie A virus:

  • Aseptic meningitis is associated with a maculopapular rash.
  • Herpangina
  • Minor respiratory infections

Note: Conditions associated with the rash on palms and soles: Secondary syphilis, Hand foot, and mouth disease, Rickettsial feature caused by Rickettsia rickettsiae

questions.text: A 2-month-old previously healthy baby was brought to the casualty when the parents found that the baby was not breathing while asleep. Following resuscitative measures, the baby was still apnoeic, pulseless, and asystolic. You suspected sudden infant death syndrome in this child. Which of the following is not a risk factor of this condition?

choices.text: Sharing a bed with a family member
Sleeping in prone position or on the side

questions.solution:
Sleeping on hard/ firm surfaces is not associated with sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS). 

Crowded sleeping areas with many pillows, blankets, and stuffed toys, or old, soft mattresses are associated with an increased risk of SIDS. 

SIDS is also known as a 'cot' or 'crib' death. Usually, the parent finds the infant expired in the crib after putting them to sleep. It is an unexpected death in a healthy infant, whose autopsy may not reveal a cause of death. 

70% of cases of SIDS are found at autopsy to have intrathoracic petechiae in the pleura, epicardium, and thymus. However, this feature is considered to be an agonal phenomenon. The presence of this feature alone should not raise concern for manual suffocation. 

Most cases of SIDS occur between 1-7 months of age but can occur up to 2 years. The risk increases with male infants, multiple births, colder climates, and lower socioeconomic status families.

Ways to reduce the risk of SIDS include:

  • Avoiding sharing a bed with the infant 
  • Abstinence from smoking
  • Using hard/firm bedding and keeping the sleeping area clear
  • Ensuring the infant sleeps supine
  • Keeping the room temperature comfortable
  • Breastfeeding

Option A: Sharing a bed with a family member is associated with SIDS. The risk is augmented if the parent has consumed alcohol or sedative medications. 

Option C: Sleeping prone or on the side is strongly associated with SIDS. The risk of regurgitation and choking is high in infants who sleep prone. These positions are associated with instability. 

Option D: Overheating while sleeping can occur if the baby has a fever or has been placed in excessive clothing or in a warm room. Overheating has been associated with SIDS.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with chronic fatigue and generalized lymphadenopathy. Investigations revealed overexpression of BCL2. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of follicular lymphoma. This condition is associated with overexpression of BCL2.

It usually presents in middle age as painless generalized lymphadenopathy. The involvement of extranodal sites is relatively uncommon. It has an indolent waxing and waning course. 

In almost 50% of patients, this cancer gets transformed to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. The median survival rate is for 7-9 years.

The cell of origin for follicular lymphoma is germinal centre B cells. It shows (14;18) translocation.

Lymph node biopsy shows closely packed follicles. Centrocytes (small cells with the cleaved nucleus and scant cytoplasm) and centroblasts (large cells with open nuclear chromatin and multiple nucleoli) are seen.

Bone marrow is involved in 85% of the cases and shows para-trabecular lymphoid aggregates.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presented with yellowish discolouration of toenails. The discolouration spread proximally as a streak in the nail and later, the entire nail separated from the nailbed. What is the mechanism of action of the drug of choice for her?

choices.text: Binding to ergosterol and altering membrane functions
Formation of pore  in cell membrane

questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of tinea unguium or onychomycosis. The drug of choice is oral terbinafine which acts by inhibition of ergosterol synthesis. 

Terbinafine acts as a non-competitive inhibitor of squalene epoxidase, an early step enzyme in the synthesis of fungal ergosterol. This results in the accumulation of sterol squalene which is toxic to the organism.

The efficacy of terbinafine in onychomycosis is improved when combined with amorolfine 5% nail lacquer.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: According to NTEP, how will you classify a TB patient who had taken antitubercular drugs for only 3 weeks in the past?
questions.solution:
Under NTEP, a new case is defined as a TB patient who had never taken ATT previously or taken ATT for <1 month.

Related Pearl: Classification of TB Patients Based on History of Treatment

New case is defined as a TB patient who had

  • Never taken ATT previously or
  • Taken ATT for < 1 month

Previously treated Case : Patients who have received 1 month or more of Anti TB drugs in the past. These include:

  1. Recurrent TB: A TB patient who had completed course of treatment / declared cured and now presenting as microbiologically confirmed case
  2. Treatment after failure: Patients who had been treated for TB and their treatment failed at the end of most recent course of treatment
  3. Treatment after loss to follow up: A TB patient who had been treated > 1 month on ATT and registered as lost to follow up and now presenting as microbiologically confirmed case of TB
  4. Other previously treated patients: Patients who had been previously treated but whose outcome is now unknown/undocumented

Transferred in: A TB patient who has been received in a TB unit after having registered in another TB unit for treatment.

questions.text: A woman diagnosed with DCIS underwent surgery and is now posted for adjuvant radiotherapy with external beam radiotherapy. Which of the following isotopes is commonly used for the same?
questions.solution:
Cobalt-60 (Co-60 ) isotope is used for external beam radiotherapy (EBRT).

External beam radiotherapy is given as follows:

  • Cobalt machine - Co-60 produces gamma rays. It emits radiation of energy 1.25 MeV.
  • LINAC (linear accelerator) - X-ray beams are generated to provide ionising radiation.

The energy spectrum used in radiotherapy is classified as follows:

  • Orthovoltage - 200-500kV x-rays are produced. It is used to treat skin conditions. 
  • Megavoltage - 1-25 MV x-rays are produced. These are used in modern radiotherapy.

questions.text: You notice a 5-year-old boy walking very differently in an orphanage. On probing further the guardian informs that he has a history of frequently soiling his pants. On examination, you find a mass protruding through his anus and a diagnosis of rectal prolapse is made. Which of the following would be the most likely cause for this presentation?
questions.solution:
In this case, the most likely cause of rectal prolapse would be Trichuriasis. It is common in poor rural communities with inadequate sanitary facilities and soil contaminated with human or animal feces. The highest infection rate occurs among children between 5-15 years.

Clinical manifestations include chronic dysentery, anemia, poor growth, and developmental deficits. In heavy infections, adult worms can extend throughout the colon down to the rectum. Over time, inflammation of the rectum causes tenesmus leading to prolapse.

Other options: 

Pertussis would present with cough, low-grade fever, and sneezing. Increased abdominal pressure due to the persistent cough could cause a prolapse.

Chronic constipation is unlikely as the child has a history of frequently soiling his pants, suggestive of dysentery.

Cystic fibrosis would manifest much earlier in life with respiratory symptoms like recurrent pneumonia. These children have exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, causing protein and fat malabsorption. This leads to bulky, greasy stools and eventually a prolapse if untreated.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with recurrent bacterial infections and Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia. The flow cytometry analysis of the boy (Boxes 3& 4) is shown below (Boxes 1 & 2 are normal). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The deficiency of the CD40 and its absence in B cells interferes with class switching and the production of memory cells. The B-cell response to antigens, is unaffected, accounting for the presence of increased IgM antibodies. Hence, the condition is known as Hyper IgM syndrome.

The given clinical scenario and the flow cytometry is suggestive of Hyper IgM syndrome. The flow cytometry shows the following findings:

  • In comparison of image 3 to 1, where side scatter is plotted against CD 19: B-cell gating is present. 
    Gating of B cells means selecting a cell during a flow cytometry experiment for further analysis or data presentation.CD 19 is widely expressed on B cells. Hence the graph shows B cell gating. Side scatter measurement provides information about the granularity of a cell.
  • In comparison of image 4 to 2, where CD 40 is plotted against CD 19: B cells are present only in quadrant 4, which means that there is CD 40 deficiency.

The deficiency of the CD40 and its absence in B cells interferes with class switching and the production of memory cells. The B-cell response to antigens is unaffected, accounting for the presence of increased IgM antibodies. Hence, the condition is known as Hyper IgM syndrome.

Given below is the explanation of how to interpret flow cytometry results:

Interpretation of results:

Quadrant 1- Cells marked in green: -VE for A antigen, +VE for B antigen

Quadrant 2- Cells marked in purple: -VE for both the antigens.

Quadrant 3- Cells marked in yellow: +VE for both the antigens 

Quadrant 4- Cells marked in red: +VE for A antigen, -VE for B antigen

 

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about amniotic fluid?

choices.text: Major source is fetal urine after 20 weeks
It is primarily reabsorbed by fetal swallowing

questions.solution:
The composition of amniotic fluid is not the same throughout pregnancy but changes later in pregnancy due to contamination by fetal urinary metabolites.

In early pregnancy, it is identical to plasma in composition as it is mainly composed of a transudate of plasma. In late pregnancy, as amniotic fluid is primarily formed by fetal urination, the composition is altered. Disorders of the fetal kidney can lead to oligohydramnios.

Fetal swallowing is the primary method of resorption of amniotic fluid. Disorders of swallowing in the fetus can cause polyhydramnios.

Amniotic fluid is alkaline in nature and this helps in differentiating it from vaginal secretions which are acidic. This forms the basis of the nitrazine paper test used for the diagnosis of premature rupture of membranes.

questions.text: You administer methyl ergometrine to a patient with postpartum hemorrhage in the labor ward. Which of the following adverse effects will you not expect to occur in this patient?
questions.solution:
Administration of Ergot alkaloids (such as methyl ergotamine) result in hypertension.

The use of ergot alkaloids is preferably avoided in hypertensive patients.

Adverse effects of ergometrine/methylergometrine are:

  • Nausea and vomiting 
  • Hypertension
  • Decrease in pain threshold but analgesia might be required
  • Decrease in milk secretion postpartum (due to dopaminergic action especially at higher doses)

questions.text: A college student presents with fever, headache, and confusion. Lumbar puncture was positive for HSV DNA, detected by PCR. An MRI brain is done to localize the lesions. Which area on the brain is most likely to show lesions?
questions.solution:
The clinical hallmark of HSV encephalitis has been the acute onset of fever and focal neurologic symptoms and signs, especially in the temporal lobe.

Investigation of choice includes HSV-DNA demonstration in CSF by PCR. 

The image below is a coronal T2-weighted MR image showing a high signal intensity in the temporal lobes.

questions.text: Which of the following is an anti-inflammatory cytokine?
questions.solution:
IL-4 is an anti-inflammatory cytokine.

It induces alternatively activated macrophages. This results in tissue repair and the resolution of inflammation.

The following are anti-inflammatory cytokines:

  • IL-4
  • IL-10
  • IL-13
  • TGF-β
  • Lipoxins

Lipoxins suppress inflammation by inhibiting leukocyte recruitment. They inhibit neutrophil chemotaxis and adhesion to endothelium.

Related Pearl: Cytokines

Interleukins Main sources
IL-1 (α and β) Macrophages and other cell types
IL-2 T cells
IL-3 T cells
IL-4 TH cells
IL-5 TH cells
IL-6 TH, macrophages, fibroblasts
IL-8 Macrophages, others
IL-10 T, B cells, macrophages

Pro-inflammatory cytokines: 

  • IL-1: induces inﬂammation, fever, and sepsis, activates TNF-α; proliferation and differentiation of T, B, and other cells; bone marrow cell proliferation
  • IL-2: promote growth and differentiation of T and B cells; cytotoxicity of T and NK cells; secretion of other lymphokines
  • IL-6: promote B cell stimulation & differentiation; mediator of acute phase reactions; IgG production
  • IL-8: attracts and activates neutrophils in inflammatory regions; neutrophil chemotaxis
  • IFN-α: antiviral, immunoregulatory (enhance MHC class I, NK-cell activity), antiproliferative
  • TNF-α: activate macrophages and cytotoxic cells, induce cachexia, acute phase proteins, cytokines such as IL-1 and IL-6

Anti-inflammatory cytokines: 

  • IL-4: proliferation of B and cytotoxic cells; increases IgG1 and IgE production; enhances MHC-class II receptor
  • IL-10: inhibits IFN-γ and IL-12 production; inhibits IFN production and mononuclear cell functions
  • IL-13

Acute inflammation and sepsis: 

  • TNF-α
  • IL-1

Special Cytokines: 

  1. IFN-γ: 
    • Granuloma formation
    • Antiviral
    • Immunoregulatory (enhances MHC classes I and II and macrophage activation)
    • Antiproliferative
  2. TGF-β: 
    • Fibrosis 
    • Activate macrophages
  3. VEGF:
    • promotes angiogenesis

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy rapidly develops hypoglycemia after moderate activity. Blood examination reveals raised levels of ketone bodies, lactic acid, and triglycerides. On examination, the liver and kidneys are found to be enlarged. Histopathology of the liver shows deposits of glycogen in an excess amount. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given features are consistent with von Gierke's disease. It is the most common glycogen storage disease.

Enzyme deficient in this condition is glucose-6-phosphatase (common to both glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis). Inheritance is autosomal recessive. 

Von Gierke disease (type I glycogen storage disorder) occurs due to the deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase enzyme in the liver, kidney, and intestinal mucosa. Patients present commonly by 3-4 months of age with hypoglycemia (leading to seizures), lactic acidosis, and hepatomegaly. Affected children often have a doll-like face with fat cheeks, relatively thin extremities, short stature, and a protuberant abdomen due to massive hepatomegaly. The kidneys are also enlarged, whereas the spleen and heart are not involved. Laboratory findings include hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, and hyperlipidemia.

A definitive diagnosis is made using a liver biopsy. Fructose and galactose restriction in the diet is advised.

questions.text: An ICU patient dies due to cardiac failure. After some time, you notice that the deceased body has become cold. What is this phenomenon known as?
questions.solution:
The phenomenon of cooling of the body following a death is called algor mortis/ postmortem cooling.

After death, the body loses heat mainly by conduction and convection. It is one of the early changes occurring after death. Temperature is usually measured in the rectum or abdominal cavity (subhepatic region).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a dimorphic fungus?
questions.solution:
Pneumocystis jirovecii is a yeast-like fungus and not a dimorphic fungus.

Dimorphic fungi exist in the yeast form in body tissues and cultures maintained at 37°C, and in the filamentous form in cultures at room temperature(25°C).

Examples of dimorphic fungi include:

  • Blastomyces dermatitidis
  • Coccidioides immitis
  • Paracoccidioides brasiliensis
  • Talaromyces marneffei
  • Sporothrix schenckii
  • Histoplasma capsulatum
  • Coccidioides posadasii

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

Blastomyces : Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.
